story:
Shifting Gears: Small Business to Community Arts Center  

Two years ago, my family and I took a giant leap as we decided it was best for me to have a more flexible schedule while our children were young. I'm a mother of triplet boys who just turned 5 and I've been a K-5 Visual Art Educator for the past 10 years. Between the cost of childcare and the extensive appointment schedule I was maintaining for our special needs son, the regular full time working schedule was not serving our family well. Created to Grow was born as a labor of love and leap of faith and we are at a crossroads. Our goal from the start was to begin a business that could fund and support a non-profit to serve the community through the arts. As we look at our position as a business we are at a turning point of sorts and we need your help to flip the switch on the second chapter in Created to Grow's story.

The business itself operates at about 50% capacity and we know there are many people in our community that could use these services and, with that, the first goal of the non-profit version of Created to Grow will be to support and fund a scholarship program. In addition to the scholarship  program, I hope to offer teen safe haven after school programs, free or reduced cost art therapy programs, and have more flexibility to donate programming at local community events. Your donation today will help us become more than a small business and be a part of building the non profit phase of Created to Grow Community Arts Center. 

During that last year of teaching, when the boys were 2 years old, I was fortunate enough to spend time in San Diego for the National Art Educators Association Conference and learn about an incredible community resource call ARTS: A Reason To Survive. This organization partners professional artists with homeless youth and families and provides a safe haven of creative endeavors during the between school and bedtime hours. To  say I was inspired would be a huge understatement. I wanted this here for my students, for our community. 

The process of starting a non-profit was not something within reach given the time and financial constraints that were on my plate, but as I wrapped up the school year, this "missing resource" in our neighborhood dug into me. We live just outside the heart of the arts district in NE Minneapolis and yet, there was no arts specific organization serving our youth and families. I had two big weights on my shoulders. One was personal, how we were going to manage the following years losing my income to childcare and balancing all of the needs of not only three toddlers, but one with significant special needs. The other was ideological, I now had the knowledge of this missing piece for our community and, in many ways, the educational and professional background to make it happen, I already felt like it was my job to plant the seed. 

I attended some small business classes and decided to start small, with a business model and build it to profitability during the leave of absence that I would have from my traditional teaching career.  Created to Grow was born as a small business providing classes, open studio hours, after school programs and special events. The idea was build a business to fund the non-profit and then head back to my teaching career in 3-5 years. Well two years have passed and 3 will be here before we know it and we have some very big decisions to make. I've created this Indiegogo campaign to put it in the communities' hands. 

This is where I get brutally honest about where we stand as a business. Probably more honest than is recommended, but if I'm going to donate to something I want to know exactly why the need is there and how the donation will be used and you deserve that same honesty from me when you are considering donating. 

In the grand scheme of things Created to Grow is doing fairly well. We are a business that still has its doors open 2 years in, which many statistics say is rare. Some months we break even, but we are, of course still working to pay off the initial investment of getting the doors open and our good months are not yet consistent. We are growing and have a strong base of clientele that are loyal to our programs and our community has become like a little family. People that come, come back and bring friends. As I stated earlier, we are now operating at about 50% capacity which is enough to continue as a business, but not enough to support the launch of the non-profits 

In February, I have to tell my school whether I'll be back to teach in the fall. Given 3 years without my income while investing in a small business, I have to go back. We don't have any more time as a family to live in this kind of debt, there is a limit on how long we can live under the financial stress that comes with a new business.

In October of 2017, our lease is up. Does Created to Grow stay in our space, move to a new space, become a business without a specific location or simply close our doors. This is the hardest part for me to wrap my head around. I need to go back to my teaching job, but we haven't reached the point where employees are feasible, meaning the thing that makes the most sense is to simply close the doors or become a mobile business; maintain the name without the space so that it could be an on the side income. These options feel crushing. The literal blood, sweat and tears in this little studio feel like a horrible shame to walk away  from, but the hardest part is walking away from the people. My incredible families that walk in the door and create with me every day. The stories they tell, the love they share and the growth I've witnessed are so important to me. How can I take that away from the community? 

With that I decided to look at the plan, spend some time reflecting and I've come to this place. I would love to see Created to Grow continue, I want this studio to grow and, more than anything, I want it to be able to form that non-profit that supports the arts for all of our community members, not just those that can afford our classes and parties. The original plan had three parts.  Opening and running as a solo employee business for 1-3 years, return to teaching while hiring a manager/teachers to sustain the studio and reaching profitability at 5-7 years. At that stage, we flip the switch build a board and turn business to non-profit. Maintaining the programs that make money to develop programs that serve. 

So here we sit, a small business at a crossroads. We could very well continue to grow enough to be at the hiring stage we need to be to continue on this path while I return to my teaching career next fall, but it is feeling unlikely and with that I decided to see if we could jump a step. This campaign supports the launch of the Created to Grow Community Arts Center. Read on to see the specific ways that these funds will be put to use. So many helped to launch our phase one and so many support our business each day, I hope to see you support the next phase. Keep our Creative Space in the neighborhood and help us not only continue to provide the high quality creative education you've come to expect from our programs, but also to serve the whole community to provide our programs to our friends and neighbors who may not otherwise have the chance to participate in the creative programs we offer. 

What We Need & What You Get

What I am hoping to do with this campaign is tie up the loose ends of some of the initial business expenses that are holding us back from stepping beyond the break even point and into the place where we can pay employees. The campaign will also support the legal fees of hiring an attorney and tax accountant to assist in our shift in status from business to non-profit. Any leftover funds will go towards to supply orders and scholarship funds for our existing programs so children that can not afford to participate are able. 

The Impact

While Created to Grow will continue to offer the incredible classes and special events we already do, we will add the following features to our programming to serve the community:

  • Scholarship Programs for our current arts classes, open studios and camps
  • Build a Teen Safehaven Arts Space with mentors for youth who need a safe and productive space to spend their afternoon. 
  • Provide Art Therapy Group Programs on a freewill donation basis. 
  • Provide Low Cost Creative Programming around the Neighborhood at events like the Farmers Market, Art-a-whirl, Eastside Neighborhood Services and other local events. 
     

Risks & Challenges

This business has not been without its challenges. As I said before, it is growing, but not at the rate needed for us to sustain in beyond my return to teaching. Our biggest challenge right now is filling the classes and workshops and, as a non-profit, this would be critical to maintain the programming.  

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand not everyone can get behind us financially, but you can certainly think of us when you clean out your crafting spaces at home. Helping us spread the word is extremely helpful to our cause. 

  • New and used supply donations art takes materials:
    -new markers, crayons, colored pencils, glue, mod podge, paints (ask for preferred brands) puff balls, google eyes, feathers, sequins, etc. really if you can make something with it we will use it. 
  • Used or Upcycling Materials: Cereal boxes, Birchbox boxes, fabric, yarn, spools, buttons, frames, scrapbook paper, old calendars and magazines, children's books, jars of various shapes and sizes. 
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools and help us spread the word, encourage family and friends to support the work we do.

We understand not everyone can get behind us financially, but you can certainly think of us when you clean out your crafting spaces at home. Helping us spread the word is extremely helpful to our cause. 

New and used supply donations art takes materials:-new markers, crayons, colored pencils, glue, mod podge, paints (ask for preferred brands) puff balls, google eyes, feathers, sequins, etc. really if you can make something with it we will use it. 
Used or Upcycling Materials: Cereal boxes, Birchbox boxes, fabric, yarn, spools, buttons, frames, scrapbook paper, old calendars and magazines, children's books, jars of various shapes and sizes. 
Use the Indiegogo share tools and help us spread the word, encourage family and friends to support the work we do.

story:
Help Bring Life to New Icons!

Once a year, I have had the opportunity to attend an Iconography Retreat with Father Abbot Damian Higgins, a skilled iconographer. These retreats have been a source of healing, spiritual growth, and Christian artwork.

With your help, I will once again attend this annual retreat from April 13-17, 2016. 

This year, I will be working on an icon of Sts. Cyprian and Cornelius. Other possible subjects include St. Raymond Nonnatus and/or Our Lady Star of the Sea. Of course, should a contributor choose to commission a piece, that will be one of this year's saintly subjects.

What Is Needed 

This campaign seeks to raise funds to cover:

  • The retreat fees ($375)
  • Meals during the retreat ($40)
  • Materials for 2 extra icon boards (one is included in tuition) ($40-80)
  • Production costs and shipping of fundraising products including icon boards, cards, and magnets (varies)
  • Indiegogo's nominal fee for their services
Any amount over and above these needs will go towards materials including pigments, boards, glue, gesso, and gold leaf in order that I might begin doing iconography at home.

What YOU Get

For your support, you may choose among the following gifts based on your level of contribution:

  • $5 - Icon Magnet or Greeting Card of your choice of available stock
  • $25 - Six (6) Icon Magnets or Greeting Cards of your choice of available stock
  • $45- One 5"x7"  Wood Board Icon Print
  • $65 - One 8"x10" Wood Board Icon Print
  • $85 - Collection of three (3) 5"x7" Wood Board Icon Prints
  • $125 - Collection of three (3) 8"x10" Wood Board Icon Prints
Last but not least,
  • One contributor of $275 will have the opportunity to commission a hand-painted icon of their Saint of choice (as agreed upon with the artist), in traditional egg tempra with gold leaf.


Icon subjects to choose from include:
  • Theotokos (Mary) & Infant Jesus 
  • Our Lady of the Rosary
  • St. Joseph the Worker with Jesus as a child
  • Sts. Anne (or Anna) & Joachim
  • St. Jude
  • St. Philomena
  • St. Maximilian Kolbe
  • St. Gregory the Great
  • St. John of Damascus
  • ... and this year's saints, Sts. Cyprian & Cornelius, among others.

Please Keep In Mind...

While this campaign goal is significantly above the retreat and material fees, this is to cover the expense of providing actual products to thank contributors. If you would like for your full amount to help pay for the retreat fees without receiving a product, please select that accordingly.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can still help!

  • Share this campaign with friends!
  • Pray for a fruitful retreat, that I and the others in attendance will be filled with the Holy Spirit as we seek to capture a sliver of beauty on our boards.

Thank you for your support! God Bless!

story:
Stripped.ego is an all natural body care company based in Brooklyn, NY. "Stripped" stands for the products being “stripped down” to the bare minimum, no extra additives. "Ego" stands for the confidence that we want you to feel while wearing our product.  With Premium ingredients like argon oil, raw Shea butter, rice bran oil, and coconut oil, we can assure you that underneath your clothes your skin will feel silky smooth and is being nourished at the same time. 

What motivates us is being able to provide quality and premium skin care products that are accessible to all while catering to everyone's specific skin needs. What prompted our interest in this field is our determination to put " you in a bottle." Literally! We all have friends and family members with really dry skin. Some of them suffer from eczema  which causes them to scratch their skin often as a result of the irritation that they are experiencing. Thus, we began our plan to create an all natural product that would nourish and soothe their skin. "People care about what they put into their stomachs, but often times forget that your skin is your bodies largest organ and you must treat your skin with care as well." -Stripped.ego


What We Need & What You Get

It is very difficult to start a new business and to be new business owners at the same time. We have completely invested ourselves into this project. We are lacking funds and we are currently using our personal money to take care of all business expenses. Frankly, it is just not enough. With the money we raise with our campaign, we will be able to take care of both product and general insurance. In New York State upon registering your business you must publish your business information in both a weekly periodical, and a local daily newspaper.


  • insurance- $1000

  • publishing fee- $2000

  • start up expenses 

The Impact

With each contribution, we will be able to take care of all the legalities which are time sensitive. We have gone to various organic and all natural stories locally and developed a relationship with them. It is our goal to grow with the community by purchasing and selling locally as well as online.  


Risks & Challenges

We all come from backgrounds where nothing has been handed to us. We have had to work very hard to get to where we are currently. With the help of friends and family who believe in us we have been able to toss a pebble into this huge pond. But now its time to make a big wave and we know we cannot do that alone.

It is statistically proven that within the first five years most small business fail. By developing a premium product, selling locally, online, to friends and family as well as at different festivals we can establish a positive presence within the community. Aside from selling our product we also plan to be involved in community events and give back which is extremely important to us.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can spread the word, share, and re-post we will be most appreciative!!

positive blessings to all!

Peace&Love.xoxo

Stripped.ego

story:
Hello and thank you for visiting our INDIEGOGO page! We are Fashion Philosophy - a London based independent publication focusing on showcasing UK talent and bringing together art, fashion, and photography. We are a team of young professionals working their way up in the fashion industry; our objective is to give students and young upcoming artists a platform to show their work and have their voice heard.


Short Summary

Up until now our platform and magazine have been entirely self-funded, however in order to make our exhibition launch happen we would like to collect funds to bring you the best content and event as possible.

By sending donations you will help us to cover costs of the venue and the production of our display. The idea is to have our exhibition launch open to public - where everyone can browse through the first two issues of our magazine, and see what's coming to our platform in the near future. On the day, you will not only see our work progress but you will also meet the Fashion Philosophy team and contributors.

The display we are preparing is to showcase our work from the beginnings of the magazine, featuring projects by a number of photographers and artists.


What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise £600 to partially cover our expenses. This will go primarily towards securing our venue space on the 10th May, printing and mounting our display, producing Fashion Philosophy zines for all attendees of our exhibition launch, and lastly to cover the costs of decorations and drinks.

If we do not reach our goal, we will still use all donated funds as best as possible to produce a brilliant exhibition.


    The Impact

    Fashion Philosophy was launched as a platform in January 2015, and by September, we digitally published the first issue of our bi-annual magazine. In short time, we reached over 300,000 views and impressions! With this exhibition launch we would like to spread the word about our platform and project, and invite students to contribute to our future magazine issues.

    This campaign is a brilliant opportunity for us to establish Fashion Philosophy as a worthy platform, help students and young upcoming artists to showcase their work, and to reach out to an even bigger audience.


    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you're unable to donate, you can still help by spreading the word! The reason behind our exhibition launch is to gain a bigger audience and gain additional exposure. Share our links on social media and invite your friends to donate on our page. Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

On the 4th February 1945, Esther Brunstein was among a group of women forced to walk from a slave labour camp near Hanover to the Nazi death camp at Bergen-Belsen. They had survived the ghettos, the death camp at Auschwitz and months of hard labour in appalling conditions. They walked through the night. People died or were killed on the way. Esther lived to tell the story. These death marches were a part of the horror of the Holocaust:

 Esther Brunstein

This appeal is is to help realise and network the final phase of the Honouring Esther project: walking the actual route of the Nazi death march that Esther Brunstein survived.


Honouring Esther was launched as part of Holocaust Memorial Day in Bristol in January 2015; the first walk took place in April on the 70th anniversary of the liberation of the Bergen-Belsen death camp.


The project concludes in Germany with a two day walk: 4th/5th February 2016. 71 years later we will retrace Esther's steps, bearing witness, expressing solidarity with all refugees, using our creativity to connect the past with the present.


Lead Artists: Richard White and Lorna Brunstein


"We are bringing an element of the story of the Holocaust into our times and into our world.  We believe this is a timely project: it is already generating many poignant resonances and with your support we can multiply and amplify them"


Lorna is the daughter of Holocaust survivors, Esther Brunstein is her mother. Lorna's art work concerning identity and inherited trauma draws on that second generation experience.


Richard is a walking artist experimenting with digital media to explore and reveal hidden heritage:

"Lorna and I have collaborated on several creative projects in the past. Honouring Esther combines the passion of both our interests. From the outset this project has been about human rights, exile and inheritance. Esther holds strong views on human rights and internationalism and in many ways it was that spirit which kept her alive and enabled her to live her life in post war Europe. We are acting in that spirit."

"In April 2015 we walked the route of the death march Esther survived, transposed to Somerset, where we live.  We invited others to join us on foot and online. Together we co-created themed stopping points where the actual walk crossed the transposed line of the death march, the ‘stations’ of our walk."

The walk will remind us that a refugee’s journey continues until they find safety and a welcome and a sense of belonging. For many it is a life long search. In the end we are all migrants and we all need safety, security, love and friendship. If you are interested in finding out more, check out the blog here: Honouring Esther

Feedback from the Somerset walk:
“Very moving and resonant walk. You have brought this difficult experience to life and related it to the current asylum seekers experience. Especially resonating with other walks.”

In February 2016, in Germany, walkers will stop at the same intersections, the stations, to listen, remember, reflect, capture the moment in some way and network thoughts and images on social media.

What We Need & What You Get

Your support will help:

  • build the network, amplify the resonances
  • support the production of print materials for promotion and dissemination
  • promote and support engagement in the project in advance and while it is live
  • document the walk in Germany
  • support logistics for the walk in Germany, travel and equipment
  • support online exhibition and distribution of materials generated on the walk

All backers will be thanked and named if they wish, on the website,

All backers will be invited to an end of project event.

Look out for backers perks!

The Impact

This final phase, if fully funded, offers a way for people in the localities and worldwide to engage in a powerfully delivered story from the Holocaust, making connections into the current refugee crisis. With your support, an historical experience of persecution, displacement and exile will be shared, articulated and connected to the present. It will be a significant step in making real the slogan ‘refugees welcome’, expressing and demonstrating empathy of the long journey to safety and security. We hope that those we connect with, especially in the UK, will feel inspired by Esther’s spirit of humanitarian internationalism and welcome all refugees as they reach safety. This is the impact your support will help us achieve.

We will:

  • do the walk and network the experience live;
  • connect with organisations and individuals in the locality of the walk: refugee hosts, second and third generation survivors, liberators, perpetrators and witnesses;
  • document the walk and share the experience on completion;
  • create new links with schools, colleges and multifaith communities;
  • develop new artwork.

In Germany in 2016 we will bear witness again to the Holocaust and to a specific death march but, more than that, we are making it resonate with our lives now.

We will consult the walkers and all those associated with it on the impact of the project and produce a report. We approach the final phase with enthusiasm and confidence. Feedback from the walk in Somerset has been extremely positive:

“Powerful, moving and highly engaging in content and format. The importance of finding innovative approaches to creating work on this subject clearly cannot be underestimated”

Risks & Challenges

Richard White organises creative walks on a regular basis, as a participatory media producer he brings a wealth of professional skills and experience. Lorna Brunstein contributes a range of project management skills from her background in arts administration. The project is supported in kind by Bath Spa University, this support includes managing and holding the budget. The first phase was delivered successfully, a small budget has been carried over.

This final phase is scaleable depending on the final budget. Richard and Lorna have already committed to undertake the walk. The walk from Ovelgonne to Bergen-Belsen will be risk assessed in February, the first challenge for the walkers will be the weather, it will be very cold.

In this final phase we are hoping that people will walk with us and others will join us online. In the cold, social networking and geo-locating will be a challenge.

There is a risk that walkers will not be able to complete the walk, this is why a support vehicle and driver is included in our costings.

Live social networking from the walk is therefore at risk and apart from actually doing the walk this is our greatest challenge. The technology could let us down in some way, we will also be recording the work in an analogue form. Fully funded all this will be mitigated, the walk will be documented by an additional two person team. There will be back up equipment at our accommodation.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word, tell family, friends and colleagues. Email and text.
  • Follow and get involved with the project on social media from now on, help build our social media presence and participate;
  • Like the facebook page, follow the project on twitter @forcedwalks
  • Join us on the walk in Germany;
  • Walk somewhere else at the same time in the same spirit and connect with us;
  • Contact us to offer support in kind..promotion, translation, logistics support, networking support.
  • Please network this Indiegogo campaign, use the Indiegogo share tools;

story:
What Happened

Coming back home to Oakland, CA from Burning Man 2015, the Amphora art car’s engine overheated, seized, and cracked, so the poor bus has been held captive in the Sierra foothills until the engine can be replaced! Without a new engine, the Amphora can’t return to Burning Man in 2016 for its 5th year in Black Rock City!

The Amphora art car, made by Love Potion Camp, is a 24’ school bus surrounded by a huge bottle of swirling love potion, made from 7200 programmable LEDs mounted to an aluminum frame and diffused with panels of Rowlux (a multi-lensed effect film). The fur-lined downstairs is a cozy lounge, while a ladder in the rear leads to the upstairs dance floor.

We miss you, Black Rock City, and we’re REALLY going to miss you if we can’t fund these repairs.

What We Need

We’re planning to get a fully-refurbished engine so we can avoid any future engine problems! At a minimum, the engine replacement will cost $10k, including parts/labor/taxes/warranty. 

However, this amount ONLY covers the engine of the bus. We also want to revamp the art car to bring more glowing interactivity to BRC! Our funding goals are as follows:

  • +$10000: Replace the engine and bring Amphora back to Oakland. We’ll be able to bring her back to Burning Man in 2016 and share her with our local Burner community in the Bay Area.

  • + $1000: STRETCH GOAL Repair “back patio”. The wood cladding on the Amphora had to be broken and torn off in order to tow the bus to the mechanic; without rebuilding, there is no way to go upstairs.

  • + $300: STRETCH GOAL Fresh paint job. The faux-wood finish is faded and stained, and the rebuilt back patio will need to be painted; let’s get Amphora looking new again!

  • + $700: STRETCH GOAL More lights! The neck of the bottle has space for 800 more lights; we’ll need to reconfigure our existing lights to incorporate the new ones and power them up.

  • + $1500: STRETCH GOAL Extended interactivity. We can add live video, sound-driven pattern generation, and hands-free Leap Motion control!

  • + $2000: STRETCH GOAL New Rowlux diffusion film. This trippy plastic looks beautiful, but breaks very easily. We've devised a new way to work with this material to last longer while still looking awesome, but at $3/sq ft, this stuff isn't cheap!

  • + $$$: Anything extra from this campaign will be used to help cover the cost of storing and maintaining the Amphora 

What You Get

What do you get in return for your help? In addition to cool perks like glow-in-the-dark Amphora t-shirts, Love Potion paddles, and uv-reactive Love Potion necklaces, Love Potion is going to leverage our alternate identity as a public makerspace to offer perks like classes (see below), rental space (for meetings, events, or private parties), and membership to our shop! All mailable perks will also come with an Amphora sticker.

UV-Glow Love Potion Glow-in-the-Dark T-Shirt
Love Potion Paddle Amphora Sticker

Learn a Skill!

For your $150, you can learn one of the following skills at our Oakland makerspace!

Pole fitness
Come on, we know what you have secretly been dreaming of... So now, don't dream it, be it! Pole-dancing is not only a joyful way to get in touch with your inner sexy goddess, it is also a fun workout to get you into great shape. Taught at LPC by our very own instructor Sam from Foxipole. Defy gravity & start to fly around the pole! (4X 90-minute classes, 0/3 claimed)
Acroyoga for you and up to 3 of your friends
The best of two worlds, acrobatics and yoga combined into one fun work-out. Each group will learn how to use flexibility and strength in a playful and physical way to give each other support. Workshop will be taught at LPC.  Classes will be up to 12 people. (each group gets 2X 90-minute classes, 0/3 claimed)
Beginner welding
Learn about different welding technologies, MIG, TIG, stick. Learn how welding works, what makes a good weld, how to slice through metal with a plasma torch and use power and hand tools to finish your work. You will have time to practice welding, and finish by creating your own metal abstract sculpture! No experience necessary. (2X 3-hour classes, all claimed—really wanna learn to weld? Send us a message!)
Couch to 5K
Starting late on your resolutions? Hate running? You're not alone! Led by a former marathoner and fellow run-hater, get your booty up and running with this 8-week training program. You will train for either a April 3 or June 5 race. Meeting in Oakland for training runs, with schedule flexibility for long weekends. (8X 60- to 90-minute classes, 0/10 claimed)
Light up your costume
Does your costume need some extra glow or lights? Learn how to add lights to any costume, accessories, wigs, sword, crown or tiara. Learn how to select clothes for light or glow modification, choose light or glow technologies (LED, EL wire, fiber optics and more), power your pieces, and attach it to your clothes. Bring your own costume or accessories to work on during this workshop. (1X 2.5-hour class, 0/8 claimed)
Unity game programming
Learn to use the Unity 3D technology suite to produce high quality 3D games that run on a variety of platforms. Together we will go through the fundamentals of using the Unity Editor, GameObjects, Cameras, and Scenes and learn how to apply scripts to drive behaviors to objects in the world. At the end you will have a simple game you can show your friends. Requires: laptop computer with 4GB RAM, Intel i5 or equivalent, 3D graphics processor, and Unity 3D installed. Programming experience not required, but helpful. Unity uses C#. (2X 3-hour classes, 0/6 claimed)
Beginner crochet
Learn crocheting basics, including how to hold yarn, which size of crochet hook to choose, and how to read basic patterns. By the end of this workshop, you will have created your first chili pepper fridge magnet! (1X 3-hour class, 0/10 claimed)

Other Perks

  • Photoshoot with Avery Wong Photography
  • Makerspace membership at Love Potion Collective

The Impact

Love Potion has been bringing art and art cars to the playa since 2006, providing enjoyment and rides for hundreds of participants. Without an art car permit in 2015, we were unable to do our thing at full capacity, and we miss you! We want to see you again, this time for everyone and every night! In supporting the Amphora, you are supporting the greater Burning Man community, by giving us more ways to bring art and interactivity to Black Rock City and beyond.

Back at home in Oakland, CA, Love Potion maintains a community makerspace, Love Potion Collective, where members can learn new skills and use a wide variety of tools and equipment to make their projects come to life. Love Potion also promotes year-round Burning Man community through hosting burner socials, gallery shows, and interactive art/music events.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign on social media and get the word out! Are you a fan of LED lights and/or art cars? Let your peers in these networks know that the Amphora needs their help! The more people who share this page, the more likely we are to reach our goal.

Don’t forget to use Indiegogo’s share tools

Looking for a one-of-a-kind experience? Can't make it to the Playa this year and still wanna inhale some of the special dust... uhm flair? Treat yourself and three friends to an artisan meal especially concocted for this occasion! Whichever donor generates the most overall funding through the Indiegogo referral program will receive this super special dinner perk in the Love Potion gallery!
story_txt:
What Happened
Coming back home to Oakland, CA from Burning Man 2015, the Amphora art car’s engine overheated, seized, and cracked, so the poor bus has been held captive in the Sierra foothills until the engine can be replaced! Without a new engine, the Amphora can’t return to Burning Man in 2016 for its 5th year in Black Rock City!The Amphora art car, made by Love Potion Camp, is a 24’ school bus surrounded by a huge bottle of swirling love potion, made from 7200 programmable LEDs mounted to an aluminum frame and diffused with panels of Rowlux (a multi-lensed effect film). The fur-lined downstairs is a cozy lounge, while a ladder in the rear leads to the upstairs dance floor.We miss you, Black Rock City, and we’re REALLY going to miss you if we can’t fund these repairs.
What We Need
We’re planning to get a fully-refurbished engine so we can avoid any future engine problems! At a minimum, the engine replacement will cost $10k, including parts/labor/taxes/warranty. However, this amount ONLY covers the engine of the bus. We also want to revamp the art car to bring more glowing interactivity to BRC! Our funding goals are as follows:
+$10000: Replace the engine and bring Amphora back to Oakland. We’ll be able to bring her back to Burning Man in 2016 and share her with our local Burner community in the Bay Area.
+ $1000: STRETCH GOAL Repair “back patio”. The wood cladding on the Amphora had to be broken and torn off in order to tow the bus to the mechanic; without rebuilding, there is no way to go upstairs.
+ $300: STRETCH GOAL Fresh paint job. The faux-wood finish is faded and stained, and the rebuilt back patio will need to be painted; let’s get Amphora looking new again!
+ $700: STRETCH GOAL More lights! The neck of the bottle has space for 800 more lights; we’ll need to reconfigure our existing lights to incorporate the new ones and power them up.
+ $1500: STRETCH GOAL Extended interactivity. We can add live video, sound-driven pattern generation, and hands-free Leap Motion control!
+ $2000: STRETCH GOAL New Rowlux diffusion film. This trippy plastic looks beautiful, but breaks very easily. We've devised a new way to work with this material to last longer while still looking awesome, but at $3/sq ft, this stuff isn't cheap!
+ $$$: Anything extra from this campaign will be used to help cover the cost of storing and maintaining the Amphora 


What You Get
What do you get in return for your help? In addition to cool perks like glow-in-the-dark Amphora t-shirts, Love Potion paddles, and uv-reactive Love Potion necklaces, Love Potion is going to leverage our alternate identity as a public makerspace to offer perks like classes (see below), rental space (for meetings, events, or private parties), and membership to our shop! All mailable perks will also come with an Amphora sticker.

story:
This campaign has closed. Still want to donate? Visit our website: Full Circle.


ABOUT FULL CIRCLE

Full Circle is a Canadian non-profit Aboriginal Arts organization that creates opportunities for Aboriginal artists through our  annual Talking Stick Festival. The Talking Stick Festival produces a number of youth-oriented programs aimed at engaging, educating, entertaining, inspiring and connecting school-aged children with various disciplines of Indigenous arts.  


ABOUT YOUTH PROGRAMMING

Programs include Workshops in Schools Series that bring artists to classrooms, Field Trip Program which brings students to a sponsored show and a Visual Arts Competition which allows youth to express their creativity through design.


Each program is designed to:

  • Share and preserve the language, culture and art forms of Indigenous peoples

  • Encourage creativity and self esteem

  • Emphasize interaction, participation, and dialogue around Indigenous arts and culture

  • Offer first-hand experience in Indigenous arts

  • Enrich the school curriculum

  • Enhance Aboriginal children's sense of belonging in the community

  • Build a sense of pride about their culture and rich history


OUR GOAL

Through our Workshop in Schools program, we reach over 5,000 school-aged kids and over 30 schools within Metro Vancouver. We hope to increase these numbers to 10,000 + students in over 50 elementary and secondary schools so as to bring Aboriginal teaching and cultural experiences to schools in other communities outside of Metro Vancouver. We can do this by raising $20,000 in funds.


HOW YOUR DONATION HELPS

Through your support, we hope to offset some costs in producing our programs:

  • Program Coordinator’s Fees - who will coordinate logistics, book the schools and communicate with schools and artists

  • Artist Fees – these are fees we pay our artists for their time in teaching, preparing and performing at the schools

  • Transportation Costs – this covers the travel costs of our artists to get to the schools booked

  • Marketing and Promotion – these are costs in building signage, brochures, posters and other materials to promote the school event.

  • Materials – these are costs of additional materials that may be required for participating students.

 

REWARDS

When you donate, you will automatically be entered into a draw for several prizes:

  • A pair of tickets for the Vancouver Chamber Choir

  • A pair of tickets to a brand-new musical called Onegin

  • A Pair of tickets to The Royal Winnipeg Ballet's "Going Home Star"

  • One Night Stay at the Accent Inn

  • A Customized “Thank You Plaque” from Full Circle

  • Aboriginal Artwork

story:
A Poet Innocently Turned to Painting

I am a lifelong resident of Massachusetts. I have degrees from Franconia College and Lesley University.

Since high school, I have been writing creatively, largely poetry. I have published three books of poetry, as well as in magazines and on websites. When I returned to school to finish the degree begun long ago, I decided to use painting as my entry point for my study of creativity. I had no previous experience in art beyond doodling in notebooks. Technique developed as colour and brushstroke coalesced into image. It has been an adventure learning a new form of expression.

We are all artists when we are young. We sing, we paint, we dance, carelessly, and with joy. As I created these visual images, I let the child in me take over. My aim is that those who see my work will become similarly inspired. The world is too full of misery not to make the effort to bring energy and light and joy to the world.

This May will see the first public showing of my work. My campaign will fund the creation of prints of my paintings. The main use of funding will be to make scans of eight paintings then print a run of twenty copies of each. The rest of the funding would pay for shipping perks to contributors.

I checked local printers who do art quality scanning and printing. The company that won me let me speak directly with the person who would do the work. Scans cost $125 a-piece. That price includes proof copies to make sure the scan is as I want it). Printing is around $18 a print. Turnover is a matter of days.

For perks, I will hand write a thank you to everyone who contributes. I thank you right now for reading this far. Those who contribute $35 will also receive a drawing by my hand. Contributions of $75 will receive one of my prints. Contributions of $500 will receive all eight prints. Contributions of $1750 will receive all eight prints framed. All contributors will be publicly thanked on Facebook (unless you choose otherwise).

If I don’t reach my goal then I will use the funds to print what I can. If I exceed my goal, I will have the nature photographs that I have taken scanned and printed.

My History

As a poet, I understand the nether world of publishing. Over the years, I have bought books and gave donations to small presses as a way of support. Later I served as editor for Potes & Poets Press, a worthwhile but negatively remunerative venture. My wife and I ran the Press for five years. During that time, we published thirty books, despite extremely untimely payments from our distributor. Profits from each book went to publishing the next.

I envision no extra costs. The showing will last one month. Such prints that remain after the showing will be taken to gift shops and other likely markets in the area,

story:
I have liaised with a book publishing company who has been kind enough to provide advice and support on the steps I need to take and the funds required in order to put together a book detailing the culture of gaming tattoos.

I created the instagram page in March 2014, it was my ambiton to bring together a community of dedicated gamers and amazing artists by sharing work by people from all over the world.

I've been lucky enough to be featured in a few gaming magazines, and now I would love to move on the possibility of a book!

In addition, more than 50 artists and tattoo artists from all over the world including the UK, Australia and the US have donated perks such as prints, orginal art pieces and even tattoo time to make help make the book happen, so if you are passionate about the gaming and tattoo community, be sure to check the campaign out and even donate if you can, its a chance to get tattooed by loads of amazing artists and have a piece featured in a book at the same time!

I have projected the book's release to be late 2016, early 2017; dependent on how long it will take to raise the funds. So far through the efforts of so many artists, just under £3500 has been raised!

In terms of the book itself, It would be desirable to visit all of the artists personally to interview them for the book and learn more about the day to day life of an artist, which wil depend entirely on whether or not I can reach the funding target.               In regards to the actual publication of the book, a US based publishing company has provided me with an overview of potential costs.

As an example, a 256 page book, glossy art paper, hardcover would be approximately (could be slightly more/less):

1000 books = $16,000 including layout/design or $16.00 per book
2000 books = $20,000 including layout/design or $10.00 per book

The variables in this situation are actual page count of the book, size of the book (8.5x11, 10x13, 8x10)

For more artist info, check out the updates tab or head over to instagram and find videogametatts 

I would be honoured if you would make a contribution to this project,

Thanks again,

Regards, Alex

videogametatts

AS YOU ALL ARE AWARE THE PROJECT IS SET AS FLEXIBLE FUNDING, HOWEVER ALL PROCEEDS WILL STILL BE INVESTED INTO FUNDING THE BOOK AND EVERYONE WHO HAS CONTRIBUTED FOR PERKS WILL STILL RECEIVE WHAT THEY HAVE DONATED FOR =)

story:
My story

Book Synopsis

INKPULSE charts the course of Yeo Shih Yun’s art journey from 2000 until 2017—one that chronicles from her budding years when she first fell in love with Chinese ink, to diving headfirst into Abstract Expressionism, Rothko and the other “gods” that would serve to underpin Yeo Shih Yun’s creative oeuvre and penchant for unconventional experimentations, to her eventual founding of INSTINC and collaborations with many interesting fellow artists from all parts of the globe. 

With an ink-based, East-meets-West aesthetic—influenced by the tutelage of eminent painter Chua Ek Kay—this monograph is a highlight on Yeo Shih Yun's pulsating pursuit for new depths and new perspectives within the realm of Abstract Expressionism,  delving into her art making process which oftentimes is akin to a spontaneous search for the poetic sentiment and dramatic unknowns. Mixing means, mediums and collaborators are important features of her painting style and creative identity as seen in her body of works. 

This publication is presented as a progressive catalogue of Yeo Shih Yun's art works over the years, interspersed with accounts by the people she has met along the way—gallerists, curators, friends and fellow artists alike. It is only through reading their essays does the chaos emerge into order, with the randomness of collective memories offering new angles, multi-layered dimensions and deeper connecting vibrations to Shih Yun's art.

I wish to dedicate this monograph to my mum, who planted that tiny seed of art in me when I was young by bringing me to art lessons. 

 

The Beginning

As a child growing up, my mum encouraged me to do whatever interested me. By age 5, I already knew that art would be my favourite and deeply important part of my world. In spite of my deepest desires to be immersed in creating art very early on in my life, I did not get to embark on any formal art training until in my early twenties -  compelled by the practical concerns of life and for my mum's peace of mind, I had to complete my Business degree course from NUS before I could get myself enrolled in LASALLE College of the Arts to finally pursue my true passion. At that time my decision was frowned upon and appeared to puzzle many, but I knew without a doubt that art was absolutely to be the epicentre of my core and calling for life. I could not imagine anything else.


A pivotal moment during my time at LASALLE was the UOB painting competition where I came in the top 20 for highly-commended works. Subsequently my painting, which was titled Bamboo was put on display at the UOB Plaza. Little did I know then that my painting would catch the eye of an expat couple, and it was soon sold at $1,500, a whopping sum at that time for a struggling artist. That someone would connect with my painting enough to want to have wanted to own it really sent me over the moon! I could finally catch that glimpse of hope that I could have a real shot at making art my career and possibly having the means to fund my lifelong passion if I could give it my all. 


I knew my next step was to refine my skills at the San Francisco Art Institute. However, my mother who raised me on her own, was reluctant to let me go to the far away Western hemisphere. It was after relentless persuasion, and I was elated when she finally gave me the nod. That I could get to study fine arts in the USA full-time opened my mind by a quantum leap to a whole new level of art consciousness!


Eventually, I came back to Singapore in 2002 and started off with teaching art to children while doing freelance design work. The following year, I had my first group show at the MICA building curated by Marjorie Chu of Art Forum Gallery. I will always remember and be thankful for Marjorie's critique and pointers for me in those early days as a professional artist. I felt strongly about connecting fellow artists and bridging artistic collaborations, and so in 2004 I founded INSTINC and the rest is history.

 

Timeline of my art journey 

 

                      

 

Biography of Yeo Shih Yun

Born in Singapore 1976, Shih Yun is a full-time artist and Director of INSTINC, an independent artist-run space. She received her Bachelor of Business Administration(Marketing) from National University of Singapore, Diploma in Communications Design from Lasalle College of the Arts and Post- Baccalaureate (Painting) from San Francisco Art Institute in 2002.

Yeo Shih Yun is known to reinterpret the very act of ink painting with striking results. Her experimentations of fusing the traditional form with contemporary mediums like new media or performance art has garnered much acclaim, including a commission by the Singapore Art Museum, winning the Sovereign Asian Art Prize People's Choice Award in 2012 and being awarded a Certificate of Distinction and Highly Commended Entry at the UOB Painting of the Year Competition in 2007. Her painting at the Sovereign Asian Art Prize was auctioned by Christie’s Asia in 2012. Her recent exhibition was in NUS MUSEUM titled "Scholars and ink". 

www.shihyunyeo.com

 

My studio & art

 

 

Why do I want to make this monograph?

Digital files and stuff get lost all the time, and I have ever lost all my files previously when my hard disk crashed. Although we have digital clouds, ebooks and all, a physical book, just like a painting in some ways, is much more personal and ideal when it comes to documenting cherished memories and artworks. Even if all my hard disks are to crash and all my artworks are lost, this book would be a record of my artistic career from 2000 till 2017. 

I had released my first book documenting my artworks in 2006, which I self-designed to save costs. More than 10 years have passed since then, and I have come to an inflection point of my art journey to take stock and look back at a transformative chapter of my life as I reach for my next one. This time however, I feel that it is important to get the best in the field to do what they are best at, hence I am working with Kelley Cheng(The Press Room), who is also a good friend, to take on this task. 

As I am turning 41, toiling on this monograph is my way of celebrating for being steadfast in my love for painting, for having clinged on to my pursuit of the art-inspired life journey even through difficult times. I hope that this monograph will be a good one to share with others on my passion for painting, and to help with my further growth as a contemporary ink artist in Singapore and internationally. I will work with a distributor so that this monograph can be exposed to a greater audience. 

This monograph will feature key works of mine from the period of 2000 to 2017, including some of my works that have never been exhibited before. It is the first time such a comprehensive survey has been carried out!

This monograph will also be used:

  • As a reference book as I am invited by Singapore Teachers' Academy for the aRts (STAR) as a Artist Mentor to conduct a series of workshops over a week in NOV 2017 for a group of art teachers. 
  • As a resource for art/design students in Singapore who is keen to understand about Contemporary ink painting from a perspective of a local artist. (donating the monograph to various  schools with art/design/architecture  courses) 
  • As a great marketing tool to promote myself as a contemporaty artist. 

 

Book Specs

Size: 213mm x 270mm
Pages: 320 pages 
Offset printing 

 

                              

INKPULSE (some layout designs from this monograph) The cover design is still in progress, will update all of you once its completed! 

 

Contributors 

Mr. Koh Seow Chuan - Chairman of Singapore Visual Arts Cluster

Ms. Marjorie Chu - Gallerist of Art Forum Singapore
Mr. Ian Woo - Art Educator and artist
Mr. Boo Sze Yang - Artist 
Mr. Louis Ho - Curator of Singapore Art Museum 
Ms. Chang Yueh Siang - Curator of NUS Museum 
Ms. Iola Lenzi - Art writer and critic
Ms. Kay Liu-  Art writer and critic

 

My monograph will be conceptualized and art directed by: 

Ms. Kelley Cheng, who published the award-winning design magazine "iSh". In 2001, she was recruited by the Page One Group, where under her leadership hundreds of art, design, and architecture books were published worldwide. As an editor and creative director she has received many international awards, and currently runs her own publishing and consulting agency The Press Room.  She has worked with National Gallery, Singapore Art Museum and The Art Stage on many publications over the years. 

"A great pleasure for The Press Room to work on my old friend Shih Yun Yeo's book "INKPULSE", with beautiful works like that, it's hard to go wrong with the book! Look out for it soon!" Kelley Cheng 

 

Jing Wei (Photographer)

             

Jing Wei documenting Shih Yun's works over a period of one week in April 2016

 

 

                                                      

"Shih Yun is always full of energy. I admire her commitment to her creative profession. I published my monograph 2 years ago so I understand how tough it is financially. She is in it for the long haul and I hope you can support her in this campaign in whatever way you can." - Mr. Boo Sze Yang (Artist and co-founder of Artist Alliance, Singapore)

 

 

 

Where will your support go?

                             

      

* Funds exceeding the stated target will support PR of the monograph and costs of venue for book launch.

Designing the book, getting a photographer to document the works in my studio and the printing of the books all add up to quite a significant amount. Sadly, I did not get the Publishing Grant from the National Arts Council, Singapore. Therefore, this is the only platform I am using to raise funds. 

If I don't reach my goal, I will use whatever funds that I have raised here to cover: (according to priority) 

  1. Design
  2. Printing 
  3. Photography 

 

 

                    

 

 

 

Impact of  the monograph 

I hope to reach out to art lovers, writers, curators, critics, gallerists, collectors, teachers as well as students in general. I am planning on marketing my monograph on social media platforms such as Facebook. In doing so, I not only wish to reach out to individuals living in Singapore, but also to an international audience as well. To do this, I have plans to contact international art organisations and institutes in order to market my book to a larger cultural audience. I will also be working with a PR agency for marketing support.

Contributing to the image of Singapore's contemporary ink art culture in the international art scene is significantly important for me. The existing contemporary ink art circle in Asia consists mainly of artists from countries such as Hong Kong, China, and Taiwan, which gives me a strong motivation to help create a name for Singapore as one of the countries with contemporary ink art. With a stronger contemporary ink art culture in existence, we would be able to foster awareness and appreciation for the beauty of ink art not only in Asia, but all around the world. 

I believe that while press and publicity helps, the best promotion for books comes from word-of-mouth, from regular people telling other people they know about what they read... so please do spread the word!

I would also like to donate this book to libraries of art & design schools in Singapore: 

  • Lasalle College of the Arts
  • Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts (NAFA) 
  • National University of Singapore (NUS) 
  • Nanyang Technological University, School of Art, Design & Media (NTU, ADM) 
  • Singapore Polytechnic 
  • Ngee Ann Polytechnic
  • Temasek Polytechnic
  • Nanyang Polytechic
  • Republic Polytechnic
  • School of the Arts (SOTA) 
  • Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) 
  • Singapore Institute of Management (SIM University) / Singapore University of Social Sciences (SUSS) 

  • Singapore Institute of Technology

 

Risks and Challenges 

I am absolutely thrilled about the release of my monograph and I hope you are, too! As with any similar project, there are many risks and challenges associated with a project of this size. 

  • Going through 18 years of works and selecting only the best to be showcased in this monograph is really a headache! 
  • Asking writers/curators who have worked with me in the past to contribute essays in this monograph. The challenge is to make sure it fits the schedule of the writers/curators as everyone is very busy! 
  • Collaborating with Kelley on this monograph, as we need to make sure we understand each other well so as to produce a monograph that we are both proud of. 
  • Hiring the right photographer to shoot new images as needed at reasonable costs, reproducing the works in the monograph so that the colours are as close to the original as possible. This will mean press check and colours correction at the printer to make sure everything is accurate.
  • Compensating the wonderful individuals who have helped me for their time and expertise.
  • At the beginning, the number of pages I wanted was about 160 pages but after the designer laid out my woks and essays, the pages doubled! This meant the printing costs will almost double too and will increase the costs of this whole project. After discussing with Kelley, she advised me to keep to 320 pages as it is important to have a comprehensive overview of my art practice rather than to remove too many works and make the book thinner and cheaper.
  • Producing the monograph is a feat but marketing it is also tricky, I have hired an old friend Florence from Flame Communications to help me with the publicity and PR of this monograph and also the book launch event. 

 

Special Thanks to:

My mum for being the best mum in the world!

Sen and my son for their presence in my life.

All my contributors: Koh Seow Chuan, Marjorie Chu , Ian Woo , Boo Sze Yang , Louis Ho,  Chang Yueh Siang, Iola Lenzi  & Kay Liu for taking time to write in my monograph.

Ms Kelley Cheng and her team for their expertise and  patience in putting this monograph together. 

My photographer, Jing Wei, for his patience and his professionalism in helping me with the documentation of my works.

Maki Kinoshita for her beautiful music in this video (https://youtu.be/OBCD1SX3f5w)

Jennie Kwok for taking time off her very busy schedule to help edit the campaign script. 

Lu-Fang for her help in proof-reading the text in this campaign. 

My intern Leon for making all the awesome videos and graphics for this campaign. 

My ex-intern Pooja for making some of the cool info-graphics in this campaign.  

And you for taking time to visit this page!!

Last but not least, my Lord God for looking out for me and his kindness towards me.

 

 

Please do share this campaign with your friends, family, and like-minded acquaintances. Even the smallest of gestures can make a world of difference! Thank you so much!
story_txt:
My storyBook SynopsisINKPULSE charts the course of Yeo Shih Yun’s art journey from 2000 until 2017—one that chronicles from her budding years when she first fell in love with Chinese ink, to diving headfirst into Abstract Expressionism, Rothko and the other “gods” that would serve to underpin Yeo Shih Yun’s creative oeuvre and penchant for unconventional experimentations, to her eventual founding of INSTINC and collaborations with many interesting fellow artists from all parts of the globe. With an ink-based, East-meets-West aesthetic—influenced by the tutelage of eminent painter Chua Ek Kay—this monograph is a highlight on Yeo Shih Yun's pulsating pursuit for new depths and new perspectives within the realm of Abstract Expressionism,  delving into her art making process which oftentimes is akin to a spontaneous search for the poetic sentiment and dramatic unknowns. Mixing means, mediums and collaborators are important features of her painting style and creative identity as seen in her body of works. This publication is presented as a progressive catalogue of Yeo Shih Yun's art works over the years, interspersed with accounts by the people she has met along the way—gallerists, curators, friends and fellow artists alike. It is only through reading their essays does the chaos emerge into order, with the randomness of collective memories offering new angles, multi-layered dimensions and deeper connecting vibrations to Shih Yun's art.I wish to dedicate this monograph to my mum, who planted that tiny seed of art in me when I was young by bringing me to art lessons.  The BeginningAs a child growing up, my mum encouraged me to do whatever interested me. By age 5, I already knew that art would be my favourite and deeply important part of my world. In spite of my deepest desires to be immersed in creating art very early on in my life, I did not get to embark on any formal art training until in my early twenties -  compelled by the practical concerns of life and for my mum's peace of mind, I had to complete my Business degree course from NUS before I could get myself enrolled in LASALLE College of the Arts to finally pursue my true passion. At that time my decision was frowned upon and appeared to puzzle many, but I knew without a doubt that art was absolutely to be the epicentre of my core and calling for life. I could not imagine anything else.
A pivotal moment during my time at LASALLE was the UOB painting competition where I came in the top 20 for highly-commended works. Subsequently my painting, which was titled Bamboo was put on display at the UOB Plaza. Little did I know then that my painting would catch the eye of an expat couple, and it was soon sold at $1,500, a whopping sum at that time for a struggling artist. That someone would connect with my painting enough to want to have wanted to own it really sent me over the moon! I could finally catch that glimpse of hope that I could have a real shot at making art my career and possibly having the means to fund my lifelong passion if I could give it my all. 
I knew my next step was to refine my skills at the San Francisco Art Institute. However, my mother who raised me on her own, was reluctant to let me go to the far away Western hemisphere. It was after relentless persuasion, and I was elated when she finally gave me the nod. That I could get to study fine arts in the USA full-time opened my mind by a quantum leap to a whole new level of art consciousness!
Eventually, I came back to Singapore in 2002 and started off with teaching art to children while doing freelance design work. The following year, I had my first group show at the MICA building curated by Marjorie Chu of Art Forum Gallery. I will always remember and be thankful for Marjorie's critique and pointers for me in those early days as a professional artist. I felt strongly about connecting fellow artists and bridging artistic collaborations, and so in 2004 I founded INSTINC and the rest is history.
 
Timeline of my art journey 
 
                       
 
Biography of Yeo Shih Yun
Born in Singapore 1976, Shih Yun is a full-time artist and Director of INSTINC, an independent artist-run space. She received her Bachelor of Business Administration(Marketing) from National University of Singapore, Diploma in Communications Design from Lasalle College of the Arts and Post- Baccalaureate (Painting) from San Francisco Art Institute in 2002.
Yeo Shih Yun is known to reinterpret the very act of ink painting with striking results. Her experimentations of fusing the traditional form with contemporary mediums like new media or performance art has garnered much acclaim, including a commission by the Singapore Art Museum, winning the Sovereign Asian Art Prize People's Choice Award in 2012 and being awarded a Certificate of Distinction and Highly Commended Entry at the UOB Painting of the Year Competition in 2007. Her painting at the Sovereign Asian Art Prize was auctioned by Christie’s Asia in 2012. Her recent exhibition was in NUS MUSEUM titled "Scholars and ink". 
www.shihyunyeo.com

Why do I want to make this monograph?
Digital files and stuff get lost all the time, and I have ever lost all my files previously when my hard disk crashed. Although we have digital clouds, ebooks and all, a physical book, just like a painting in some ways, is much more personal and ideal when it comes to documenting cherished memories and artworks. Even if all my hard disks are to crash and all my artworks are lost, this book would be a record of my artistic career from 2000 till 2017. 
I had released my first book documenting my artworks in 2006, which I self-designed to save costs. As I am turning 41, toiling on this monograph is my way of celebrating for being steadfast in my love for painting, for having clinged on to my pursuit of the art-inspired life journey even through difficult times. I hope that this monograph will be a good one to share with others on my passion for painting, and to help with my further growth as a contemporary ink artist in Singapore and internationally. As a reference book as I am invited by Singapore Teachers' Academy for the aRts (STAR) as a Artist Mentor to conduct a series of workshops over a week in NOV 2017 for a group of art teachers. 

As a resource for art/design students in Singapore who is keen to understand about Contemporary ink painting from a perspective of a local artist. (donating the monograph to various  schools with art/design/architecture  courses) 
As a great marketing tool to promote myself as a contemporaty artist.

story:
Welcome to my "Wallmatter" Campaign.

My name is Jenny Davis. I am a visual artist who works from a studio I built from recycled materials, in the Yarra Valley,Victoria, Australia.


I have been a practicing artist for almost 25 years and work in many disciplines including : Painting, drawing, sculpture, photography, collage, installation, video, new media and virtual worlds.



My artwork has been exhibited in Australia, New York, Berlin, Spain, France, UK and the U.S.A. and is in numerous private and public collections in Australia, UK, Europe, Canada and the U.S.A. I have also, won various awards and overseas arts residencies.



Artist in residency, Barcelona Spain



Installation in recessed stone wall, Barcelona Spain



Meet the Tenant Project, Paris France


About the Project

My latest project, "Wallmatter" will be a solo installation of new work, at The Memo Gallery, Victoria Australia in July 2016. It will consist of large textual abstract paintings with three-dimensional objects using concrete, textile, rust and artist books. The work links to, the beauty of imperfections and decay, caused by, neglect, abandonment and the evidence of time.






Please see more about work on progress, my art and life.

Outlook8studio
Instagram
Facebook
Pinterest


What We Need & What You Get

Your support will help me cover, the costs, to frame my large paintings. If I don't reach my goal, I will use the funds, already contributed, to frame as many artworks, as I can afford. If I reach my goal and there are leftover funds, after framing costs, I will use this to buy an ergonomic chair with wheels and a foot stool. This will allow me to sit and move about the studio more comfortably when working.

Costs
Painting Size -  120cm x 100cm.

Floating Frame cost - $286.00AU each.

10 paintings - $2886.00AU

Large Bambach chair with back $999.00AU.

I have almost finished the paintings and I hope to frame them in simple a wooden, floating frame, that will cover the sides of the canvas, leaving a 3mm. gap between the frame and the canvas. This allows the artwork to float in its own space.

I have some awesome perks on offer for my supporters!

$20   Set of 5 Artist Postcards - 25 Available


$40      Original Collage 14x10cm - 16 Available


$60       Original Collage 19x14cm - 21 Available



$80       Original Abstract Painting - 6 Available



$130      Large Collage 76cmx50cm - 4 Available



$280     Overland Painting Series - 5 Available

$350     Giclée Art Print Framed -  1 Available



$600     5 Terrasporus Paintings - 1 lot Available



$1000   4 Beneath Metro Grid Paris Paintings - 1 lot Available



Please choose your rewards in the right hand colum near the top of this page!

 

 The Impact

This exhibition and your support will really help me expose, my new experimental artworks, to a local, regional and city audience.

By experimenting with new materials and methods, this exhibition has already, challenged and pushed me, out of my comfort zone of just painting and has allowed me, to express my ideas more thoroughly, in my arts practice.


I have used various methods for the mixed media sculpture pieces: eco, rust and Japanese Shibori dyeing and slow Boro stitching. To construct the pieces, I will stitch, tear, burn and manipulate the material, into sculptural objects.




I have a passion for surface quality, texture and space in my work. I work intuitively with paint and mixed media, to build up layers, into dense abstract paintings and forms. My abstract paintings are almost, finished.




They may have as many as, 5 to 50 layers. By taking away layers, stripping back identity, I want to get to the essence of something. This is much more interesting to me than, creating something recognizable.



Challenges

My main challenge for this project has been finding new ways of working on such a large body of work, after receiving injuries to my neck and spine in a car accident, years ago. As a result, as time has gone on, I have lymphedema (swelling) in both legs, which means I can only work in short bursts. Whereas, years ago I was able to paint 8-12 hours straight.

So far I have created, 8 large paintings and 10 small paintings. My proposal for the gallery space requires me to have 20 paintings altogether with several, mixed media sculptures, using concrete, rust and cloth. I am well on my way,

I am now experimenting with concrete, textiles and rust creating my 3d objects by adding texture and form, to cloth fragments and found objects.

I hope this exhibition will offer my audience a new way of seeing!

Thank you for your visit and taking the time to read about my project


Other Ways You Can Help

Please feel free to share this project to those who may be interested.

Enjoy your day!

$80       Original Abstract Painting - 6 Available
$130      Large Collage 76cmx50cm - 4 Available
$280     Overland Painting Series - 5 Available$350     Giclée Art Print Framed -  1 Available
$600     5 Terrasporus Paintings - 1 lot Available
$1000   4 Beneath Metro Grid Paris Paintings - 1 lot Available
Please choose your rewards in the right hand colum near the top of this page!   The Impact

This exhibition and your support will really help me expose, my new experimental artworks, to a local, regional and city audience. 
By experimenting with new materials and methods, this 
exhibition has already, challenged and pushed me, out of my comfort zone of
 just painting and has allowed me, to express my ideas more thoroughly, in my arts practice.


 I have used various methods for the mixed media sculpture pieces: eco, rust  and Japanese Shibori dyeing and slow Boro stitching. To construct the  pieces, I will stitch, tear, 
burn and manipulate the material, into  sculptural objects.


I have a passion for surface quality, texture and space in my work. I  
work intuitively with paint and mixed media, to build up layers, into  
dense abstract paintings and forms. My abstract paintings are almost, finished. 





They may have as many as, 5 to 50 layers. By taking away layers, 
stripping back identity, I want to get to the essence of something. This is much more 
interesting to me than, creating something recognizable.


Challenges


My main challenge for this project has been finding new ways of 
working 
on such a large body of work, after receiving injuries to my neck and 
spine in a car accident, years ago. As a result, as time has gone on,
 I have lymphedema (swelling) in both legs, which means I can only 
work in short bursts.  Whereas, years ago I was able to paint 8-12 hours
 straight.
So far I have created, 8 large 
paintings and 10 small paintings. My proposal for the gallery space requires me to have 20 paintings altogether with 
several, mixed media sculptures, using concrete, rust and cloth. I am well on my way,
I am now experimenting with concrete, textiles and rust creating my 3d objects by adding texture and form, to cloth fragments  and found 
objects.
I hope this exhibition will offer my audience a new way of seeing!

Thank you for your visit and taking the time to read about my project 
  Other Ways You Can Help
Please feel free to share this project to those who may be interested.
Enjoy your day!

story:
My Grandfather has been a Professional Artist his whole life working as head Artist at the Seattle Times for a while in the 70s but mostly on his own as a Commercial Artist as Larry Countryman Art & Signs in Snohomish Washington.

His work is and has been in many art galleries, trade shows and private collections. He also said he doesn’t want to be a Famous Artist because he would have to be dead for that. Well we are going to bring a bit of fame to him before he’s dead with this Indiegogo campaign.

This Coloring Book is not your run of the mill coloring book when we say Big we mean 11 x 17 and 12 x 18 inch depending on the art work but big enough that when you are done coloring it you will be able to have frame quality to hang on your wall not the refrigerator. That is why this coloring book will be on quality paper not the cheap stuff in the stores.

 

This Coloring book is 25 of Grandpa's best illustrations

It will be a soft cover that opens flat with detachable or loose pages so illustrations can be cleanly removed.

1 illustration per page to prevent issues with color bleed-through.

Printed on the highest quality drawing paper: acid-free, thick archival paper to prevent illustrations from yellowing.

Suitable for drawing with almost any coloring medium: pencil, crayon, gel pens, ink, marker, pastels and water color.

 For the JPEG People

7 illustrations will start to be emailed the first month after the Indiegogo in order of first perks. These illustrations unfortunately will come through as 8 by 11 for a home printer.

 

A few samples of the 25 Coloring Book illustrations:

With Color

Original Art work available

Trains, Airplanes, Cars & Trucks: do you have a special vehicle that you would like in a Countryman Original Art work & be in Grandpa’s BIG Coloring Book then this is the perk for you. $3,000 for Three art collectors and $5,000 for Two art collectors with a Bed & Breakfast meet the Artist 2 night stay for two.

Sample of his work

One of Grandpa's great signature styles is he actually puts people in and around the art, if you look close in the cloud next to the airplanes propeller is a famous aviator of back in the day.

Trains in Snohomish

Bird Lady in Pioneer Square

Old tractor on the farm

Yes the above art will be in the coloring book without the color.

 

What We Need

The goal for this project is to preserve the art work of Grandpa's 60 years.

The price of the perks reflex the cost of the project.

Starting with fees at 3% & 5% for Indiegogo and credit card and or (PayPal) going with 10%

Shipping 25% to 30%  depending on variables of where the art is being shipped and how many books being shipped.

Production of the coloring book 60% to 65% for sizing of the art work, digitizing and then printing.

 

Risks & Challenges

Countryman coloring book will be printed in the U.S.A. at Alexander Printing Company in Everett Washington "Continuous operation since 1886 Quality and on-time"

Grandpa has all the art work for the coloring book done but the custom one of a kind work he will do for the top tier group of wonderful Indiegogo customers after they decide what art they would like.

Our team will keep you up to date on the progress of the coloring book from print to ship dates.

You will notice that the photos in this Indiegogo are not from the best camera or best lighting that is to prevent copying of Grandpa's work on this page.

 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Thank you for your time reviewing this campaign please help me share Grandpa's work with social media. Please use the link to share with others.

    https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/grandpa-s-bi...
