story:
The Probability Probe is coming to Burningman to collect your messages and transmit them around the universe.  We have embedded systems connected to Blackrock Castle Observatory in Co. Cork Ireland. The structure (including antennas) now stands 32 feet tall.  The Probe is highly interactive and has several key technologies built into it. These include a highly-sophisticated lighting system and the ability to send targeted messages directly to a library of over 3,000 exoplanets around the universe. The initial vision for the structure came from a recurring dream that the lead artist has had since childhood. It is hoped that Participants who encounter the Probability Probe will not only ponder the possibilities of where the Probe has come from but also question where they themselves have come from and what are the different possibilities for their own lives.

What We Need & What You Get

The Probability Probe is an independently funded art and technology project.  The project has not received any grants. The cost to build, transport and run the probe on the playa is $47,500. So far, our team has contributed over 2,500 hours of work free of charge along with the first $20,000.  Now we are asking you to help fund the balance and share in our dream of having the Probability Probe on the playa at Burningman.            

In short, the money raised will enable the Probability Probe team to:

  1. Finish off the structure
  2. Ship two forty-foot containers to Reno
  3. Install a state of the art lighting and laser system
  4. Transport to the playa at Black Rock City

Our team is personally covering all its own expenses.  All the money raised will go toward the project.  If the full amount is not funded we will have to cut back on some aspects of the lighting and laser systems.  This project deserves to be shown on the Playa in its full glory and we hope you will contribute and become a part of the Probability Probes history. 

In return for helping us fund the remainder of the project, we offer you a chance to experience the Probability Probe at three stories high, it is one of the largest, most elaborate recycled steel sculptures to have even been constructed.  To make it a little more interesting and interactive our team have added the ability to send Burner Cosmic Messages i.e. targeted messages into outer space and what better place to do this than on the Playa at this year’s Burn.  For those of you who are unable to attend Burningman this year, we have designed and completed a web portal that can be accessed from anywhere in the world and will enable you to still experience the excitement of sending your message into space and having your voice heard throughout the universe. The message to space portal allows you to pick a date and time that is suitable for you and is suitable for all ages.        

 

Other Ways You Can Help

As well as contributing (if you can) please take the time to share this campaign with friends, family and on your social media networks. Like and share our Facebook, Instagram and Twitter accounts.

Who are we?

The Probability Alchemists are collective of artists, engineers, astronomers, scientists, technologists, and entrepreneurs. Our team has come together through a remarkable set of coincidences all centered around a man that burns in the desert. We are dreamers, explorers, time and inter-dimensional travelers. We share a common mission to engage citizens of Black Rock City by taking concepts and ideas from our reality and other planes of existence mixing them with playa magic to create compelling works of art.  

Main Structure Build Coordinator

Piyanuch Chanphet: Co-Founder of RoboSteel, Model, and Actress 

Lead Artist

Brendan RoboSteel who has over 14 years’ experience building large-scale sculptures from recycled steel. Brendan has completed commissions for many individuals and brands across the world and had been featured in Wired Magazine and Ripley's Believe it or Not.  

Lead Designer 

Wolf Reicherter: Named as one of the 25 iconic artists of our time. Illustrator - Concept / Character, Theme Park Ride Designer and world class Bodypainter

Cheif Technology Officer 

Alan Giltinan: MSc, Applied Physics & Instrumentation, Chief Technology Officer at Blackrock Castle Observatory.

Motion Graphics / Lighting Designer 

Daniel Staines:  Motion Graphics and Lighting designer. Programing & technical production for LEDs, stage lighting & projection mapping. Experience in live festivals and events. Member of the Slipdraft VJ Duo. BA Degree in Animation. 

Content Animator & Videographer 

Kevin Freeney: Motion graphic content designer and animator. Videographer & Film Editor.
Experience in live festivals and events. Member of CLU Audio Visual Duo.  BA Degree in Fine Art.

Mission Specialist and Ground Station Manager 

Claire McSweeney: Facilities Manager at Black Rock Castle Observatory, Co. Cork, Ireland

Message to Space Portal

The Probability Probe message to space portal provides users with the ability to directly target an exoplanet from a database of over 3,000 that have been discovered and have the conditions necessary to support life and send a personalized message directly to this planet. This web-based portal can be accessed from anywhere in the world including Black Rock City at Burningman.  In effect, we are linking Black Rock City with Black Rock Castle Observatory in Co. Cork Ireland in real time.

Simply scroll down to the Scheduler and pick a date and time which is good for you. Click on Confirm to add it to your schedule. You can also delete any previously reserved slots so you can free up space for others.

Once you have a slot reserved, a counter will show you how much time you have to wait for your experience.

To send a message to space, you must first pick a star.

Before you make your choice it’s a good idea to take a couple of factors into consideration including its distance from the Earth and its angle above the horizon.  First, consider its distance: a message becomes weaker the further it must travel. The closer the star is, the better the message has of arriving in one piece.

 

Second, consider its angle above the earth Our atmosphere has a big effect on how weak or how strong the signal will be.

If we send to a star close to our zenith (straight up), it passes through much less of the atmosphere than if we send our message to a star closer to the horizon.  The Stars altitude depends on the time of day and year.  Some stars can only be seen for a short space of time and others are only visible from the Southern Hemisphere.

Now it’s time to choose your target star.  Use what you have learned to pick the best target.

Once you have chosen your target star it’s time to think about what you will say in your message. Here are some previous famous messages that have been sent.

This message was sent in 2003 from the Evpatoria telescope in the Ukraine.

Like the Arecibo message, the message was based on symbols. It was designed to be strong for space communication. It contained similar information to the Arecibo message. However, it introduced new concepts such as

  • mathematics
  • chemical elements
  • units of measurement
  • the Earth
  • and cosmology

The last section asks whoever has got the message to respond with similar information.

The most recent message as actually computer programs.

Ok along with your personal message we will attach one of these previous famous messages to your interstellar communication. Please choose one.

Now it’s time to type your personal message, take your time and when you are ready to send hit send the message!

Congratulations you have now completed your mission to send a personalized message into space all you have to do now is wait for a response!

story:
Short Summary

Local  SD artist and MiscreAnt, Jake Holler, has dreamt of turning his old Dodge Ram Prospector into a Giant Anteater for sometime. Using  recycled materials (old shade structures, old aluminum paneling, etc etc) and the hep of MIscreAnt, Bat Country, and other SD artist friends, he's finally making this dream come true. 

But we're not quite there yet! The crew is working tirelessly around the clock to finish building the structure. The Giant Anteater will leave for Burning Man in one short week! 

Many of our friends have expressed interest in contributing to this project but just don't have the time or means to help us build. But there is still a way you can help!

What We Need & What You Get

We still need cash donations for build material, gas, and to cover any trips to the vet this beast might need. 

We appreciate any amount you can give to awesome big art, but if we can sweeten the deal for you:

  • $20 donation - "Anteaters are REAL" sticker 
  • $50 donation - "Anteaters are REAL" sticker + "My Other Car is a Giant Anteater" Bumper Sticker + 1 real, decent drink from the Bastards Bar at Burning Man or YOUtopia (All subsequent donation amounts will receive this package in addition)
  • $100 donation - Small Metal Anteater Sculpture + Sticker and drink package
  • $200 donation - Hand blown glass anteater pipe by Jake Holler + Sticker and drink package
  • $250 donation - We'll give take you on an ice run on the playa or a tour of YOUtopia! + Sticker and drink package
  • $500 donation - 3 ft Giant Anteater Metal Sculpture by Chas Clark + Limited Edition Cork BAnt Sticker + Sticker and drink package
  • $1000 donation - We'll bring the Giant Anteater Art Car to your event! + Sticker and drink package

The Impact

In this dreary world, the MiscreAnts are here to help you remember to be silly. Our goal is to never stop building and creating and to remind folks to laugh at themselves. This art car is just one incarnation of a million nonsense dreams we want to give to the world. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you still want to contribute, we need all hands on deck to finish skinning and lighting the structure. It's the last stretch! 

You can also help us by sharing this campaign with your art-loving friends!

story:
The Hand Washing Project

This socially engaged project is a combination of participatory art and paintings meant to break down barriers between individuals. By enlisting people to wash each others hands I'm trying to critique our contrived systems of injustice, prejudice, and notions of difference. The water, pigments, lye, and salts used in these hand-washing interactions are then used to create unique works of art. The paintings which result are formed through the evaporation of the water and what remains is the residue of salt crystals, oils, and pigments. These paintings become the shared marks of the participants, highlighting the individuals' dependence to the other and vice versa.  

As much as we need to accept difference it is more important to connect with others who are different from ourselves and find the humanity in one another. Our humanity is universal and I believe physical touch can teach us that. Scientific research shows that increased physical touch decreases violence and creates greater trust between individuals. Touch can release oxytocin, the "love hormone," and stimulates feelings of compassion and trust between individuals. The Washing Hands Project cleanses and unites people and does so in a tangible, physical, and intimate way.

In a Utopian world we would all get along, there would be no war, and there would be no injustice. Everyone would be taken care of and no one would go without. To strive for this Utopia we have to connect with people we normally would not connect with. This has to start by each of us realizing we are the same as our neighbors. We are more similar than different. We are all just people.  What I’m doing is using the power of touch to help people be more understanding of one another. 

In light of the last few months and all the division in our country I’ve been thinking a lot about what causes someone to be "different" from ourselves? How do we feel connected to others? Why is physical touch so important in relationships? The WHP is a socially engaged work exploring these questions. I believe in the axiom that we are connected to one another and that we are all equal. In this project I’m working with people of all colors, races, genders, sexualities,classes and ideologies and trying to bring people together who otherwise would not mix. I’ve already started working with a few people and you can check out one of the videos here

 

This video is of a woman, Andi who works with the homeless and a homeless man named Larry. Larry was touched by the power of the interaction he had with Andi and it revitalizes my belief in how important this project really is. The participants in these hand washing pieces represent the full spectrum of humanity. I’m facilitating these performances and then capturing the water used in the washed hands. During these hand washing interactions water is combined with pigments, lye, charcoal, and salts to create “paintings” which symbolize the “fingerprints” of the participants involved. These paintings live on as the mixture of two people who connected with one another. Some of these paintings will be sold (hopefully to you), others given to participants, and some to be exhibited along with videos of the various hand washing performances. Check out the gallery to see some examples of these paintings. I truly hope you will support this meaningful work.

 

Why should you contribute?

- Contributing helps broaden the audience of this meaningful work which means to bring people of all different races, religions, genders, ideologies, and economic backgrounds together. Your contributions will help with my material costs, some travel costs, compensation to others, and help me earn a living wage as an artist. 

- Contributing can also be an opportunity to purchase a unique work of art. These pieces are beautiful and over the last few months I have been developing and perfecting the technique to create these pieces.

- You could also support this project by purchasing The Washing Hands Experience and I will bring this project into your workplace, or with a group, or with another individual. I am offering supporters the chance to purchase their own hand washing experiences which will include the artwork created, a presentation on the power of touch, and a workshop. This project is meaningful to everyone who participates and I would love to share the experience personally with you. 

The Breakdown of Your Contribution

Your contribution helps:

-  Broaden the reach of this public art project.

-  Cover the cost of supplies, materials, and travel.

- Compensate time and labor invested into the project. 

 

Thanks! 

That's about it folks! Thank you for taking the time to  read through this, look at the videos, and check out some pictures. I really hope you will help support this project and please feel free to ask a question or leave feedback. 

 

More About Nick Rivers

Nick Rivers (1983) was born in Saint Paul, Minnesota. His work explores interdependency and social equality through sculpture, painting, and performance. Over the last 6 years he completed an A.A.S. in Manufacturing and Engineering, a B.L.A in Culture and Film Studies and recently his M.F.A. from Minneapolis College of Art and Design.

Most recently Rivers was selected as the 2017 Harpo Foundations Emerging Artist Residency Fellow at Santa Fe Art Institute. His public art projects such as Five Day Fast: My Theses on Art, or Something To Hold Onto Until the Wind Carries Us Away, have gained the public’s attention. He has exhibited his work regionally, nationally, received awards for his efforts, been written about by artists and curators, and given numerous artist talks. He maintains an active studio and research practice and continues to stay involved with the contemporary and academic art world. Rivers resides on the Mississippi River in Minneapolis, Minnesota with his wife Brooke and their six month old daughter, Josephine.

Education

2016 M.F.A. in Visual Studies, Minneapolis College of Art and Design, Minneapolis, MN.
2013 B.L.A. in Culture, Film, and Art, Metropolitan State University, Saint Paul, MN.
2009 A.A.S. in Manufacturing and Engineering Technology Sciences, Hennepin Technical College,
story_txt:
The Hand Washing Project
This socially engaged project is a combination of participatory art and paintings meant to break down barriers between individuals. By enlisting people to wash each others hands I'm trying to critique our contrived systems of injustice, prejudice, and notions of difference. The water, pigments, lye, and salts used in these hand-washing interactions are then used to create unique works of art. The paintings which result are formed through the evaporation of the water and what remains is the residue of salt crystals, oils, and pigments. These paintings become the shared marks of the participants, highlighting the individuals' dependence to the other and vice versa.  

As much as we need to accept difference it is more important to connect with others who are different from ourselves and find the humanity in one another. Our humanity is universal and I believe physical touch can teach us that. Scientific research shows that increased physical touch decreases violence and creates greater trust between individuals. Touch can release oxytocin, the "love hormone," and stimulates feelings of compassion and trust between individuals. The Washing Hands Project cleanses and unites people and does so in a tangible, physical, and intimate way.
In a Utopian world we would all get along, there would be no war, and there would be no injustice. Everyone would be taken care of and no one would go without. To strive for this Utopia we have to connect with people we normally would not connect with. This has to start by each of us realizing we are the same as our neighbors. We are more similar than different. We are all just people.  What I’m doing is using the power of touch to help people be more understanding of one another. 
In light of the last few months and all the division in our country I’ve been thinking a lot about what causes someone to be "different" from ourselves? How do we feel connected to others? Why is physical touch so important in relationships? The WHP is a socially engaged work exploring these questions. I believe in the axiom that we are connected to one another and that we are all equal. In this project I’m working with people of all colors, races, genders, sexualities,classes and ideologies and trying to bring people together who otherwise would not mix. I’ve already started working with a few people and you can check out one of the videos here

 
This video is of a woman, Andi who works with the homeless and a homeless man named Larry. Larry was touched by the power of the interaction he had with Andi and it revitalizes my belief in how important this project really is. The participants in these hand washing pieces represent the full spectrum of humanity. I’m facilitating these performances and then capturing the water used in the washed hands. During these hand washing interactions water is combined with pigments, lye, charcoal, and salts to create “paintings” which symbolize the “fingerprints” of the participants involved. These paintings live on as the mixture of two people who connected with one another. Some of these paintings will be sold (hopefully to you), others given to participants, and some to be exhibited along with videos of the various hand washing performances. Check out the gallery to see some examples of these paintings. I truly hope you will support this meaningful work.

 
Why should you contribute?
- Contributing helps broaden the audience of this meaningful work which means to bring people of all different races, religions, genders, ideologies, and economic backgrounds together. Your contributions will help with my material costs, some travel costs, compensation to others, and help me earn a living wage as an artist. 
- Contributing can also be an opportunity to purchase a unique work of art. These pieces are beautiful and over the last few months I have been developing and perfecting the technique to create these pieces.
- You could also support this project by purchasing The Washing Hands Experience and I will bring this project into your workplace, or with a group, or with another individual. I am offering supporters the chance to purchase their own hand washing experiences which will include the artwork created, a presentation on the power of touch, and a workshop. This project is meaningful to everyone who participates and I would love to share the experience personally with you. 

The Breakdown of Your Contribution
Your contribution helps:
-  Broaden the reach of this public art project.
-  Cover the cost of supplies, materials, and travel.
- Compensate time and labor invested into the project. 
 
Thanks! 
That's about it folks! Thank you for taking the time to  read through this, look at the videos, and check out some pictures. I really hope you will help support this project and please feel free to ask a question or leave feedback.

Over the last 6 years he completed an A.A.S. in Manufacturing and Engineering, a B.L.A in Culture and Film Studies and recently his M.F.A. from Minneapolis College of Art and Design.Most recently Rivers was selected as the 2017 Harpo Foundations Emerging Artist Residency Fellow at Santa Fe Art Institute. His public art projects such as Five Day Fast: My Theses on Art, or Something To Hold Onto Until the Wind Carries Us Away, have gained the public’s attention. He has exhibited his work regionally, nationally, received awards for his efforts, been written about by artists and curators, and given numerous artist talks. He maintains an active studio and research practice and continues to stay involved with the contemporary and academic art world. Rivers resides on the Mississippi River in Minneapolis, Minnesota with his wife Brooke and their six month old daughter, Josephine.Education2016 M.F.A. in Visual Studies, Minneapolis College of Art and Design, Minneapolis, MN.2013 B.L.A. in Culture, Film, and Art, Metropolitan State University, Saint Paul, MN.2009 A.A.S. in Manufacturing and Engineering Technology Sciences, Hennepin Technical College,

story:
Pitch

This campaign is to support Lacuna Gallery, a new contemporary art space in South Minneapolis.  Lacuna is a space dedicated to invigorating the Minneapolis art scene through the support and representation of visual artists early in their careers, especially those with a focus on ceramic sculpture and installation art.  We aim to connect visual artists to the resources they need to move through the early stages of their careers by providing space, resources, and a platform to do so.

Who We Are

Lacuna Gallery is the venture of Brittany Trushin and Erin Paradis, professional ceramic artists living and working in Minneapolis, Minnesota.  Collectively we have over 20 years of involvement and a wide range of experience in the art world.  We each bring something unique to this venture, giving us a diverse set of views to apply to the programing and operations of Lacuna.  With our combined experience and your continued support, Lacuna Gallery can not only be a successful venture for us, it can become an important art space for you to get to know and love.  

What it Will Be

Lacuna Gallery will become a unique art space that challenges what is currently available in the gallery scene in Minneapolis. Lacuna Gallery will support the practices of installation, sculptural ceramics, abstraction and other conceptual artistic media which we believe are currently underrepresented in Minneapolis.

Over the last several years, we have encountered many artists that are dedicated to their practice but need a flexible, professional space to install and exhibit the work they are making in their studios. As working artists ourselves, we understand the enormous impact that having a space to execute ambitious projects can have on the creative growth of an artist and the outcomes of their work.

We aim to give working artists professional support by providing studio space, project space and exhibition space.  Each of these spaces will be used to foster an ongoing dialogue between the artists practicing in the space, exhibiting artists, community supporters, collectors, ourselves and the general public.  Artists will have opportunities to share the work with the community, make professional connections and participate in a sales outlet.  In addition to hosting regular shows  in the exhibition space, Lacuna Gallery will organize other supporting events throughout the year to help build stronger connections between art and community, including but not limited to studio dinners, artists markets and public discussions.

The Space

We have secured a beautiful, 2000 sq. foot space located in South Minneapolis at the intersection of Chicago Avenue and 38th street, at the cross section of four main South Minneapolis neighborhoods. Tucked in the neighborhood with us is the Chicago Avenue Fire Arts Center, 3rd Place Gallery, Covet Consign, Frank Modern, Blackeye Coffee and City Food Studio to name a few.

Upstairs, the shotgun space with original wood floors is naturally lit by a large storefront and transom windows. It will house a 700 sq ft exhibition space and a 250 sq. foot 'Project Space'. Lacuna is thrilled to host the ‘Project Space’ which will be a resource available to Lacuna studio artists as well as community artists for brief periods of time. This versatile mini-gallery will allow artists to install and professionally document their work, as well as provide an opportunity to gain conceptual growth through conversation and contemplation about works that are in-process.  

In addition to exhibition and project space, in the white-washed, well lit basement are four semi-private studio spaces available for rent to professional working artists including space for electric kilns, shared workspace and storage.

The Impact

As you can see, Lacuna Gallery has big plans. Your contributions will enable us to make Lacuna Gallery’s first year a success. As owners, Brittany and Erin both have capital contributions in place for some startup and first year operations costs, but we are looking to raise an additional $15,000 to help us with rent for one year, programing costs and renovations. Even though the building we are activating is in great shape, the space needs electrical for kilns, track lighting, materials for installation and deinstallation of artwork, construction of a floating wall for the project space and renovation to the basement space to make it a safe, functional workspace for artists to use.  

We hope you see our passion and commitment to making Lacuna become a reality.  Your contribution will allow us to focus on Lacuna Gallery programming, management and relationships during the first year so we can build a strong community space you can enjoy for years to come.

Perks

To show our enormous appreciation for your contribution to this campaign, we have put together a great line up of perks that include handmade ceramic objects by yours truly, Lacuna Gallery swag, and curated gallery experiences for you to share and enjoy.  Please don't hesitate to contact us via email at hello@lacunagallery.com if you have any questions about making a contributions or getting a perk!

 

Risks

We realize that this is a big venture and there are many risks associated with starting an art gallery from scratch. The first year is going to be a bit of a learning curve with us stepping out of our roles as professional artists and into the roles of business owners, curators, managers, art dealers, landlords and accountants. Yet, we’ve prepared for these roles and have a business plan that includes three years of operations and a diversified business model with costs being covered by varied income sources throughout the year. This allows us to focus on supporting and exhibiting truly exciting artwork, not just art that sells. We are aware of our challenges and we know Lacuna Gallery is worth the incredible reward of establishing and running this unique art space in South Minneapolis!  

Thanks!

Lacuna Gallery has been all talk and planning for nearly three years! We are extremely energized and excited about this venture but now is the time to get it off the ground!  With your help, Lacuna’s creative space will bring more attention to underrepresented artists from around the country and become a unique staple in the Minneapolis gallery scene.  If you aren't able to donate at this time, you can help us out by sharing this campaign with your friends and family via email and social media. This endeavor would not be possible without you and we are so grateful to you for any help you can give!    

More

Stay up to date with us by following this campaign:

Indiegogo

Facebook (@lacunagallerympls)

Instagram (@lacunagallery).

Want to get in touch with us right now? Email hello@lacunagallery.com.

Want to keep in touch with us in the future? Sign up for our mailing list here.

story:
As See What Sticks enters its second year, we would love your support to keep renting our theaters at the Complex Hollywood, pay for extra features like microphones, music stands, projectors and more, and to keep our workshops free to the public!

We are trying to raise $1000! This campaign will help fund the future of See What Sticks.

Thank you!

This campaign will help fund the future of See What Sticks.Thank you!

story:
Summary

Black communities have been among the hardest hit by austerity and the arts are consistently undermined by cuts. We want to run an exhibition in January 2016 supporting artists of African heritage, bringing them together and celebrating their work.


About us

Theoo is a growing Community Interest Company based in the UK. Involvement in grassroots art projects like ours is proved to boost self confidence and community cohesion. We galvanise the skills and potential of upcoming and established artists alike to make change happen in the community. 

Our current project is the African Collective Placement. The theme is The Sub-Saharan Main Course (SSMC). In this project, art from artists from Black and African heritage is exhibited in various social spaces and public areas to invite much needed conversation on Sub-Saharan Africa. An exhibition will follow directly on from this, bringing the art together in one place as a celebration of the talent that lies in the under-represented parts of our society. We also actively encourage female artists to participate.

We had already had interest from emerging and established artists from around the UK, the US and Nigeria all eager to see Black African artists flourish! 

To make this happen successfully, we have a target of £1500 and a belief in our exceptional artists.


The funding targets

Advertising- to reach out to under-represented artists who need exposure via various media and to attract endorsements from known artists and organisations to help the project grow.
Securing a venue- one that is accessible to non-traditional audiences but also reflects the high quality and innovative work our artists produce.
Transport- We want to subsidise the cost to the artists of transporting their work from their many locations, so that financial difficulty is not a barrier to participation.
Catering- the exhibition will be non-conventional and approachable for people who don't traditionally visit events of this sort. To do this, we want the exhibition to be seen as a social event where individuals of all backgrounds can comfortably learn, discuss and share ideas.
Merchandising We want to transfer our current merchandising production arrangements to a Nigerian company thus supporting these indigenous entrepreneurs. We need a deposit to secure this sustainably.

The Impact

Your donation can help our artists rise. The bigger and more successful this exhibition is, the more exposure and inarguable recognition our artists will receive. They will be exhibited with known artists and have the opportunity to network and build their own profiles with support from us and the wider artistic community. In turn, their respective communities will benefit and see investment in these talents to be worthwhile. 

In the long term, we will be able to show budding artists there is a wealth of support available to get behind them and see to it to they are represented in what can be an otherwise daunting circle. 


Future implications

This project will generate future funding for future projects through 

- ticket and merchandise sales

- sponsorship gained from attendees to the exhibition

- auction of artwork after the exhibition (majority proceeds for artists directly)

Donors are offered exhibition tickets and the chance to meet our artists personally.


Other Ways You Can Support this:

We always appreciate support online so why not

- follow us on twitter: search @Theoo_pcurator

- like and share our page on Facebook: search Theoo CIC

- purchase our original clothing at http://theoo.spreadshirt.co.uk

- share our promo presentation: https://youtu.be/fXieAe1670k

For any further information, check our our website www.theoo.org.uk.

story:
The fundraised money will be used to produce the play but the profits will go solely to a non-profit company to help immigrants.


We tried my play a couple days ago at an amazing black box theatre named The Manhattan Repertory Theatre in New York city, I'm taking a big risk since it is my first work and my writing and storyline is not "specific" what you normally see out there, about two immigrants that find themselves in two different dreams which are created by the writer who is also one of the characters. I'm mixing realism and absurdism into a poetic language.  

Why it is important...
as a south american performer living in NYC I know how hard it is to make it happen here, and I'm trying to create a space, a company, where we can work freely and disciplined, I'm trying to create something detailed that also explains our position, our people, immigration and my thoughts on it. Its a Scream from my people's voice.

I NEED...
We are raising money to make it happen on a contemporary space. The idea is to create an experimental immersion process for the audience to come join the puzzle of this character's life, the money will be used for renting a space, paying the actors and creating publicity. 

Rosa's Monologue:

Rosa (Exploding): Armando, for god’s sake! I don’t love you. You are... you’re just a simple bricklayer; you are no one, nothing. (Bitter) Yes, I’m a whore but at least I’m something; A grown up woman, and you want me to tell you why I’m here? After all these years maybe now is the right time so you can just walk down the hallway and never come back, I’m tired of your stories, I’m tired of your analysis; I’m tired of your romanticized ways. (Visceral) Life is cruel, damned, life is sex and shit and food and sex and blood and curses and feelings. Life is... life is a night at home with the family watching abuelo dance tango with my aunts while they sing and talk about better times. Life is... life will never be here. This country has no space for me and yet I insist on being here. (Pause) I have a mother that needs me. (Pause) (Starting to cry, trying hard not to look weak) she’s dying Armando, lung cancer... the only thing I can do to pay her treatment lies between my legs. My body for hers. My soul for hers. Do you still think I’m going to marry a shitty gringo? I hate them all.  The way they smell and their fake smiles, their greed, the little grace they have to dance and don’t even make me talk about sex, they are not even worth a blowjob. You are not different Manny. I don’t belong in this city. (She goes for a drink) I can’t lie. I can’t behave according to the code and I’m declared a brute for that. Well, you found it, an animal, a boor. My soul stinks and my pussy hurts and bleeds and I don’t have to discuss this with you. Leave now. 


Armando's Monologue:

Armando: Sometimes I think everything came from an unexpected collision, a thing that made everything a singularity, a coincidence, a divine punishment for all the evil we haven’t committed yet, like when my mother said she didn’t deserve the misery life gave her Miss. (Pause)

When I think about my family the only thing I see is birds, isn’t that weird? I see birds trying to fly, birds trapped in cages made of hand-crafted, delicate iron. 

We humans are very peculiar beings; we dedicate our lives to knowledge, to a quest for some logical explanation. (Pause) What if we discover that living is just another stage (Pause) We would probably destroy ourselves. (Pause) We’d be nothing more than animals. (Pause) But wouldn’t that be good? What I’m trying to say is, humans everywhere are trying to survive; can you “try” to survive? You survive or you don’t, where’s the midpoint? And wouldn’t it be easier to survive if we started to recognize that we are all equal and equal to nature? Time could be so much less severe. (Raising in passion) People would stop wasting 

their time searching for ideals, they’d live, they wouldn’t worry, they’d laugh and cry and believe. No more White or black or Latino or European, we’d become a specie, the same as rats or lions. (Pause) (Discovering something) Surely we’d be less efficient. Humans are nothing; our weapons are something, our buildings are... our creations are... but us? We don’t even survive a cold. We’re vulnerable. No animal in the world fears us, they fear our creations. We are insufficient; we need to shield ourselves with clothes and weapons to survive. Am I talking nonsense Miss? (Bitter and Torn) It’s just... What is the United States? A country? What’s a country? A group of people? We all are people... What is the United States then? A selected group of people? Perhaps there are selected groups of Lions... grouping is a need I guess. (Pause) That girl... she radiated the purity, the nobility of a wild free animal. I... I couldn’t save her Miss... not she, not you. I can’t save you…(Pause) 

(Grabbing courage) I’m starting to feel alive today. I’m starting to recognize this house, the dust around it, the street that brings me here, and you. It feels just like being blind for years before an unexpected door opens and lights the room and unfolds my eyes. That girl was an angel and you are my salvation. (Pause) Miss, give me a reason, a motive to stop loving you. It feels like I’m living tomorrow already and tomorrow I’ll forget but today my heart is beating stronger. Today I’m not Armando or White or Colombian or incompetent or salaried. I’m... 


Second act Scene:

Manny: thank you.

Cristina: Alright, enjoy the bench. I’m going that way. 

Pause.

He looks at her.

Cristina: Thank you. Oh. look. it stop snowing.

Manny: Have a good day miss.

Cristina: Hope to see you around someday.

Manny: Same.

Cristina looks at him, smiles, leaves humming the tango.

Manny sighs, he is focused on writing. 

A little girl enters and looks at him. Manny doesn’t see it, he is writing.

Little girl: Mister.

Manny looks up. He is trembling, he starts to cry.

Manny: You.

Little Girl: She wants you to know she remembers you. 

Manny: This…

Little Girl: Mister. She remembers you, don’t cry please. She says she is better now and you don’t have to worry anymore mister. She also says she loves the way you write and she forgives you for everything. Mister, she says you have to work for what you believe is right and you also have to stand tall. Mister, she says she is sorry she never learned English and you were disappointed of her. She also says she did the best she could until her last day. Mister, one last thing, she says she forgives you for calling the cops, she says she forgives you for leaving her behind and never, ever, ever call her or visit her. Mister. She says she has always love you.

Manny: I know what this is.

Little Girl: Bye mister.

The little girl leaves.

Manny: My mother sold herself to give me a better life,  she was a prostitute, an immigrant prostitute,  she had lung cancer from smoking and she worked every fucked up day of her life for me. I know what this is. I’m a fucked up bastard. I never value her words, or her smile, or her sorrow. I didn’t… I DIDN’T WANT TO REMEMBER. I’m lost in this city, lost, with her, with her memory.  I didn’t want to accept it. I left her dying. I’m a selfish bastard. selfish. bastard. I want to stop writing DO YOU HEAR ME GOD? I don’t want to remember. I don’t want to see it. They came through the door, they, she, deported. I stood. I wanted to. Be. A. Playwright. Change. The. World. After. Nine. Eleventh. I. Didn’t. Want. To. Remember.  I miss her. Mommy, I miss you. I’m your little baby boy, where are you? Mama. I’m lost, lost in this shitty city in this shitty country. I’m lost in New york. I dont want to write anymore.

He screams. 

Manny:  I don’t want to write anymore. I don’t… want… to… write… any… more.

He pukes.
story_txt:
The fundraised money will be used to produce the play but the profits will go solely to a non-profit company to help immigrants.We tried my play a couple days ago at an amazing black box theatre named The Manhattan Repertory Theatre in New York city, I'm taking a big risk since it is my first work and my writing and storyline is not "specific" what you normally see out there, about two immigrants that find themselves in two different dreams which are created by the writer who is also one of the characters. I'm mixing realism and absurdism into a poetic language.  Why it is important...as a south american performer living in NYC I know how hard it is to make it happen here, and I'm trying to create a space, a company, where we can work freely and disciplined, I'm trying to create something detailed that also explains our position, our people, immigration and my thoughts on it. Its a Scream from my people's voice.
I NEED...
We are raising money to make it happen on a contemporary space. The idea is to create an experimental immersion process for the audience to come join the puzzle of this character's life, the money will be used for renting a space, paying the actors and creating publicity. Rosa's Monologue:

Rosa (Exploding): Armando, for god’s sake! I don’t love you. You are... you’re just a simple bricklayer; you are no one, nothing. (Bitter) Yes, I’m a whore but at least I’m something; A grown up woman, and you want me to tell you why I’m here? After all these years maybe now is the right time so you can just walk down the hallway and never come back, I’m tired of your stories, I’m tired of your analysis; I’m tired of your romanticized ways. (Visceral) Life is cruel, damned, life is sex and shit and food and sex and blood and curses and feelings. Life is... life is a night at home with the family watching abuelo dance tango with my aunts while they sing and talk about better times. Life is... life will never be here. This country has no space for me and yet I insist on being here. (Pause) I have a mother that needs me. (Pause) (Starting to cry, trying hard not to look weak) she’s dying Armando, lung cancer... the only thing I can do to pay her treatment lies between my legs. My body for hers. My soul for hers. Do you still think I’m going to marry a shitty gringo? I hate them all.  The way they smell and their fake smiles, their greed, the little grace they have to dance and don’t even make me talk about sex, they are not even worth a blowjob. You are not different Manny. I don’t belong in this city. (She goes for a drink) I can’t lie. I can’t behave according to the code and I’m declared a brute for that. Well, you found it, an animal, a boor. My soul stinks and my pussy hurts and bleeds and I don’t have to discuss this with you. Leave now. 


Armando's Monologue:
Armando: Sometimes I think everything came from an unexpected collision, a thing that made everything a singularity, a coincidence, a divine punishment for all the evil we haven’t committed yet, like when my mother said she didn’t deserve the misery life gave her Miss. (Pause)
When I think about my family the only thing I see is birds, isn’t that weird? I see birds trying to fly, birds trapped in cages made of hand-crafted, delicate iron. 


We humans are very peculiar beings; we dedicate our lives to knowledge, to a quest for some logical explanation. (Pause) What if we discover that living is just another stage (Pause) We would probably destroy ourselves. (Pause) We’d be nothing more than animals. (Pause) But wouldn’t that be good? What I’m trying to say is, humans everywhere are trying to survive; can you “try” to survive? You survive or you don’t, where’s the midpoint? And wouldn’t it be easier to survive if we started to recognize that we are all equal and equal to nature? Time could be so much less severe. (Raising in passion) People would stop wasting 
their time searching for ideals, they’d live, they wouldn’t worry, they’d laugh and cry and believe. No more White or black or Latino or European, we’d become a specie, the same as rats or lions. (Pause) (Discovering something) Surely we’d be less efficient. Humans are nothing; our weapons are something, our buildings are... our creations are... but us? We don’t even survive a cold. We’re vulnerable. No animal in the world fears us, they fear our creations. We are insufficient; we need to shield ourselves with clothes and weapons to survive. Am I talking nonsense Miss? (Bitter and Torn) It’s just... What is the United States? A country? What’s a country? A group of people? We all are people... What is the United States then? A selected group of people? Perhaps there are selected groups of Lions... grouping is a need I guess. (Pause) That girl... she radiated the purity, the nobility of a wild free animal. I... I couldn’t save her Miss... not she, not you. I can’t save you…(Pause) 
(Grabbing courage) I’m starting to feel alive today. I’m starting to recognize this house, the dust around it, the street that brings me here, and you. It feels just like being blind for years before an unexpected door opens and lights the room and unfolds my eyes. That girl was an angel and you are my salvation. (Pause) Miss, give me a reason, a motive to stop loving you. It feels like I’m living tomorrow already and tomorrow I’ll forget but today my heart is beating stronger. Today I’m not Armando or White or Colombian or incompetent or salaried. I’m... 

Second act Scene:
Manny: thank you.


Cristina: Alright, enjoy the bench. I’m going that way. 


Pause.


He looks at her.


Cristina: Thank you. Oh. look. it stop snowing.


Manny: Have a good day miss.


Cristina: Hope to see you around someday.


Manny: Same.


Cristina looks at him, smiles, leaves humming the tango.


Manny sighs, he is focused on writing. 


A little girl enters and looks at him. Manny doesn’t see it, he is writing.


Little girl: Mister.


Manny looks up. He is trembling, he starts to cry.


Manny: You.


Little Girl: She wants you to know she remembers you. 


Manny: This…


Little Girl: Mister. She remembers you, don’t cry please. She says she is better now and you don’t have to worry anymore mister. She also says she loves the way you write and she forgives you for everything. Mister, she says you have to work for what you believe is right and you also have to stand tall. Mister, she says she is sorry she never learned English and you were disappointed of her. She also says she did the best she could until her last day. Mister, one last thing, she says she forgives you for calling the cops, she says she forgives you for leaving her behind and never, ever, ever call her or visit her. Mister. She says she has always love you.


Manny: I know what this is.


Little Girl: Bye mister.


The little girl leaves.












Manny: My mother sold herself to give me a better life,  she was a prostitute, an immigrant prostitute,  she had lung cancer from smoking and she worked every fucked up day of her life for me. I know what this is. I’m a fucked up bastard. I never value her words, or her smile, or her sorrow. I didn’t… I DIDN’T WANT TO REMEMBER. I’m lost in this city, lost, with her, with her memory.  I didn’t want to accept it. I left her dying. I’m a selfish bastard. selfish. bastard. I want to stop writing DO YOU HEAR ME GOD? I don’t want to remember. I don’t want to see it. They came through the door, they, she, deported. I stood. I wanted to. Be. A. Playwright. Change. The. World. After. Nine. Eleventh. I. Didn’t. Want. To. Remember.  I miss her. Mommy, I miss you. I’m your little baby boy, where are you? Mama. I’m lost, lost in this shitty city in this shitty country. I’m lost in New york. I dont want to write anymore.


He screams. 


Manny:  I don’t want to write anymore. I don’t… want… to… write… any… more.


He pukes.

story:
“DIARY OF AN INFATUATION JUNKIE” IS A MULTI-MEDIA ART INSTALLATION
                                        INSPIRED BY A LIFE LONG PURSUIT OF:

                                        

                              PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT    &     A PASSIONATE LIFE


My IndieGOGO Campaign is to fund a 10’ x 42' x 8' art installation I'm creating at my studio in New York for the Venice Biennale. It will be on view at the Swatch Pavilion in Arsenale Nord, Venice, from September 10th through October 21st.

Swatch is the main partner of The Venice Biennale 2015, the world’s most prestigious exhibition of contemporary art Swatch Website. The 56th edition opened May 9, 2015 under the title “All the World’s Futures" curated by Okwui Enwezor and runs through November 22, 2015. Biennale Website

I’ve launched a 35 day IndieGOGO campaign, ending this coming July 27th to raise the funds to pay for shipping, transportation and supplies. Please get involved and participate in making this massive visual extravaganza about love in the fast lane become a reality! Your financial help, whatever you can contribute is essential for this project to materialize. The installation must be delivered in parts from Manhattan and installed in Venice, which is quite costly.

My installation is actually a SECRET….Swatch wants my images under lock + key until the unveiling to the media on September 10th so I am sworn to secrecy. What I CAN tell you, is that it’s going to be a multi-media installation entitled “Diary of an Infatuation Junkie” and will tell a visual story of love and passion at the turn of the 21st Century. My past work is on view at www.jennykrasner.com


                                           ________________________________


Diary of an Infatuation Junkie will be a wall relief/installation that will be printed on archival photographic paper. The white is the wall, and my images will be separately printed and then cut out to be attached to the wall. Areas will be painted directly on the wall and actual created objects nailed into the wall as well as free standing in the immediate front space you see in this diagram.
 


                                              ________________________________

The installation, though thematically not new in respect to the concept of photocollage, is technically and culturally innovative as digital collage has only recently been widely accepted as a viably commercial art form by art dealers, an investment opportunity by collectors, and respected by the public through exposure in museums and galleries.

This new artwork is directly inspired by a life-long fascination with graffiti and street art; I will essentially be creating my own urban wall. Using images appropriated from mass culture in tandem with objets trouvés the work becomes a means of establishing a private iconography, thereby wresting identity from a larger public sphere, where commodification can threaten individuality and meaning. This narrative artwork will communicate deep personal opinions and emotions but as human beings we share similar feelings, hopes and fears so inevitably visual and conceptual universality does exist.

                                                 ________________________________

                                               ________________________________

 
Now the FUN part! :-)

- a signed glossy postcard of my artwork "In my Dreams" 4" X 6"

- HUGE Thank you and public acknowledgment of your generosity on our social media platforms
          Estimated Delivery August 30th


      

- a limited edition (150) signed and numbered print of “In my Dreams” 5” X 7”

-HUGE Thank you and public acknowledgment of your generosity on our social media platforms
          Estimated Delivery August 30th

-A limited edition (100) ultra cotton t-shirt made with 100% cotton jersey         Choice of "PINK TEE with BUNNIES" (S,M,L) or "BLACK TEE with BAD DOG" (S,M,L)

- HUGE Thank you and public acknowledgment of your generosity on our social media platforms   Estimated Delivery August 30th


      

-A limited edition (10) signed and numbered archival matte print of  “Bad Dog 2,” 10” X 10”.  Estimated Delivery August 30th

-HUGE Thank you and public acknowledgment of your generosity on our social media platforms

      

-A limited edition (10) signed and numbered archival matte print of  “Bad Dog 2,” 17” X 17”.  Estimated Delivery August 30th

-HUGE Thank you and public acknowledgment of your generosity on our social media platforms

      

-A limited edition (10) signed and numbered archival matte print of “Bad Dog 2,” 24” X 24".  Estimated Delivery August 30th

-HUGE Thank you and public acknowledgment of your generosity on our social media platforms



-Lunch for two with the artist and a two-hour behind the scenes tour of the
Swatch 2015 exhibition with Jenny Krasner in Venice (all other expenses sole responsibility of the patron)

-Your choice of any single image limited edition (25) signed and numbered archival matte print on the web site:  www.jennykrasner.com

-HUGE Thank you and public acknowledgment of your generosity on our social media platforms         




-Full day with the artist and personal behind the scenes tour of the exhibition in Venice includes breakfast/lunch/dinner for two (all other expenses sole responsibility of the patron)

-Your choice of any single image limited edition of 25 (most images approximately 30"x40") signed and numbered archival matte print on the web site: www.jennykrasner.com     Estimated Delivery August 30th

-HUGE Thank you and public acknowledgment of your generosity on our social media platforms

story:
Short Summary

The Moreno Valley Arts Council has served the communities of Moreno Valley in northern New Mexico for 35 years.  We provide workshops, education, exhibits, shows, competitions, concerts and performances. We have always hopped from place to place because we had no venue of our own. 

I am Katherine, the Executive Director. I have worked with and for the Board for 15 years.  The dedicated people who started and sustained this organization gave us the footing and programming which allows us to grow.  It's simple. To continue to grow the arts in our communities, we need a home of our own.  There are several available spaces right now, that could serve our primary needs.  How big we go depends on how much we ultimately raise. We need space for workshops, performances, for rehearsals, for fine art exhibits, and art events, A place for the communities we serve to enjoy the arts. Even for simple meeting space we scramble month to month. 

We  know that $20,000 won't buy a facility.  Or $40,000 with the match. So why is that what we're asking for?  First, we believe it is achievable.  More importantly, with those funds we can leverage more funds with opportunities which require a match.  We can double or even triple the amount we can raise in this short term.  If we raise more than $20,000, it gets even easier.  Indiegogo keeps our account open to grow. There is an opportunity for a facility which would be a good fit for all but full performances.  With $100,000 we could buy it outright, do some updates/repairs, and still have funds for about a year of utilities and insurance.  We have a business plan and opportunity for grants. 

We are also working closely with the Artist Guild of Northern New Mexico. This group of all local artists organizes displays and shows and manages an ongoing show at our local visitors center.  Their 30 members are also our members and will be an integral part of our future home.  We are committed to Northern New Mexican artists and will strive to continually lift the stature of the arts in our communities.  We can see Poetry Readings, Literary soliloquies and similar events for the benefit of enriching the lives of our residents and visitors, which is integral to our mission. 


What We Need & What You Get

Above I explained more about what we need.  In short, we are aiming right now for $20,000 which is a starting place from which to grow the funding we'll need to make the art center a reality. It is what we need for initial negotiations with building owners to demonstrate we are serious about this. We plan to pass this center on to the future generations to continue the arts foundation built before us.  Further, as I explained above, we intend to leverage these funds with other funding opportunities that require a match.  Our ultimate goal is to acquire a space for cash with no obligatory Real Estate Contracts.  We have some great benefits for supporters donated by members and by ourselves.  No matter what you donate, you can choose to receive the "perk" or not, and, you can choose to be identified or not. 

The Impact

Long term, we see having our own space as a sustainable commitment to bringing the Arts to our communities.  We believe the long term impact of an Arts Activities Center is integral to the growth and sustainability of the communities we serve.  A number of young families are moving in....providing access to the Arts via workshops, performances, concerts and even access to dance is essential to the development of young people and to the enrichment of the adults.  Having a space that everyone knows is "where the Arts are" is part of the strategy of building Arts Based Rural Economic Development.  Garnering support from outside agencies and foundations is also increased when there is a specific facility that everyone can find where they can take workshops, see performances and experience the arts.

Risks & Challenges

There are challenges such as the fact that we are located in a small, rural and remote community. We operate a lot of programs/events on a shoestring, as it were.  We have to reach out to reach the funding goals we have and this is just the beginning.  If we reach our goal here, we can leverage those funds with other agencies, foundations and other funding opportunities to help us get enough funding to achieve this goal.  If we don't reach our goal, we won't stop. And this is important....if we don't meet our goal, we still get what has been donated, and pay indiegogo a fee (9%) But if we DO hit our goal (or more) that fee drops to 4%!  That format is why we chose indiegogo.  Any funding we achieve here will to a special restricted account for a facility. It will not be used for operations..we have other funding streams for that, which can not be used for capital acquisition. There is really little risk...we are committed to having a home.  It is simply a matter of how fast we get there.  All of the perks promised will be delivered, No matter what.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone who supports what we do can contribute.  You can still help.  Spread the news.  There are share tools right here on this site.  Share, share share!  And thank you, thank you, thank you.

story:
THIS CAMPAIGN HAS MOVED TO:  http://igg.me/at/vab/x/8936154


Many people don't like reading a lot of text, so the 2-panel comics and art in the Vegan Artbook are the perfect solution to spread the vegan message in a creative and thought-provoking way.

Some detailed info about the Vegan Artbook series: https://youtu.be/RjXzk2OTneY

The Vegan Artbook MILD contains over 300 pages of colourful artwork and comics each, focused on veganism, ethics, the environment, food, peace, love and animals. Aside from spreading cuteness, the books also raises awareness and shows people how they can make healthier and more ethical choices in their daily lives... all via artwork and short comics with 1 to 6 panels each!

These unique books are therefore the perfect gift for vegans and vegetarians or people who are interested in this ethical life philosophy. Because of the colourful cartoonish art style, the books especially aim at people who are visually oriented and young people such as teenagers (who often don’t like to read a lot of text) and it teaches our future generations how to make the world a better place.


I've been working on these books for many months but because I am still studying, I lack the funds to publish the Vegan Artbook MILD. The Vegan Artbook MILD is planned for an april release and I need your help to make it happen. If you think my project is valuable, please help me realize it by helping me fund the publication of this book. Everything will be produced environmentally friendly, but also in very high quality on smooth recycled paper! Printing a full-colour book like this with 320 pages in small quantities is quite expensive here, so I'll be very grateful for every bit of help I can get on this.

This is one of the unique VAB mugs you will receive if you claim reward 9, 10 or 11. There is also a different design availible.

Your money will be used for the printing and publication of the artbook. All other costs (like copic markers & other drawing materials) will be paid with the money from my own pocket. Vegan Artbook has been a non-profit project until now. The previous book (SPICY) was a free book and people only paid for printing and shipping costs. I think that, for a project like this, money isn't important. The most important thing is spreading compassion and literally save lives that way.

Don't forget to check the video for more information!
And please share a link to this crowdfunding page!
Thank you everyone! I love you all!
story_txt:
THIS CAMPAIGN HAS MOVED TO:  http://igg.me/at/vab/x/8936154Many people don't like reading a lot of text, so the 2-panel comics 
and art in the Vegan Artbook are the perfect solution to spread the 
vegan message in a creative and thought-provoking way.

Some detailed info about the Vegan Artbook series: https://youtu.be/RjXzk2OTneY

The Vegan Artbook MILD contains over 300 pages of 
colourful artwork and comics each, focused on veganism, ethics, the 
environment, food, peace, love and animals. Aside from spreading 
cuteness, the books also raises awareness and shows people how they can 
make healthier and more ethical choices in their daily lives... all via artwork and short comics with 1 to 6 panels each!

These unique books are therefore the perfect gift for vegans and 
vegetarians or people who are interested in this ethical life 
philosophy. Because of the colourful cartoonish art style, the books 
especially aim at people who are visually oriented and young people such
 as teenagers (who often don’t like to read a lot of text) and it teaches 
our future generations how to make the world a better place.


I've been working on these books for many months but because I am still 
studying, I lack the funds to publish the Vegan Artbook MILD. The Vegan 
Artbook MILD is planned for an april release and I need your help to 
make it happen. If you think my project is valuable, please help me 
realize it by helping me fund the publication of this book. Everything 
will be produced environmentally friendly, but also in very high quality
 on smooth recycled paper! Printing a full-colour book like this with 
320 pages in small quantities is quite expensive here, so I'll be very 
grateful for every bit of help I can get on this.

story:
For the past year and a half I’ve been working days and nights alongside with my friends and family, to accomplish one dream. 

I want to become a great artist!

To do so I have to get better. 

I enrolled in the 3D sense media school of arts in Singapore, and I know it is on the other side of the world, but nothing worth the while is easy!

I am here to ask for your support so I can accomplish this dream.

story:
Our Mission

To build community by sharing tools, ideas, and know-how.

About the Ballard Tool Library

What is a tool library? Just like a normal library, a tool library is a sustainable public service that provides community access to tools and an exchange of knowledge, at little to no cost.

The Ballard Tool Library will promote a sharing economy, mutual reliance, and environmental stewardship for our community.

A project of Sustainable Ballard, the BTL offers our community a chance to borrow tools and art supplies, reserve workspace, and learn more about DIY construction, gardening, and crafts. The BTL will also facilitate the exchange of privately owned tools community members are willing to trade or loan out to their neighbors because sharing is caring!

Our Vision

The BTL uses a very loose definition of "tools" and aims to create a diverse collection of construction, gardening, electrical, woodworking, arts, and crafting tools (think: power drills and knitting needles, sewing machines and shovels, pasta makers and linocut tools). 

In addition, the BTL plans to offer instruction, demos, and reservable workspace to assist you with your DIY projects.

What the Funds from this Campaign Will Cover

The BTL aims to be inclusive of all interested borrowers and will keep start-up and maintenance costs low.

The start-up costs raised from this campaign will be used in the following ways:

  • Ballard Tool Library site repairs and building costs
  • Collection building (i.e. buying BTL-owned tools to loan out)
  • Material costs (creating borrowing cards, buying record keeping materials, creating signage, etc.)
  • Insurance costs
  • Outreach costs to get the word out (poster printing, exhibiting, promotional materials, etc.)
  • Other miscellaneous start-up costs

Non-Financial Contributions

If you would like to get involved with the BTL and cannot contribute financially, please get the word out to others by sharing this Indiegogo page. The BTL works as a community-sustained service and is supported by donors, members, and volunteers.

Have tools you'd like to donate? We would love to hear from you. We are currently collecting names of potential tool donors to contact when we have a space for our future collection. Please let us know you are interested by sending an email to anna@sustainableballard.org.

Or—come to a meeting! Our volunteers are essential to getting the BTL up and running and their feedback and ideas will help the Tool Library offer a service that reflects the community’s needs. Check out the Sustainable Ballard Events page for upcoming meeting information: http://www.sustainableballard.org/events/

story:
Project Summary

You can help produce and archive this historic and monumental collaboration of art and music, 

During his highly public struggle with the city of Philadelphia to save his iconic studio from seizure under Eminient Domain, artist James E. Dupree developed over 400 pieces of artwork. Now, these pieces are brought together in the exhibition Stolen Dreams in the Promise Zone at Stockton University Art Garage in Atlantic City. Renown composer, bassist and producer Jamaaladeen Tacuma provides a powerful musical rendition of the installation titled The Black Picasso & Goliath– Breaking it All the Way Down. Each of The Black Picasso & Goliath's three movements reach deep into the total experience of Dupree's battle, resulting in a composition that conveys turmoil, passion and the triumphant result.  

Tacuma's composition will be performed live on Friday August 28 from 6PM-8PM, is  free and to the public. Your contribution will help make this event happen and produce its documentation.  


How Your Contribution is Used

100% Your donation to this project supports this historic, groundbreaking arts event in two ways:

1. Making the Event Happen:

Your donation will go directly to paying musicians and renting sound equipment to perform Tacuma's The Black Picasso & Goliath which is free to attend for all. This three movement piece puts sound to the visual installation Stolen Dreams in the Promise Zone, chronicling Dupree's seven year struggle to save his studio and museum from the hands of Eminent Domain laws in Philadelphia. 

2. Preserving This Piece of History

This once in a lifetime event can never be attended twice, but it can be preserved in history in the form of a video and audio recording.  Your contribution will help in rental and studio costs to digitally archive Tacuma's composition both in the form of an audio recording, and a DVD of the live performance at Stockton University Art Garage, which you can receive as a perk of your donation! 


About the Artists:


James E. Dupree

James E. Dupree is an accomplished artist, educator, and business owner.  Raised in between Philly and Pittsburgh, Dupree lived as a child just a few blocks from his Haverford Ave. studio.  Among the first black graduates of the University of Pennsylvania MFA program, and a recent recipient of the UPenn Black Alumni Society's Living Legend Award, he is in many ways an example of the success of Philadelphia’s art institutions in addressing the city’s underprivileged communities. He attended free classes at Fleisher Art Memorial as a child, he later received a full scholarship at Columbus College of Art and Design, and went on to prominence via graduate school at Pennsylvania Academy of the Arts and the University of Pennsylvania.


Dupree’s works are in the permanent collections of several museums, including the Philadelphia Museum of Art, the African American Museum in Philadelphia, and the Schomberg Museum in Copenhagen, as well as in private collections of the Dave Matthews Band and Patti LaBelle. He has been artist-in-residence at numerous cultural institutions including the National Museum of Wales and the Studio Museum of Harlem, and his sets for a Mummers Fancy Brigade club, the Shooting Stars, won them first place two years in a row and him the nickname of "King James". 

As an educator, he and his wife spent seven years running  and teaching at the Community Voyage School for runaway children at 35th and Lancaster Ave., and Mr. Dupree also taught at the Prints in Progress after-school program at 3500 Lancaster in the CEC building.  Dupree taught in higher education for many years at the University of the Arts and PAFA.  Currently, in addition to the private instruction offered at Dupree Studios, you can take free figure painting classes with Dupree at Fleisher Art Memorial.

Mr. Dupree has used his success as an artist to reinvest in the Philadelphia communities of his roots. There are many well-known examples of that investment, but one example that stands out is his studio in the Mantua neighborhood. His success is a product of the best Philadelphia art institutions, and he is an exemplary model of a Philadelphian investing back in his community. Part of his long term goals, his dream, has been to leave Dupree Studios as a pillar in the Mantua community.

jamesdupree.com for his bio and more of his work.


About Jamaaladeen Tacuma:

Tacuma has performed and recorded and collaborated with musicians on nearly every continent such as Japan, Korea, Europe and the Middle East. In September 2007, Jamaaladeen released a new recording entitled "THE FLAVORS OF THELONIOUS MONK RELOADED" paying musical homage to the great pianist composer Thelonious Monk and also releasing a new recording in October 2007 with "FREE FORM FUNKY FREQS" a trio with guitarist Vernon Reid (Living Color),and G. Calvin Weston (John Laurie, Medeski, Martin & Wood) on drums entitled "URBAN MYTHOLOGY" on Thirsty Ear Records. He has also played and produced for many American and European Jazz/Funk musicians. Furthermore, the release "Mirakles" by Derrick Bailey, G. Calvin Weston & Tacuma was cited as one of the "most important recordings of year 2000" by All Music Guide. He also recently completed a recording entitled "DUST" with BAUHAUS member Peter Murphy on the Metropolis label. He is also featured as writer and co-producer on the new 2006 release of the World Saxophone Quartet's album on Justin Time Records entitled "Political Blues" with a song by Jamaaladeen entitled "BLUE DIAMOND" Tacuma has collaborated with a diverse and talented roster of artists: Guitarists Jeff Beck, Carlos Santana, Marc Ribot, James Blood Ulmer, Jean Paul Bourelly and Derek Bailey.

He has performed and recorded with saxophonist Pharoah Sanders, Grover Washington Jr., David Murray, Odean Pope ,Wolfgang Puschnig and James Carter. He has worked with orchestras led by Anthony Davis at Carnegie Hall, to recording and performing with the Hip Hop rap group, The Roots, DJ King Britt and DJ Logic. Tacuma has shared the stage with the great comedian and philanthropist Bill Cosby at the JVC Jazz Festival, on the David Letterman show where Tacuma was Band Director for the night. He has even written music for the hit TV show, "The Cosby Show". He has worked with poets Jayne Cortez, Quincy Troupe, Amiri Baraka and co-wrote and co-produced a song entitled "WOMEN FIRST" with the R&B Neo Soul group from Philadelphia, KINDRED (the family soul) on their new CD recording "IN THIS LIFE TOGETHER", on the Hidden Beach/Motown label (2006). Jamaaladeen has recently explored the music of legendary saxophonist, composer John Coltrane with a preview recording and an extended European tour which featured the British saxophonist and BBC award recipient Tony Kofi. Jamaaladeen's FOR THE LOVE OR ORNETTE released 2010 on his own label was a monumental recording made in honor of his mentor Ornette Coleman. In 2013 Jamaaladeen released Bon Vivant his 2nd studio recording with FREE FORM FUNKY FREQS trio with G. Calvin Weston and Guitarist Vernon Reid on his newly formed recording label Jam All Productions.

In recent years Jamaaladeen has been gaining recognition from some of the Unites States most prestigious artist foundations, 2011 Jamaaladeen received the Pew Arts & Heritage Award, The Marcus Garvey Foundation Award, Uptown Theater Hall of Fame Award 2014. Jamaaladeen has received composer’s residencies at the prestigious MacDowell Colony , Headlands Center for the Arts, and Civitella Rainier Italy, where he composed a new project he will be presenting in 2015. Staying true to his artistic and experimental approach to music, Tacuma is consistently bringing musical happiness to fans World Wide.
