story:
Summary

In 2006, schoolteacher Marcel Jean started the Cite Soleil School of Music in Haiti to combat the traumas of poverty and misery with music and song. The Cite Soleil School of Music soon became the lifeblood of over 240 children.

As co-founder and director of Give Kids Your Instruments, a young-budding 501c3 nonprofit based in Brooklyn, NY, my goal is to get musical instruments to kids who cannot afford them. As an organization, we are also involved in setting up songwriting and ensemble workshops, recording sessions, and creative environments for young people in underserved communities to explore and harness the power of music and art.

I see art as foundational to social change; and I am moved beyond words when I see the tremendous effect music and arts education has on children living in areas emerging from conflict.

Over the past year, as Marcel and I have become friends, I have accumulated 20 instruments to donate to the school itself – as well as over 240 flutes for all 240 kids connected to Marcel Jean, director of Haiti Scholarship Association.

We are in the early stages of creating a partnership between Haiti Scholarship Association and Give Kids Your Instruments and it is important for me to travel to Haiti to see the school for myself and assess how best we can work together.

I will be traveling with my childhood friend Patrick who is Haitian and he will act as translator and cameraman. Our flight leaves for Port au Prince February 14th and we stay for 9 days. 

The following month, documentation of this project will be distributed online via our respective websites, art and culture blogs, and social media outlets. In addition, I will use the documentation of this project as supporting material when seeking grants for the Cite Soleil School of Music.


What We Need & What You Get


MY GOAL NOW IS TO RAISE $2000-$3,600 IN THE NEXT 10 DAYS TO HELP FUND THE TRANSPORTATION OF MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS AND THE DOCUMENTATION OF THE PROJECT.

$2000 will cover travel-related expenses:
-  $900   two plane tickets ($450 each)

-  $300   packing and transportation of music instruments  

-  $300   car hire in Haiti (four days worth)

-  $300:  anti-malaria medication

-  $200:  Indiegogo 9% fee

$1600 will cover documentary-related expenses:

-  $750   Canon EOS 7D DSLR camera body

-  $750   24-105mm lens

-  $70   external microphone

-  $30   tripod

Breakdown:

Transportation: $1500

Medical: $300

Documentation: $1600

Indiegogo fee: $200

Creative Perks For Contributions:

 

Prints:

Drawings:

 
Photographs:


Paintings:


Sculptures:


Please visit the gallery on the website to see what sort of artwork is available: www.singsoleil.com/gallery/

The Impact You Will Help To Make



1. Instruments:

Clearly, these kids also need food and medical attention, and you cannot eat a saxophone – but a saxophone can help us in less visible ways.

Music helps us deal with the dissonance in our lives. The simple act of blowing through a saxophone creates a safe space to reflect upon and express oneself, and this in turn strengthens our sense of self-reliance and feeling of belonging.

The kids at the Cite Soleil School of Music create a community of support for each other and this inspires and motivates them in the present and impacts the cultural life of Haiti in the long run. 

By contributing you help me bring tools of inspiration and strength to young people that need it most. 

2. Create Partnership 

By creating a partnership between Give Kids Your Instruments and Haiti Scholarship Association, we will be able to help project manage the music/arts program at the new school in the bamboo settlement being built in collaboration with Haiti Renaissance and the MIT architecture department. For more information on the long-term objective, please refer to our website: www.singsoleil.com/partners

3. Document Project  

My goal is to develop accountability with the local community and transparency with the international community. 

This will be the opening chapter to a documentary about the effect of arts education in areas emerging from conflict and the importance of art in cultural development. 

Please take a moment to watch the documentary about the Cite Soleil School of Music:



Risks & Challenges


There are health and safety risks that we are preparing for. The  post-earthquake landscape of Port au Prince can be hard to traverse. Not to mention, extreme levels of poverty and the political uncertainty of Haiti today force us to remain flexible for once we are on the ground we may have to improvise according to the present circumstances in order to achieve the mission. 

Be a part of this journey and allow me to escort you to the heart of Haiti's creative spirit by way of the camera. 

We are using the flexible donations option because every contribution counts. Patrick and I are going to Haiti to do this project by any means necessary. 


Other Ways You Can Help

  • HELP ME GET THE WORD OUT: Ten days is short and sweet. Help me get the word out. Share this campaign with anyone you feel might appreciate it and/or post on your social media sites.
  • DONATE AN INSTRUMENT: Have an instrument you'd like to donate to kids in Haiti? Contact us at: wehelpyou@givekidsyourinstruments.com  
  • LEARN MORE ABOUT GIVE KIDS YOUR INSTRUMENTS: www.givekidsyourinstruments.org
  • LEARN MORE ABOUT HAITI SCHOLARSHIP: www.haitischolarship.org
  • FOLLOW SING SOLEIL: 240 FLUTES: www.singsoleil.com

1. Instruments:
Clearly, these kids also need food and medical attention, and you cannot eat a saxophone – but a saxophone can help us in less visible ways.
Music helps us deal with the dissonance in our lives. The simple act of blowing through a saxophone creates a safe space to reflect upon and express oneself, and this in turn strengthens our sense of self-reliance and feeling of belonging.
The kids at the Cite Soleil School of Music create a community of support for each other and this inspires and motivates them in the present and impacts the cultural life of Haiti in the long run. 
By contributing you help me bring tools of inspiration and strength to young people that need it most. 
2. Create Partnership 
By creating a partnership between Give Kids Your Instruments and Haiti Scholarship Association, we will be able to help project manage the music/arts program at the new school in the bamboo settlement being built in collaboration with Haiti Renaissance and the MIT architecture department. For more information on the long-term objective, please refer to our website: www.singsoleil.com/partners
3. Document Project  
My goal is to develop accountability with the local community and transparency with the international community. 
This will be the opening chapter to a documentary about the effect of arts education in areas emerging from conflict and the importance of art in cultural development. 
Please take a moment to watch the documentary about the Cite Soleil School of Music:





Risks & Challenges

There are health and safety risks that we are preparing for. The  post-earthquake landscape of Port au Prince can be hard to traverse. Not to mention, extreme levels of poverty and the political uncertainty of Haiti today force us to remain flexible for once we are on the ground we may have to improvise according to the present circumstances in order to achieve the mission. 
Be a part of this journey and allow me to escort you to the heart of Haiti's creative spirit by way of the camera. 
We are using the flexible donations option because every contribution counts. Patrick and I are going to Haiti to do this project by any means necessary. 


Other Ways You Can Help


 

HELP ME GET THE WORD OUT: Ten days is short and sweet. Help me get the word out. Share this campaign with anyone you feel might appreciate it and/or post on your social media sites.




DONATE AN INSTRUMENT: Have an instrument you'd like to donate to kids in Haiti? Contact us at: wehelpyou@givekidsyourinstruments.com  




LEARN MORE ABOUT GIVE KIDS YOUR INSTRUMENTS: www.givekidsyourinstruments.org




LEARN MORE ABOUT HAITI SCHOLARSHIP: www.haitischolarship.org




FOLLOW SING SOLEIL: 240 FLUTES: www.singsoleil.com

story:
My name is Zach Seeger and I am an artist based in Brooklyn and upstate New York.

Recently I was provided with the opportunity to teach a class The Found Object: an Exploration of Appropriation at UC Berkeley Extension in California starting in the spring semester of 2016. I am excited for the opportunity, but cannot afford the travel and living expenses in the Bay Area. This campaign is to bring attention to the struggles that adjunct teachers are forced to contend with just to do what they were educated and trained to do (I received my BFA from Binghamton University, and my MFA in painting from RISD). With your help I will succeed in my goal to teach the class. I will be rewarding those who contribute with original artworks: drawings, paintings, and collages. I need to raise a total of $12,000 dollars to break even on my expenses. I have dedicated the last 6 months to making drawings, paintings, and collages to give back to those who donate.

Donate $50 and receive a collage 8" x 11"

Donate $100 and receive an acrylic painting on vinyl (album cover) 16" x 20"

Donate $200 and receive an acrylic, ink, mica drawing on paper 22" x 30"

Donate $400 and receive a small painting 16" x 22"

Donate $500 and receive a medium painting  36" x 48"

Donate $1000 and receive a large painting 48" x 67"

Donate $5000+ and be a sponsor of the class*

*your name will go on the title of the class and I will read your name before the start of each class

story:
Hello! We are Threads. We would like to present our project... Threads on Tour: Pop-up Gallery Project

After staging several pop-up art events we are now at the stage where we need to move Threads on, take on new challenges and embark on the journey we created. So we are taking Threads on tour... 

We offer

  • Free opportunities to exhibit work 
  • Video Art screenings
  • Peer-to-peer work-in-progress crits 
  • Development workshops 

Our project is / your money will support:

We will use this money to match fund an Arts Council Funding application which will help fill the void between graduating with an Art Degree... and the "Real World". We will also be able to purchase the equipment we need to sustain our events and exhibitions on a regular basis. We plan on helping fill this void by offering a funded 3 month placement for an Art-Grad to run regular peer-to-peer work-in-progress groups within their local community. They will be learning on the job business skills as they: Source the venue, advertise to reach out to find the Artists, Budget the pop-up exhibition. As a result they will have more experience to present on their CV. The group they manage will meet on a peer-to-peer level, discussing art work in progress with the aim to produce more work alongside trying to earn a living. They will then celebrate their time together with a pop-up exhibition.

If we don't reach our target

We will still be able to use any money we raise to support our application to the Arts Council. 

How will this benefit you and the IMPACT of this project?

By creating these pop-up events we boost the cultural drive and excitement for the Arts outside London. We believe that this energy will spark hope in other creatives who lack, or who have lost the confidence to create. We will be able to offer more exhibiting opportunities for Artists and more paid opportunities for those Artists wishing to run workshops etc. with the support of our team. 

Moreover, we have a heap of lovely hand-made incentives that we have been working on! As these are limited editions and 1/1's they are incredibly sentimental and high in personal value. 

Perks For YOU! 

We have some fabulous hand made incentives for you when you pledge money towards our project.... perfect for gifts!! Remember, you can pledge how much or how little you wish... but 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

If you pledge £15 or more you will receive a mention on our website and also in our next publication and a selection of 3 Hand Made Illustrated Badges

                              

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

For a pledge of £20 or more you will get to engrave your name onto one of our man made plinths at the Private View of our next pop - up exhibition and once the exhibition is over we will let you keep the bit of plinth with your name on it! You will also receive a notable mention in our publication and on our website... take a look at one of our previous Plinths... 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
For a pledge of £35 or more you can get one of our one special Goodie Bags which includes; a one of a kind Limited Edition A3 Screen Print, A5 Hand Made Canvas Sketch Book, Painted Post Card, Screen Printed Tote Bag, notable mention on our website AND in our next publication 
Goodie Bag 1


Goodie Bag 2


Goodie Bag 3


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
For a pledge of £40 or more a place on one of our Japanese bookbinding workshops, a bundle of handmade goodies, notable mention on our website AND in our next publication 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

For a pledge of £50 or more we will give you access to a webinar (live stream) of our next artist critique with the chance to question our artists on their practice, notable mention on our website AND in our next publication 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

For a pledge of £100 or more you will get the chance to sit amongst the artists critique for you and one friend as a form of live cinema with champagne. This will give you an insight into the workings of our chosen artists' brains, a notable mention on our website AND in our next publication 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 

Risks & Challenges

I (Philippa Wall) Graduated with a Fine Art Degree in the summer of 2013 from University of Southampton, Winchester School of Art. Since then I started Threads. Along this journey I have attended many entrepreneurial workshops/courses ranging from Book-keeping to start-up one day courses in order to inform my business skills. 

Although Threads was only created earlier this year we have grown into a team of Art Graduates devoting time and love to this project. We have had this projected acknowledged and supported by Jamie Wyld (Director of This is Wyld and Videoclub) who has agreed to write our Arts Council England application which this Indie Go Go will match fund. This support along with countless others, credited by various institutions has confirmed our confidence in this project. 

As we are using this money to match fund an Arts Council bid by at least 35% we have confidence that this will be a successful application. If it is unsuccessful we shall apply the improvements and re-apply.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us share this project by using the #threadsontour on Instagram, Facebook, Twitter and LinkedIn, you can follow us @ThreadsKent

story: Avant Garde of Arts /Christopher Marc is a dreamer’s society, which has focused on providing a global platform and forum for dreamers, artists, and entrepreneurs worldwide.  Through our society we will provide a support system for each individual to help develop and build their dreams. Our goal is to show multicultural creativity through theater, film, poetry, fashion, and many other forms of artistic expression. We provide affordable entertainment with a fulfilling exposure to multiple aspects of culture. With this vision we will help dreamers, artists, and entrepreneurs to get back to enjoying life again by paving a way to help make their dream come true.
story_txt:

Marc is a dreamer’s society, which has focused on providing a global platform
and forum for dreamers, artists, and entrepreneurs worldwide.  Through our society we will provide a support
system for each individual to help develop and build their dreams. Our goal is
to show multicultural creativity through theater, film, poetry, fashion, and
many other forms of artistic expression. We
provide affordable
entertainment with a fulfilling exposure to multiple aspects of culture. With this vision we will help dreamers, artists, and
entrepreneurs to
get back to enjoying life again by paving a way to help make their dream come true.

story:
Koco Collab

Hello humanoids! We are Koco Collab a collaborative Duo consisting of art ladies Aiko Szymczak and Corinne "Bee Bop" Trujillo. With your help we can paint murals on non profit organizations and engage with the community through art. Our goal is to raise $20,000 for our studio based out of Denver, Co in the Santa fe Art District that will help us buy materials like spray paint, house paint, rollers, brushes, lifts ect. because the average mural cost us $2000-$7000 (depending on the size of the wall). If you donate $100 dollars you will receive a limited edition print, if you donate $500 you will receive a small original painting, if you donate $1000 you will receive a T-shirt and a small painting, if you donate more than $1000 you will get all of the above and the $10,000 plus backers will receive a large original Koco Collab painting. If we don't hit our goal we will still use the money for as many art materials as we can get our painty little hands on. This project will stop vandalism in areas that are consistently getting tagged and help powerful organizations acquire art bringing attention to what they do in the community. We are working with a couple non profits teaching classes, giving demonstrations, and live painting at various venues around Denver, as well as hanging our work in galleries, at coffeeshops, dance studios, breweries and bars. Your contribution to this project big or small is monumental for not only two female artists but for everyone who enjoys mural art and art in general.  We struggle to make ends meet when we are pouring all our money into supplies, studio rent, and product investment. Sometimes making little to no money on certain projects we spend hours, days, and weeks on. We will keep keepin on and fight to live in our passions before being comfortable because we are creators and fail all the time but always find a solution. If you don't have the money to help that's totally a okay just share and make some noise for us!!! We love everyone who supports our mission! Thank you. 

~Aiko Szymczak & Corinne "Bee Bop" Trujillo 

Instagrams: @aikoyougo @corinnebeebop @kococollab

Website: www.aikoyougo.com www.vivifyart.com 

Music in video: https://m.soundcloud.com/mbellemares

story:
Intro and Director Statement

Hello my name is Hawar Karim, I am now major in Master of Fine Arts in New York Film Academy in Burbank. There is an upcoming student thesis film that begins its production in March which is very essential for me to build a portfolio into my film business career. I hope this campaign can give you an idea what you can see and discover.

The concept of the story is taken by those victims from Iraq who suffered the attack by ISIS's brutality. The war that causes thousands innocent lives show no mercy to this world. Victims who kidnapped by the ISIS are forced to be sex slaves, especially the women and girls. People are losing their strength and soul during the manipulation.

The center of my film is about women and I hope people can hear the voices from the women above the violations. I want to point out that what happen in the story can also be occurring everywhere awarded wars. I also want to point out I come from this background  and I surely understand the feelings when the women are suffering and when they have a child who is about to born into this world.

Use of donations

As this is a very important project for me, I hope you can help me and my production when we are currently battling out biggest war so far, which is the financial issue.

The donations from you will be used into the below areas of our productions.

- Production Team

- Locations and permits

- Camera  & lighting Equipments & Insurance

- Costume and makeup for actors

- Large amount of food catering.

Risks & Challenges

Based on the script so far, the estimated budget of money will be exceeded over $7,000, which is a very large number for me. 

I am in a very harsh situation that I also need to pay the tuition for my current school program. There will be no words to say but only appreciation and thanks to you if you can help me out. 

As I have been thinking about this idea for years and i know this is a right time for me to achieve this dream. Please hear the voices from my very deepest heart, it is the right time for you to share my information to your friends and family. Please give us a chance to make a great film and please trust us and let's make this film come true.

Thank you so much!!!

story:
Well on the way to being finished! We now need help paying off the bills.

This photo is from several days ago and shows the canopy frame disassembled on the deck, the panorama frame is on its pedestal (the viewers, which fit into the openings in the sides, are inside the building and off the construction site to protect them), one of the "skirts" to dress the sides of the trailer is in place to show how it will look (all the others are done). For lots of photos of our build, check out our Instagram page at https://www.instagram.com/puddletown_panorama/

 

 

Extra special gift to entice you to donate!

Anyone who has donated to date (August 7th, 2017) will be receiving a special thank you gift from us, and anyone donating at $50 or above from now on, until the end of the campaign, will also be getting this visual treat and 3d collectible!

Thanks to one of our build crew - who also happens to be a stereographer - you will be receiving a pair of left - right button badges with which  you can practice your free-viewing skills. Yup, pin them to your jacket either left-right for parallel viewing, or right-left for you cross-eyed viewers, and you will see our logo do magical things. You can start practicing right now - check out the graphic for the buttons shown here in left-right-left form:

Wondering what all this free-viewing and left-right-left stuff is all about?

Wonder no more. For a donation of $25 bucks you could get our handy dandy postcard guide to free-viewing (check out the perks below and to the right), and for an extra $25 more we'll send the badges along too! Deal!

What is this all about?

Everyone loves optical illusions!  For anyone who has studied vision, or even played around with a plastic View-Master, you know how cool it is to see a photograph in 3D!  In the 1800s, the first stereoscope was invented to trick the eyes into seeing three dimensional images from two slightly offset photos, and thus begun the world’s love affair with 3D imagery. 

As a lover of stereoscopes old and new, I decided it would be cool to bring the science of stereoscopic imagery into an interactive mobile art piece that showcases both how these images are created and allows viewers to view our vast collection of new and historic photographs.

We’re excited to bring you the Puddletown Panorama - an art and science exhibit on wheels!

The Puddletown Panorama (PtP) is a multi-station viewing device, inspired by antique stereoviewers and using the format of the stereocard.  And my amazing crew and I are building it right now! For more information about the roots of this project, please take a look at our first IndieGoGo video at https://youtu.be/loWE7ByLhlM

Up to five people at a time will be able to view unique sets of 3d images in the form of stereocards  at each of the viewing stations. The subject matter will vary, depending on venue and the type of event.  We have received overwhelming interest from fellow stereophotographers who have already started sending their images for inclusion in the Puddletown’s collection of cards, and they will take their place alongside hundreds of historic and antique cards.

This is not a short term project; we intend to grow this venture into the future as our library of images expands, and word spreads of our willingness to bring stereophotography to your community.  Our first outing will be to the Burning Man arts festival in August this year and we just landed our second outing - we have been invited to bring the PtP to Portland's, Mini Maker Faire at the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry in mid-September.

The entire Puddletown Panorama, in a livery of British racing green with cream, dark red and gold trim, has the look of an early 20th cent. circus, or carnival, sideshow with Victorian remnants peeking out around the edges. Illuminated by LED lighting and towed by it's own unique vehicle, the Puddletown Puller, the Puddletown Panorama is decorated with fancy metal work, gilding, hand painted artwork and lettering, the entire piece forming an  intimate space, itself a demonstration of art and craftsmanship in the service of a special type of photography.  Any you can be a part of this by making a donation to our project.

 

Fundraising #2.

Our first IndieGoGo campaign for the PtP, back in April this year, raised $4,100 (after fees taken by IndieGoGo and payment processing companies). As we explained back then, this was seed money to get us up and running with materials, equipment and general supplies, and that is exactly how all of that (and nearly as much again) has been spent:

Basic trailer construction and registration - $1,400

Building materials and specialist parts - $3,450

Tools and equipment - $800

Card making supplies - $350

Puller (base vehicle, parts, etc.) - $800

Fundraising rewards (includes stock for future campaigns) and shipping - $1,000

TOTAL SPENT TO DATE = $7,800

While we have the bulk of our materials, we still have things to acquire and on-going expenses; we need a spare wheel and four corner stabilizers for the trailer,  printer ink for the cards, hardware, paint, more printer ink, saw blades, four LED lanterns as emergency lighting in case the generator dies, did we mention printer ink, photo paper for the cards, drill bits, more photo paper, deckstain, etc., etc.  Then there are the transportation costs for the PtP's first outing, to Burning Man.

Our projected total costs will be around $12,000.

So, we are asking for your help in raising at least another $4,000 towards this overall total. $5,000 would be even better!

 

What do you get?

The satisfaction of knowing that you helped out a bunch of talented and passionate builders finance and make a contraption that will be both educational and bring smiles to many faces. Building projects like these also give opportunities for makers to learn new skills while sharing their existing ones with others. These projects foster friendships and cooperation between makers that can last a lifetime, and extend into other parts of their lives and communities, both work related and personal.

But, if that isn't enough, we have perks for you. Some of them were available during our first campaign, but we have added a few new items if you feel the need for a physical token of our thanks for your donation. Please take a look at our offerings described at the bottom of this section. 

Want to see how the build is going?

Check out our build blog at https://www.puddletownpanorama.com/build-blog

 

Risks & Challenges

We are well on the way to making the Puddletown Panorama a reality. Actually, it is a reality, and getting closer to completion everyday. There is little risk involved in backing us; as a crew we are all seasoned, successful builders and makers of similar projects, and many of work in creative day jobs. We have already done much of the primary construction work and are now dealing with the details. You will be backing a winner and making it easier for us to reach completion. Not to mention lightening the financial load that has already accumulated.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you have already supported us with a donation and once again, we thank you.  If you can help out one more time with a few more dollars, that would be fantastic.  

If this project is new to you, or you were waiting to see what we did with the initial funding, how about stepping up and giving us a donation, please?  All offerings, large or small are most welcome.

Whether you are able to help us financially or not, please lend a hand by spreading the word about our project to as many people as possible.  Share it on Facebook, Twitter, whatever is your social media of choice. Email your friends.  IndieGoGo makes this easy through their share tools on this page. 

And that's all there is to it!

 

Want to see the Puddletown for yourself?

August, 2017 - Burning Man arts festival, Nevada

September 16-17, Portland Mini Maker Faire, Oregon Museum of Science and Industry.

May 18-20, 2018, Bay Area Maker Faire (anticipated event)

If you’re interested in showcasing the PtP at your event, get in touch!  We’d love to connect! 

 

The Perks!

A complete breakdown of the individual perks and combinations are on the right of this page, but here is an overview of what we would like to give you in return for your generous donation and support.

FOR ALL DONATIONS TO THIS CAMPAIGN: Your name added to the list of Puddletown Philanthropists that will be posted on our website and proclaimed at our inaugural outing to Burning Man, 2017.

FOR $5: Thanks, gratitude and appreciation.  Every penny counts, as they say, and we believe this wholeheartedly.  Every click of the Panorama as it turns, will be a shout out to you.

FOR $10: The Puddle Town Panorama sticker. A full colour rendition of our logo, printed on a sticker  so that you can proclaim your support anywhere you choose to place it.

The Puddletown Panorama stickers.

FOR $10: Enamel camp mug. If you saw our first campaign, you will recognise this mug.​ Unfortunately,  after getting them, we discovered that they had not been manufactured properly and that if submerged in water (as you might  when washing them in a sink, for example) the coating separates from the outside and peels off. Despite exhaustive efforts to get the manufacturer to replace their substandard product, we have been left with a number of these to disperse. They are food safe, will hold hot drinks or food, you just can't soak them in the sink! But all is not lost - they make terrific pencil, pen and small tool holders! We are offering them at this level (plus shipping) in an effort to recover our costs and a few bucks more. 

Repurposed mug pencil holder.

FOR $30: Puddletown insignia pendant or pin. This laser cut, wooden token is in the shape of the Puddletown insignia and is 2.25 inches tall. It is available to you as a pendant or pin - your choice.

Our insignia available as either pendant, pin or fridge magnet.

FOR $25: A stereo-postcard of the Puddletown Panorama model, complete with instructions on how to “free view” stereo images. Yes, you can view stereopairs without  a viewer, so with these instructions, a sample image and a little practice, you too can become an expert freeviewer.

The secrets to free viewing!  Well, you didn't expect us to put the actual text here, did you?  Claim this perk, and all will be revealed.

FOR $35: Insignia embroidered patch: This is our standard embroidered patch, stitched in great detail and highlighted with gold metallic thread.

Our insignia as an embroidered patch.

FOR $50:  Coasters. A set of four, laser cut, wooden coasters in the shape of the Puddletown insignia.

The Puddletown wooden coaster.

FOR $60: Combo - patch and  pendant  or pin. In honour of your generous donation, we will send you an embroidered patch along with your choice of wooden pendant, pin or magnet.

FOR $75:  Combo - patch and a set of coasters.  Wear our insignia while sharing a beverage with your friends and keep those ring marks off your best table by using your very own Puddletown coasters.

FOR $90: Combo - patch, pendant or pin and stickers. A patch, a pendant or pin and four stickers wrapped with oodles of thanks.

FOR $110: Set of three handmade stereocards with folding viewer.  Three handmade stereocards from stereo-photographs taken by J. Claire Dean, the proprietress of the Puddletown Panorama, featuring the PtP at Burning Man this summer, August, 2017.  If you claimed the first set of cards during our April campaign, these will make a nice addition to your collection. They will be part of the permanent Puddletown library, and this is a chance for you to get your very own copies, with a viewer - just in case you didn't manage to master the art of free viewing. (Note: views will be different from those shown here.)

Three new stereocards of the Piddletown Panorama at her inaugural event - Burning Man, 2017.

FOR $250: Limited chance, your name on the Puddletown.  Let your name help light our way and become a true Puddletown Panorama Philanthropist!  Your name emblazoned on a dedication plaque on the reflector of one of the Puddletown Panorama’s lanterns. Below is a photograph of one of the two dedication plates claimed during our last campaign. Four opportunities remain for you to claim a lantern. We will send you a photograph of your name on the Puddletown Panorama as a memento (along with a sticker or two) and of course, our endless thanks.

The dedication plate for one of the two lanterns claimed  during our last IndieGoGo campaign, seen here attached to the mockup of the lantern reflector, which is being made from brushed stainless steel. The plaques are mounted on the backs of the reflectors where they can be clearly seen by our visitors enjoying the viewers on the platform.
story_txt:
Well on the way to being finished! We now need help paying off the bills.
This photo is from several days ago and shows the canopy frame disassembled on the deck, the panorama frame is on its pedestal (the viewers, which fit into the openings in the sides, are inside the building and off the construction site to protect them), one of the "skirts" to dress the sides of the trailer is in place to show how it will look (all the others are done). For lots of photos of our build, check out our Instagram page at https://www.instagram.com/puddletown_panorama/

 
 
Extra special gift to entice you to donate!
Anyone who has donated to date (August 7th, 2017) will be receiving a special thank you gift from us, and anyone donating at $50 or above from now on, until the end of the campaign, will also be getting this visual treat and 3d collectible!
Thanks to one of our build crew - who also happens to be a stereographer - you will be receiving a pair of left - right button badges with which  you can practice your free-viewing skills. Yup, pin them to your jacket either left-right for parallel viewing, or right-left for you cross-eyed viewers, and you will see our logo do magical things. You can start practicing right now - check out the graphic for the buttons shown here in left-right-left form:

Wondering what all this free-viewing and left-right-left stuff is all about?
Wonder no more. For a donation of $25 bucks you could get our handy dandy postcard guide to free-viewing (check out the perks below and to the right), and for an extra $25 more we'll send the badges along too! Deal!
What is this all about?
Everyone loves optical illusions!  For anyone who has studied vision, or even played around with a plastic View-Master, you know how cool it is to see a photograph in 3D!  In the 1800s, the first stereoscope was invented to trick the eyes into seeing three dimensional images from two slightly offset photos, and thus begun the world’s love affair with 3D imagery. 
As a lover of stereoscopes old and new, I decided it would be cool to bring the science of stereoscopic imagery into an interactive mobile art piece that showcases both how these images are created and allows viewers to view our vast collection of new and historic photographs.
We’re excited to bring you the Puddletown Panorama - an art and science exhibit on wheels!
The Puddletown Panorama (PtP) is a multi-station viewing device, inspired by antique stereoviewers and using the format of the stereocard.  And my amazing crew and I are building it right now! For more information about the roots of this project, please take a look at our first IndieGoGo video at https://youtu.be/loWE7ByLhlM
Up to five people at a time will be able to view unique sets of 3d images in the form of stereocards  at each of the viewing stations. The subject matter will vary, depending on venue and the type of event.  We have received overwhelming interest from fellow stereophotographers who have already started sending their images for inclusion in the Puddletown’s collection of cards, and they will take their place alongside hundreds of historic and antique cards.
This is not a short term project; we intend to grow this venture into the future as our library of images expands, and word spreads of our willingness to bring stereophotography to your community.  Our first outing will be to the Burning Man arts festival in August this year and we just landed our second outing - we have been invited to bring the PtP to Portland's, Mini Maker Faire at the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry in mid-September.
The entire Puddletown Panorama, in a livery of British racing green with cream, dark red and gold trim, has the look of an early 20th cent. circus, or carnival, sideshow with Victorian remnants peeking out around the edges. Illuminated by LED lighting and towed by it's own unique vehicle, the Puddletown Puller, the Puddletown Panorama is decorated with fancy metal work, gilding, hand painted artwork and lettering, the entire piece forming an  intimate space, itself a demonstration of art and craftsmanship in the service of a special type of photography.  Any you can be a part of this by making a donation to our project.
 
Fundraising #2.
Our first IndieGoGo campaign for the PtP, back in April this year, raised $4,100 (after fees taken by IndieGoGo and payment processing companies). As we explained back then, this was seed money to get us up and running with materials, equipment and general supplies, and that is exactly how all of that (and nearly as much again) has been spent:
Basic trailer construction and registration - $1,400
Building materials and specialist parts - $3,450
Tools and equipment - $800
Card making supplies - $350
Puller (base vehicle, parts, etc.) - $800
Fundraising rewards (includes stock for future campaigns) and shipping - $1,000
TOTAL SPENT TO DATE = $7,800
While we have the bulk of our materials, we still have things to acquire and on-going expenses; we need a spare wheel and four corner stabilizers for the trailer,  printer ink for the cards, hardware, paint, more printer ink, saw blades, four LED lanterns as emergency lighting in case the generator dies, did we mention printer ink, photo paper for the cards, drill bits, more photo paper, deckstain, etc., etc.  Then there are the transportation costs for the PtP's first outing, to Burning Man.
Our projected total costs will be around $12,000.
So, we are asking for your help in raising at least another $4,000 towards this overall total. $5,000 would be even better!
 
What do you get?
The satisfaction of knowing that you helped out a bunch of talented and passionate builders finance and make a contraption that will be both educational and bring smiles to many faces. Building projects like these also give opportunities for makers to learn new skills while sharing their existing ones with others. These projects foster friendships and cooperation between makers that can last a lifetime, and extend into other parts of their lives and communities, both work related and personal.
But, if that isn't enough, we have perks for you. Some of them were available during our first campaign, but we have added a few new items if you feel the need for a physical token of our thanks for your donation. Please take a look at our offerings described at the bottom of this section. 
Want to see how the build is going?Check out our build blog at https://www.puddletownpanorama.com/build-blog 
Risks & Challenges
We are well on the way to making the Puddletown Panorama a reality. Actually, it is a reality, and getting closer to completion everyday. There is little risk involved in backing us; as a crew we are all seasoned, successful builders and makers of similar projects, and many of work in creative day jobs. We have already done much of the primary construction work and are now dealing with the details. You will be backing a winner and making it easier for us to reach completion. Not to mention lightening the financial load that has already accumulated.

 
Other Ways You Can Help
Some of you have already supported us with a donation and once again, we thank you.  If you can help out one more time with a few more dollars, that would be fantastic.  
If this project is new to you, or you were waiting to see what we did with the initial funding, how about stepping up and giving us a donation, please?  All offerings, large or small are most welcome.
Whether you are able to help us financially or not, please lend a hand by spreading the word about our project to as many people as possible.  Share it on Facebook, Twitter, whatever is your social media of choice. Email your friends.  IndieGoGo makes this easy through their share tools on this page.

They are food safe, will hold hot drinks or food, you just can't soak them in the sink! But all is not lost - they make terrific pencil, pen and small tool holders! We are offering them at this level (plus shipping) in an effort to recover our costs and a few bucks more. Repurposed mug pencil holder.FOR $30: Puddletown insignia pendant or pin. This laser cut, wooden token is in the shape of the Puddletown insignia and is 2.25 inches tall. It is available to you as a pendant or pin - your choice.Our insignia available as either pendant, pin or fridge magnet.FOR $25: A stereo-postcard of the Puddletown Panorama model, complete with instructions on how to “free view” stereo images. Yes, you can view stereopairs without  a viewer, so with these instructions, a sample image and a little practice, you too can become an expert freeviewer.The secrets to free viewing!  Well, you didn't expect us to put the actual text here, did you?  Claim this perk, and all will be revealed.FOR $35: Insignia embroidered patch: This is our standard embroidered patch, stitched in great detail and highlighted with gold metallic thread.Our insignia as an embroidered patch.FOR $50:  Coasters. A set of four, laser cut, wooden coasters in the shape of the Puddletown insignia.The Puddletown wooden coaster.FOR $60: Combo - patch and  pendant  or pin. In honour of your generous donation, we will send you an embroidered patch along with your choice of wooden pendant, pin or magnet.FOR $75:  Combo - patch and a set of coasters.  Wear our insignia while sharing a beverage with your friends and keep those ring marks off your best table by using your very own Puddletown coasters.FOR $90: Combo - patch, pendant or pin and stickers. A patch, a pendant or pin and four stickers wrapped with oodles of thanks.FOR $110: Set of three handmade stereocards with folding viewer.  Three handmade stereocards from stereo-photographs taken by J. story:
DRIGGproductions is a small collective of dance artists who are passionate about creating art that connects people. In our attempt to humanize our art form, we learn more about ourselves, and how we can contribute to society through expression, action and giving. 

 

'Magnificent You' explores the socio, psychological, and spiritual cause & effects of narcissism through multimedia and live dance performance. During our research of self obsession, dancers investigate the physical realities of division, separation and discord amongst the self, observing how we are affected by our surroundings and others’ choices. How has society and media become a crucial component in our view of self?

DRIGGs is excited for our educational residency and repertory workshop at the Dance Industry Performing Arts Center in Dallas, Texas. Co-Artistic Directors Khadija Ahmaddiya and Mark Caserta, & DRIGG's company members will teach master classes and lead students in the creation of short works to be shared in informal installations throughout the week. The residency will culminate in the world premieres of the newly revamped 'Magnificent You' and a new DRIGGproductions original film. We are thrilled to embark upon our first national tour and grateful for the opportunity to share our work in ever expanding spaces! 

 

SUPPORT DRIGGS TODAY!!

story:
Libby's Eyes is by emerging playwright Amy Bethan Evans, Libby’s Eyes will premiere at The Bunker Theatre London this June as part of the Breaking Out Season.  It is produced by A Poke in the Eye Productions and directed by Spencer Noll.

 

Based on the real life experience of playwright Amy Bethan Evans and that of many disabled people like her. Libby's Eyes is a black comedy, state of the nation theatre production about one one blind girl, the benefit system and a smart mouth sassy robot called L. E.

 

However in order to get this show on we need your help.  By contributing to the Libby's Eyes Campaign you will not only help fund an original and innovative theatre production but one that provides a voice to the disabled community.  Libby is the voice of an underrepresented group who are currently at the mercy of government cutbacks to there disabled benefits. Cutbacks that are forcing many disabled people into poverty. Amy would like to dedicate this play to anyone who has been through the PIP process or has supported someone who has.

 

We are asking you to make whatever donation you can towards putting on the 8 night run of our show at the wonderful Bunker Theatre in London's as part of their Breaking Out season.  A small donation to this show will have a huge impact.

The Bunker Theatre is highly successful fringe venue in the bough Southwark London.  "Celebrating 'The Company' and showcasing BREAKING OUT is a festival of world premiere shows by six of the country's most exciting emerging theatre companies, chosen by The Bunker artistic team from over 45 different projects. BREAKING OUT is your chance to see the future of theatre in the here and now."

Now let me tell you where your money will be going....

 

Access requirements.

Libby's Eyes is not like any fringe theatre show because we hope to make it fully accessible. Many disabled people cannot access theatre due to inaccessible venues and shows, they can feel marginalised from being able to experience theatre and we want to change that. Many shows do not have WC access, clear signage, captioning etc-all the things that would allow a person with a disability to experience a theatre production. These are all simple things that can be put into a show at a reasonable cost. People with disabilities can not only experience a show that's accessible for them but one that represents their lives. They can hear and see their voices and lives on stage.  The Bunker is WC access venue and we plan to add captioning, BSL interpreter, touch tours and audio description. 

 

Rehearsal space

Rehearsal space in London is notoriously expensive and we need a safe space to rehearse Libby's Eyes in for our team to get the best results.   By contributing to this you are allowing disabled actors and writer to work in safe functional space that gives them the chance to create the best work they can without hindrances.

 

Paying the team

Libby's Eyes has a cast of four actors and we believe in paying actors for their work. We want the best out of the team and production and paying actors is simply an obvious way of doing that.  It would set an example in the industry that actors should be paid. 

Cast and creative team fees are in line with Equity, ITC and industry standards. We are passionate about increasing the pressence of disabled creatives and performers in theatre, which can only be achieved through better access in terms of disablity and pay. By providing paid work and professional credits we hope to see more disabled performers playing roles of both disabled and non-disabled characters on stage.

 

Why donate?

Libby's Eyes is more than play.  It is statement on the realities of living with disability in the 21st Century.  Benefit cuts are affecting the quality of life and independence of the its recipients and this is going unnoticed, forcing some into poverty, anxiety and mental health issues as a result of the assessment process.  

 

Life costs you £570 more on average a month if you're disabled.-Scope

Read more at https://www.scope.org.uk/media/disability-facts…

 

Libby's Eyes is a chance to start a conversation with wider society about the heartbreaking impact these cuts are having and using Libby to illustrate said consequences.  In supporting this play you are helping begin this conversation and be part of changing misconceptions about disability and benefits.  Libby's Eyes is step towards creating a conversation that could lead to real change.  This is a play that must be made now before more government changes are made that are detrimental to the disabled community.   

 

On raising only £3000 funds we will be able to cover these costs and put on the best run of this show at a crucial time due to its topical nature.  Its now or never!

All projects like this come with an element of risk which we are fully aware of.  To put your mind at rest, producer Georgie Morrell has already successfully raised two crowdfunding campaigns for two full Edinburgh runs, and has also sourced donation from private companies and pharmaceuticals organisations.  Additionally we already have been given £300 as part of the Tim Gebbels Bursary that nurtures disabled led work. We have approached several local companies and private donors who have supported A Poke in the Eye Productions work in the past.

 

Writer-Amy Bethan Evans

 

“Libby’s Eyes was written on Soho Theatre Writers’ Lab and while I’d had the idea of exploring “function” through robots and disabled people for a while, I was experiencing the PIP Appeals process at the time. I’d just moved to London having taken my initial assessment in Bristol and I was trying to assert all the things I could do in a new job while constantly reiterating the things I couldn’t do for the Appeals Process. It was emotionally draining and left me with very little self-worth. It was important to me that I had a visually impaired protagonist played by a visually impaired actor and that society rather than Libby’s impairment was portrayed as the barrier. I really feel like this play is the play I’ve always wanted to write.”

 

Originally from Bristol, Amy studied BA Drama and English at UWE and MA Playwriting at RHUL. She found her feet with Graeae Theatre Company working as a dramaturg before being part of the first year of Write to Play as well the Royal Court's National Writers' Group and RADA's Advances in Scriptwriting. Her monologue To Be My Eyes was commissioned for Theatre 503's The Words Are Coming Now in January and is being extended for Extant's slot at the Bloomsbury Festival in October.

 

Director-Spencer Charles Noll

 

“First and foremost, Libby’s Eyes is a great script! It takes current issues facing the disabled community and explores them with wit and humour. It experiments with theatrical conventions and re-invents how they can be used to make a play that is fully accessible without those accessible elements feeling like an add-on or afterthought. The play is both comedic medic and touching and does what great plays do best, guiding you to the questions that need to be asked rather than providing you with easy answers. I’d never read anything like it before and I am so excited that I am helping to bring it to life - It’s pioneering and relevant and entertaining and you absolutely do not want to miss it.”

 

Spencer trained with the National Youth Music Theatre and at The University of Kent, Canterbury and is an award winning actor and director (Michael Macliammoir Award for Lord Arthur’s Bed- Dublin International Gay Theatre Festival).

Directing credits include: Romeo and Juliet (New Wimbledon Studio), Too Far from the Light, by Katie Wimpenny (The Lion and Unicorn), Dan and Joel, by Barry McStay (Arcola Theatre),  Iron, by Tristian Bernays (Orange Tree Theatre), The Orange, by Katie Wimpenny (Landor Theatre) and Market Boy, by David Eldridge (Lost Theatre) Previous work includes Associate Director on Paul Miller's critically acclaimed production of Terence Rattigan's French Without Tears (Orange Tree Theatre and Tour)Associate Director to Rebecca Gatward on Sandi Toksvig's new play Silver Lining, (Rose Theatre Kingston and Tour) and Associate Director on the national tour of Rules for Living by Sam Holcroft, directed by Simon Godwin, (Royal and Derngate, Rose Kingston and tour)  all produced by English Touring Theatre.

 

--

Libby's Eyes is already supported by Extant Theatre Company, Tim Gebbels Bursary, Soho Theatre, RNIB and The Thomas Pocklington Trust.

If you are unable to help donate to Libby’s Eyes we would love if you could share this campaign via social media and the share button in the corner of the screen!

 

Would mean the world to us to have the word out there about our show and the important story it conveys.  Thank you. 

 

Follow Libby @LibbysEyes 

For any more info or to book tickets go to-https://www.bunkertheatre.com/whats-on/libbys-e...

RNIB are the premiere sight loss charity in the UK. You can discover more about their excellent work here - https://www.rnib.org.uk/

They can hear and see their voices and lives on stage.  The Bunker is WC access venue and we plan to add captioning, BSL interpreter, touch tours and audio description.  Rehearsal space
Rehearsal space in London is notoriously expensive and we need a safe space to rehearse Libby's Eyes in for our team to get the best results.   By contributing to this you are allowing disabled actors and writer to work in safe functional space that gives them the chance to create the best work they can without hindrances. Paying the team
Libby's Eyes has a cast of four actors and we believe in paying actors for their work. We want the best out of the team and production and paying actors is simply an obvious way of doing that.  It would set an example in the industry that actors should be paid. 
Cast and creative team fees are in line with Equity, ITC and industry standards. We are passionate about increasing the pressence of disabled creatives and performers in theatre, which can only be achieved through better access in terms of disablity and pay. By providing paid work and professional credits we hope to see more disabled performers playing roles of both disabled and non-disabled characters on stage. Why donate?
Libby's Eyes is more than play.  It is statement on the realities of living with disability in the 21st Century.  Benefit cuts are affecting the quality of life and independence of the its recipients and this is going unnoticed, forcing some into poverty, anxiety and mental health issues as a result of the assessment process.   Life costs you £570 more on average a month if you're disabled.-Scope
Read more at https://www.scope.org.uk/media/disability-facts… Libby's Eyes is a chance to start a conversation with wider society about the heartbreaking impact these cuts are having and using Libby to illustrate said consequences.  In supporting this play you are helping begin this conversation and be part of changing misconceptions about disability and benefits.  Libby's Eyes is step towards creating a conversation that could lead to real change.  This is a play that must be made now before more government changes are made that are detrimental to the disabled community.    On raising only £3000 funds we will be able to cover these costs and put on the best run of this show at a crucial time due to its topical nature.  Its now or never!
All projects like this come with an element of risk which we are fully aware of.  To put your mind at rest, producer Georgie Morrell has already successfully raised two crowdfunding campaigns for two full Edinburgh runs, and has also sourced donation from private companies and pharmaceuticals organisations.  Additionally we already have been given £300 as part of the Tim Gebbels Bursary that nurtures disabled led work. We have approached several local companies and private donors who have supported A Poke in the Eye Productions work in the past. Writer-Amy Bethan Evans “Libby’s Eyes was written on Soho Theatre Writers’ Lab and while I’d had the idea of exploring “function” through robots and disabled people for a while, I was experiencing the PIP Appeals process at the time. I’d just moved to London having taken my initial assessment in Bristol and I was trying to assert all the things I could do in a new job while constantly reiterating the things I couldn’t do for the Appeals Process. It was emotionally draining and left me with very little self-worth. It was important to me that I had a visually impaired protagonist played by a visually impaired actor and that society rather than Libby’s impairment was portrayed as the barrier. I really feel like this play is the play I’ve always wanted to write.” Originally from Bristol, Amy studied BA Drama and English at UWE and MA Playwriting at RHUL. She found her feet with Graeae Theatre Company working as a dramaturg before being part of the first year of Write to Play as well the Royal Court's National Writers' Group and RADA's Advances in Scriptwriting. Her monologue To Be My Eyes was commissioned for Theatre 503's The Words Are Coming Now in January and is being extended for Extant's slot at the Bloomsbury Festival in October. Director-Spencer Charles Noll “First and foremost, Libby’s Eyes is a great script! It takes current issues facing the disabled community and explores them with wit and humour. It experiments with theatrical conventions and re-invents how they can be used to make a play that is fully accessible without those accessible elements feeling like an add-on or afterthought. The play is both comedic medic and touching and does what great plays do best, guiding you to the questions that need to be asked rather than providing you with easy answers. I’d never read anything like it before and I am so excited that I am helping to bring it to life - It’s pioneering and relevant and entertaining and you absolutely do not want to miss it.” Spencer trained with the National Youth Music Theatre and at The University of Kent, Canterbury and is an award winning actor and director (Michael Macliammoir Award for Lord Arthur’s Bed- Dublin International Gay Theatre Festival).
Directing credits include: Romeo and Juliet (New Wimbledon Studio), Too Far from the Light, by Katie Wimpenny (The Lion and Unicorn), Dan and Joel, by Barry McStay (Arcola Theatre),  Iron, by Tristian Bernays (Orange Tree Theatre), The Orange, by Katie Wimpenny (Landor Theatre) and Market Boy, by David Eldridge (Lost Theatre) Previous work includes Associate Director on Paul Miller's critically acclaimed production of Terence Rattigan's French Without Tears (Orange Tree Theatre and Tour)Associate Director to Rebecca Gatward on Sandi Toksvig's new play Silver Lining, (Rose Theatre Kingston and Tour) and Associate Director on the national tour of Rules for Living by Sam Holcroft, directed by Simon Godwin, (Royal and Derngate, Rose Kingston and tour)  all produced by English Touring Theatre. --
Libby's Eyes is already supported by Extant Theatre Company, Tim Gebbels Bursary, Soho Theatre, RNIB and The Thomas Pocklington Trust.
If you are unable to help donate to Libby’s Eyes we would love if you could share this campaign via social media and the share button in the corner of the screen! Would mean the world to us to have the word out there about our show and the important story it conveys.  Thank you. 
 
Follow Libby @LibbysEyes 
For any more info or to book tickets go to-https://www.bunkertheatre.com/whats-on/libbys-e...
RNIB are the premiere sight loss charity in the UK. You can discover more about their excellent work here - https://www.rnib.org.uk/

story:
Artist's Statement

Hi, I’m Victor Acevedo. I’ve been a visual artist since 1977 and a digital artist since 1983. Many of you have known me for a long time -- and some of you have met me more recently in the Real-World or on Social Media.

I want to tell you about my IndieGoGo Campaign. I am launching it to raise the funds to self-publish a book.

The book will be called Acevedo in Context. It will be a 40-year Art career retrospective; an illustrated chronology about my life and art - with an emphasis on the Art.

It will contain about 250 pages and include many documentary photographs and over 150 reproductions of my paintings, drawings and prints. It will also address my recent ‘visual music’ video work. It will include essays by two well-known art writers, who are also historians. Their names will be revealed after the campaign wraps and the commission agreements are signed.

The book will cover my work in Traditional media; painting & drawing, starting in 1977 and then into Digital media from 1983, leading up to the present.

The book is called Acevedo in Context because it’s not just about me. It is also about the milieu from where I’ve have come;  my early influences and the community around the early digital art movement as it continued to grow and evolve at the dawn of personal computing.

It has been said that my artwork reflects that time; the transition from the 20th century into the 21st. That unique ‘moment’ when our collective cybernetic future was being born.

Acevedo in Context will be published as an eBook and if we raise enough money, it will also be issued as limited-edition soft-cover Print Book.

I hope to raise $25,000 dollars, which will fund every aspect of the project from beginning to end.  Some-of-which will include:

• Converting the original Manuscript to eBook format, for both the iBook and Kindle.

• Executing the first press run for the hardcopy Print Book.

• Commissioning the 2 writers to write the essays.

• Hiring an editor to double-check the copy & formatting and to sculpt the final flow of the book.

• Cover the fees for 3rd party IP (intellectual property) which will be important for telling the story in its complete form.

These are just some of the main expenses. To see the complete list, please check out the itemized budget which is posted below.

We’ve got a good solid plan and strategy for Success!

We have a lot of great perks at every donation level. Please check them out here on the Campaign page.

I hope that you will join-me in this venture and lend your support with a donation-to-the-project. Of-course donations at any level will be helpful toward reaching the funding goal. And who knows, with your help maybe we can even surpass it!


As well as donating monetarily, I would like to ask you to help out by spreading the word to your friends. Please share this IndieGoGo-campaign with those who might want to be part of it. Please spread the word by email and sharing on your favorite Social Media. For example, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc.

I really need your help to make this campaign go viral! The truth is, it is imperative to get the word out beyond my own mailing list!

Thank you all in advance, for any and all support that you can bring! Cheers! - Victor
 

The Backstory

I always hoped that someone would come along and want to write a book about my art. Or perhaps i would submit a book proposal to a major art house publisher and wait for their approval. Many years went by and these things never happened.

However as communication technology and social media have evolved remarkably in the last 15 years, there are now many new options to bring a project such as this into the world.

This book publishing project is based on the interplay and coordination of 3 key infra-structural elements. They are:  crowdsource fundraising platforms (such as IndieGoGo) via the internet: facilitated by email and social media; eBook technologies which allow a digital book to be published and read easily and inexpensively on mobile devices and computers. And finally print-on-demand (POD) technologies for publishing and distribution:  POD is new eco-system to produce a real tangible hardcopy book that you can hold in your hands; turn the pages, have that special experience. These things really didn’t co-exist with such turn-key facility until relatively recently.
 

The Plan

Production:

Once the funds are raised, the commissioned essays will be ‘green lit’ and begun. Simultaneous to this work, all the images and other written material will be formatted in a master inDesign manuscript file. In fact, i have already started collecting together and organizing all this material. You can get a glimpse of this in the video above.

Once the essays are added and the document’s format is fine-tuned. It will be outsourced to two ebook converters. One for iBook format (Apple platform) and one for (Amazon) Kindle which are the 2 formats with the widest distribution channels.

Apart from the eBooks, the first edition of Acevedo in Context will also be issued  as a Print book. The quantity for all 3 formats of the first edition will be 3000 each. The Print book edition will be printed gradually on a print-on-demand (POD) basis 25–100 a time, unless demand warrants larger quantities. I plan to use the POD company called Bookbaby. The print book will be in soft cover and its trim size will be 8.5x11" landscape. The first edition eBooks will be distributed online, on demand, one-at-a-time, as needed, up to 3000 copies in each format.

Distribution:

The first edition of Acevedo in Context as an iBook will be uploaded to the Apple iBooks store.

The first edition of Acevedo in Context in Kindle format will be uploaded to Amazon Books

The first hardcopy book print run of Acevedo in Context will be made available for sale online through Amazon Books.

If all goes well these will be issued by December 2018.

Promotion: Sales and Marketing Efforts:

After the book published, i will be spending as much time as possible, promoting the book in person and online in an all-out grass-roots DIY campaign. If the total funding goal is met I will be able to retain a small PR Firm to help me promote the book for a short time in order to  maximize and expand its audience.
 

Where your donations will go:

Your contributions are absolutely vital to the execution of this project. We hope to raise  $25,000 USD through this campaign.

Here is the current projected budget:

$4500 Two critical art historical essays $2250 each

$2500 Editor copy + line

$1000 ebook conversion to MOBI (kindle)

$1000 ebook conversion to ePUB (iBook)

$3000 First Print book press run toward complete the Limited edition quantity.

$_295 ISBN numbers and barcodes 10 + 5 barcodes. Each published format of the book will need a unique ISBN number. This is the most economical way to buy ISBNs; the extra ones will not go to waste, they can be used for a future 2nd edition of the book in each format.

$_550 Copyright registration book itself plus 9 sets of images registered separately

$4000 IP rights permission to reproduce work: Escher, Dali, Picasso, Fuller, others (these 3rd party images will greatly enhance the authority and power of the narrative.)

$3355 To retain a PR Firm for a short time to help promote the book.

$1500 Project manager honorarium.

$1000  Production for the Digital Print perks in all sizes:  printing, packaging and shipping fees (projected)

$_750  Credit card charges 3% of total of all money raised = 3% of $25000

$_300 Credit card projected 30¢/transaction (30¢ x 1000 projected transactions)

$1250 IndieGoGo platform fee 5% of $25000

$25,000

 

Plan B strategy – funding short fall

As you can see, the budget is well thought out and it will indeed cover the costs of the entire project and the cost of the campaign itself. With your help we will raise the full amount required to produce the book in its deluxe form on 3 platforms. The campaign is in flex-funding mode, so whatever amount that is raised I will put toward the project. However, should we fall short of the total target goal, I will adjust the project’s specifications accordingly. In any case, i plan to still issue an eBook; however, one that the raised funds can support. It will most likely be a Kindle eBook. By the way Kindle (mobi) format ebooks can be read on Mac or PCs on IOS and Android tablet Devices, you just need to download the Kindle app to do so.
 

Plan C Strategy – exceeding our initial Goal!

Given the range of Donation Levels and Perks, and if we all help to share and endorse the Acevedo in Context IndieGoiGo Campaign, there's a good chance that together we will reach the target Goal, and possibly even exceed it!

If that is the case, it will be great for all of us! Depending on how much extra money we raise, i will look seriously into publishing the first print edition in Hard cover and/or increasing the quantity of the first Softcover print run.

 

Artist’s Short Biography

Victor Acevedo is an artist best known for his digital work involving printmaking and photography. However, since 2007 his primary focus has been working with video and producing visual music works. As an ongoing practice, selected still images from the videos are made available as archival signed limited edition prints.

Acevedo is considered a desktop computer art pioneer as he was an early adopter of pre-Windows personal computer (PC) software to create fine art, in the early 1980s. He now works primarily on the Apple Macintosh platform.

The arc of Acevedo’s career is noteworthy in that it begins in his student phase in 1977 with traditional (analog) media painting and drawing and then shifts starting in 1983 over a three year period to exclusively digital media.

The 3 main periods of Victor Acevedo’s work to date are as follows:

1977- 87: Analog Art: traditional media, painting, drawing & film

1983 to 2007: Digital Art: archival inkjet and photo prints

2007 to present: Visual Music: Digital Video and Digital Prints

Acevedo grew up in Los Angeles, California and attended Art Center College of Design in Pasadena 1979-81.

In early 1995 Victor moved to New York City and became a digital artist in residence in the BFA Computer Art Department at the School of Visual Arts. He began teaching there in 1997 and moved to the Masters level (MFA) program three years later.

In 1996 he created one of his most well know images called The Lacemaker, which he named after the same-titled painting by Johannes Vermeer (1665). This is the image he has chosen for the cover of his book, Acevedo in Context.

Acevedo is now based in Los Angeles having returned to his hometown in the Spring of 2009.

After settling back into LA life, he explored the application of his motion graphic work to live-mix video projection for electronic dance music events, primarily in night club settings. In doing so, he combined his interest in contemporary Electronic Bass music with concepts in Digital Cinema and Synergetic Geometry. His music video work and live  visual (VJ) performances were informed by a synthesis of these traditions, disciplines, phenomenologies.

Since 2014, Acevedo has been exploring the realm of pure abstraction to a greater degree. Thus, establishing a new body of work in parallel to that which addresses figurative subjects.

In late 2015, slipping easily back into the fine-art community, he began showing fairly regularly at the Los Angeles Center for Digital Art (LACDA) in Downtown Los Angeles. Overall, he has shown his work in well over 100 group and solo art exhibitions since 1982.

Acevedo’s work has been featured in several recent art history books. Highlighting a few of them: Acevedo’s image called 4D Memory Cluster was reproduced in the book called “Moving Innovation: A History of Computer Animation” (Tom Sito, MIT Press, 2013); The Acevedo image called Eric in Orense is reproduced in the book called, “Art of the Digital Age”, (edited by Bruce Wands Thames and Hudson, 2006)  This image was also featured in the book’s UK online promotional announcements.

"Art of the Digital Age" has been described as “The first major illustrated survey of this exciting, new, and experimental field”. Acevedo’s work was discussed at some length in the important and influential book called “From Technological to Virtual Art”, written by art historian Frank Popper, (MIT Press 2007).

His image called Springside Cynthesis and a descriptive blurb about his work was included in the books called "Digital Art" (Ullmann/Tandem, 2009) and “The World of Digital Art” (h.f.Ullman, 2010) Both are edited by the well-known digital art authority and gallerist, Wolf Lieser. He founded The Digital Art Museum (DAM) Gallery in 1998. It is now located in Berlin.

A self-penned article and several Acevedo images were included in the book and accompanying CD called “Escher’s Legacy: A Centennial Celebration” (Doris Schattschneider and Michelle Emmer eds., Springer-Verlag 2002)

As of 2017 he has been slowly venturing into Virtual Reality (VR) working and studying with the well-known and brilliant young underground film director, Michael Woods.

story:
Margery’s campaign is to raise funds for:

1. Her plane ticket and airport shuttles $1000

2. Subsistence for the whole month of August – food, gas, etc. $1000

3. art supplies $500

Unique perks: 

At the $100 level you will receive a small (7”x5” approx.) silverpoint drawing by Margery Theroux. 10 available

At the $250 level you will receive a medium sized (11”x14”) drawing by Margery Theroux. 4 available.

At the $500 level, you will receive a painting on canvas by Margery Theroux!

If we don’t reach the entire goal, any money raised will help Margery pay for these very real expenses of the residency. We thank you for your donations, your well wishes and for spreading the word! Share on FB, Twitter, and by using Indiegogo share tools.  Remember, by donating you are helping an artist to make art.
