At the $250 level you will receive a medium sized (11”x14”) drawing by Margery Theroux. 4 available.
At the $500 level, you will receive a painting on canvas by Margery Theroux!
If we don’t reach the entire goal, any money raised will help Margery pay for these very real expenses of the residency. We thank you for your donations, your well wishes and for spreading the word! Share on FB, Twitter, and by using Indiegogo share tools.  Remember, by donating you are helping an artist to make art.

story:
Dreamscape Series II: Painting the South of France

My name is Lilo Jones and I am a painter based in New York City. One year ago I created this Dreamscape Series in honor of my leading muse, the country of France. Through study and exposure to so many aspects of French culture, I have developed and deepened as an artist, steeped in the inspiration from all I have experienced under its influence. This series is my humble attempt at paying homage to this profound source, to which I owe so much.

As a Geffen Records recording artist and creative director of surreal theatre troupes Toujours L'Amour and Theatre Marvelosa, I have cultivated a visual world that is a pastiche of performance art, beloved works of literature & film, traveling adventures, observations from everyday life and compelling events in history.

Employing a wide array of mediums, I paint dreamworlds that seek to engage and transport. My musical training has deeply influenced my painting practice, and I tap into the language of music as a way to embrace the poetry of light and space. 

What I am doing and why I need your support

Having completed the first part of my  Dreamscape painting series, "Forever Paris," (focused on Paris and currently showing at Manhattan's Le Midi), I am now preparing to launch production of phase 2 of the series, entitled "South" based entirely on imagery found in The South of France.

The South of France is a magical place where life slips into a lower gear and scenes slide by in soft focus: drowsy villages with quaint cafes and winding cobbled alleyways. . .  cool forests stuffed with truffle oaks . . .  lavender, poppy and sunflower fields nestled within orchards of lemon and mandarin . . . craggy coastlines dotted with pastel houses and their shutters of Mediterranean blue. The inspiration for visual artists there is astounding; utterly limitless, which is why it has attracted so many painters throughout time.

What your support will cover

My goal is to raise $8,000 to cover all expenses for this project. This money will go directly towards all art supplies/materials, shipping, photography and transportation. The length of this Indiegogo campaign is 60 days, which means I have until September 5 to reach my fund raising goal.

The Perks

There are a variety of levels of support that are offered online; from $10 to $1,000. I know that some of you might be uncomfortable contributing online, please let me know and I can provide you with an alternative method of contributing.

Risks & Challenges

There are no risks or complications I can think of except of course those unexpected “acts of God” that sometime get in the way of best made plans.

Please know how much I appreciate your contribution/purchase. It validates my efforts and my work. Thank you.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you can contribute or not, I thank you for your support. You can help further by sharing the link to this campaign with your friends on Facebook or Instagram. Twitter me to the ends of the twitter universe or tell someone by text or word of mouth. You can also email this campaign to friends and family who you think might be interested in contributing and collecting my work. Spreading the word is equally as effective as donating and Indiegogo lets you SHARE from right here….!

For more of my work, you may visit my website at www.LiloJones.com

Thank you.

Please see the gallery beneath my video at the top of this page for a peek at some of my Paris paintings from part 1 of the Dreamscape series to let you get a feel for my work. Below is a bit of the story behind that collection. 

Dreamscape Series - Part 1    "Forever Paris"      The Background 

Inhabiting the neighborhoods of Montmartre and Montparnasse, Paris’ first bohemians created a wild-hearted nirvana where they could behave as they chose. Potent and provocative, that mecca was a home for the exotic, the passionate and the free. In flamboyant, often debauched cafes, these visionaries would gather, masterminding art movements that profoundly rocked world culture.

Inspired by the timeless layers of eye-popping Boho art posters papered on tattered walls throughout Paris to this day, I created a series of 15 large-scale paintings to pay tribute to the boundless reach of the bohemian spirit.

 

PRESS:

Lilo Jones "Forever Paris" at Le Midi

“An explosion of texture and color, artist Lilo Jones summons dreams onto canvas.  Dipping her brush in champagne, she brings French whimsy to Manhattan’s Le Midi in a show entitled, "Forever Paris." Inspired by tattered posters papered onto old stone walls throughout The City of Light, she taps into the spirit of joie de vivre that pulses throughout the bohemian world of Montmartre, Montparnasse and French cabaret.”    

- Boggs Krawcheck | Letters to Vollard, | May 2017

story:
In Short

My name is Kristin Taylor. I am the founder of OnPointe.org which grew out of a love for dance and music. Inspired by a passion for the art; I want to create positive images for the black community to look at. I think it is so important to see possibilities while dreaming about the future. I am so excited to have a hand in creating that for black girls.

Contributors can help OnPointe.org spread achieve a gallery full of images accessible in-person and online of Black Ballerinas in leading roles such as Juliette and the Firebird. By contributing to the campaign, not only are you giving young black dancers and children role models to look up to; you are also propelling the career of a black dancer by giving them a platform to share their talent and passion. Dance has saved these ballet dancers; you're helping to save more dancers.

We will use the funds raised from the gallery and the production to fund the salary of a dance teacher to provide dance classes for underprivileged students in the Charlotte, NC area.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $60,000 to help fund the cost of production, payment for our dancers and photographers, printing costs for the gallery displays.

We are really excited to highlight our dancers with custom exclusively printed signed posters of our dancers, t-shirts, black ballerina barbie dolls and VIP meet and greet tickets to the event on August 25th, 2018.

If we do not reach our entire goal; we will be scaling back the photo and video shoots and donating the funds directly to Zeal For Life Dance Company to fund the salary of one of their teachers to teach underprivileged students for free.

The Impact

You will make a difference:

The On Pointe Perks are exclusives that highlight these young dancers are just for you and the other contributors to our Indiegogo campaign. Your contribution will go to aid up to 40 young underprivileged children starting this fall in learning how to dance for free.

Giving back to children has been a longtime initiative of our Founder's company, Kristin Taylor Events. As a successful fundraiser for the Mint Museum's Children's Tour funds through the Young Affiliates of the Mint for three years in a row.

As the process goes along, you can stay up to date by staying in the know through our Indiegogo campaign and our email list.

 

Risks & Challenges

Spreading the word is one of the biggest challenges that we face. When trying to break the ceiling; awareness is the first step to making a change.

We are planning to help overcome that challenge by partnering with influencers and personalities that can spread the word. We are also hoping that contributors and supporters like yourself will help us out. There's nothing like the power of word of mouth to help a cause.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us make some noise for On Pointe! Share it on Instagram, Facebook, Twitter and the blogs! Tell your friends! There are easy tools in Indiegogo that you can use to make it super easy!!

Thank you so much for your help!!!

story:
Resumen

Hello, my name is Ksenia. I´m a museologist, designer and artist. Currently
I´m living in Madrid and volunteering at "The Tarot Museum" (Museo Del Tarot in spanish).

This is a very nice private museum where you can find a lot of different decks from all over the world. The idea to create a tarot deck dedicated to this beautiful city was born in the  museum.

Many tarot decks have been created in honor of different cities among which we know  "The Tarot of Paris ","The Tarot of Prague", etc.  So why don´t we create a deck which would represent the spirit of Madrid?  One deck from Madrid had already existed , it´s beautiful and unique but  it has only 22  major arcana cards and they are quite dark and don´t show  vibrant colors of sunny Madrid. Wheares the deck "The Tarot of Madrid" consists of 78 cards, being a full deck with major and minor arcana.  In our project the main goal was to create cards that would tell us the history of the city and not to loose the essence of the cards. A talented artist from Madrid, Carlos Pumariega collaborated in the project of The Museum Of Tarot, Madrid. Carlos, being madridian, could perfectly reflect the mood of the city and the bright colors he uses transmit a lively rhythm of Madrid.

- > turn on english subtitles

In 1997 Ricardo Salas, the founder of the Tarot Museum held in his hands his first Tarot deck, which opened the world of Cartomancy for him. That first contact with the tarot cards led him to start a search for original and unique pieces and become a collector.

 (turn on english subtitels)

All the editions and objects related to tarot presented in the museum Ricardo Salas obtained by exchanging them with collectors, acquisitions in auctions and donations from individuals, magicians, or Tarot experts.

For many years Ricardo has been keeping the idea of creating a deck of cards dedicated to the city of Madrid, each of which would tell us the story of its historical places, buildings and monuments.     

Here you can see the idea of one of the cards, described by the artist himself:

- > turn on english subtitles

The Project

Funding for this project would provide us a means to print the full 78 card deck "The Tarot of Madrid" in the edition of 997 decks, work with the artist, graphic designer to make the backside as well as the boxes and short descriptions of the cards at an affordable cost without impacting the quality of production.

The cards will be 7,5 cm x 11 cm, printed on 350 gsm card stock with golden edge.

Costs of production:

Printing of 997 high quality Tarot decks = 12961 Euro

Making high quality packs = 3*997 = 2991 Euro

 Artists´ design work= 5000 Euro

Here you can see the process of making some of the cards:

 
Risks & Challenges
 
The projects has been completed, all the card images have already been painted and ideas realized. The only missing thing is graphic design of the backside of the cards as well as the box. We are planning to have it done within 2 months. And after that we will be ready to print the decks. This will take 3-4 weeks. Then we will resume the process of shipping it out to you. That is the most risk that you will take! 
 
Artistic works made by a well-known artist greatly increases the value of the project for us. This is another reason why we want this idea to see the world and be rewarded. With everything said above we can admit that the project turned out to be more expensive than it had been expected.  This is why we  decided to reach for funding with hope to make it work out.
 
We are fully dedicated to getting this project off the ground and releasing the deck by the 11th of September, 2018. If for some reason we don´t get full funding, we will print fewer number of decks and continue looking for other ways of funding. 
 
We assure that this project perks will be created and shipped on time as promised.
 

Other ways you can help

Not all of you need  a tarot deck or are into decks, but love to support other artists, that is why we provided the €5 base level of support. But of course, we will be happy if you can contribute more or choose one of the perks!

We would really appreciate it if you helped us spread the word. If you are on a Facebook group for other Tarot lovers, maybe you can tell others about it sharing this campaign. You just need to click on the icons at the top of the page to instantly share. Or send a message to your friends you know who could be interested in  something like this or you can just make a present for you friends. 

If you find this project interesting, please leave a comment to let us know what you think about this idea.  Thank you!

If there's anything else you need or want to ask us about, feel free to email me artpromoter@museodeltarot.com.

Not all of you need  a tarot deck or are into decks, but love to support other artists, that is why we provided the €5 base level of support. But of course, we will be happy if you can contribute more or choose one of the perks!
We would really appreciate it if you helped us spread the word. If you are on a Facebook group for other Tarot lovers, maybe you can tell others about it sharing this campaign. You just need to click on the icons at the top of the page to instantly share. Or send a message to your friends you know who could be interested in  something like this or you can just make a present for you friends. 
If you find this project interesting, please leave a comment to let us know what you think about this idea.  Thank you!

story:
Don Kennell & Lisa Adler have been art collaborators for many years. DKLA Design was incorporated in 2015. Don makes design drawings and leads the fabrication crew. Lisa focuses on community engagement. We make animals monumental to highlight their heroic qualities.

 

Polar bears are on the front lines of climate change and are uniquely positioned to bring the arctic into human awareness.

If the Arctic disappears and polar bears lose their habitat, then we will all live in a world without wild polar bears. That feels like the worst kind of failure of the human imagination.

This public artwork will capture peoples imagination and the aspiring scope of the project is to inspire the audience to save polar bears.

 

At night, the artwork will have images projected that shows scenes of melting ice & ocean habitat.

 

Our Plan

Our plan is to travel this message around the country to invigorate the conversation about climate change. A 36 foot polar bear is impossible to ignore. This icon will rally people together with common concerns to share a common experience. It will bring more people on board. We will partner with local groups where the sculpture is installed to increase awareness of practical solutions for reducing carbon footprint.

​

We have already raised $75,000 from investors and from Burning Man. The sculpture will debut at Black Rock City in August 2018. And then the polar bear will continue its search for allies.

We need $50,000 to complete the project. These funds will be used to purchase projectors for showing high-impact content on the sculpture at night. The funds will also be used to create professional 3D digital images from real life footage of icebergs cracking, underwater environments, weather, and other natural and human environments. We will also use the funds to add audio to these images to increase the artwork's emotional power.

Our message is that all life on the planet is interconnected. What happens to polar bears affects humans. This is a message that must be heard now.

Production on the polar bear has begun. Get in on the ground floor.

 

Our designs invite the view to develop a relationship with the animal.

 

We have lots of experience designing & fabricating monumental animals from car hoods.

 

The sculptures include a structural steel armature. Car hoods are bolted on with original factory paint.

In the shop this week, we are getting the polar bear feet off the ground.

 

Next steps is to bolt on our white car hoods onto the legs of the polar bear.

story:
100 Pictures to get Ellie to Tisch

I remember so clearly sitting at my job at the Putt Putt Fun Center last October. I was working on a set design for Newsies to take to the Virginia Theatre Association Drama Production competition. I was running the laser tag arena that day, and armed with colored pencils, scale rulers, and graph paper, I was able to create an entire set design for this show by slowly upping the time limits on the arena, minute by minute, just enough so that my boss wouldn’t notice and get me in trouble, but giving me more time between each game to work. At the end of that day kids were getting twenty-five minute sessions of laser tag and my design and model ended up winning me 3rd place in the state.

Who is Ellie Matthews?

I am currently a junior at Heritage High School and I also attend the Central Virginia Governor’s School for Science and Technology. I play on my school’s varsity soccer team as well as participating heavily in our school’s theatre program all while working 20+ hours a week as a Lifeguard at the YMCA and keeping up my 4.5 GPA. I have been drawing and creating things my entire life, it’s what I do best, it’s what I do constantly. Art and performing are the reasons I wake up in the morning and Theatre Production Design is the perfect combination of my love of both.  Last week I was accepted into the Tisch Summer High School Program at New York University. It is a highly competitive program with less than a quarter of the applicants granted admission. Waking up to the email saying I was accepted is one of the thrills of my life.

And the program?

The program itself is a month long on-campus intensive in their Theatre Production Studio where I’d be taking classes on everything from set design to painting with the best in the business. At the end of the program I would leave the school to start my senior year in high school with almost a semester’s worth of conservatory style college credit from NYU. 

But here’s the thing:  Tisch is not cheap and I need to raise a lot of money to make this work.  I am not asking for donations (although if you would like to give me a straight donation that would be amazing! I would totally love that and gladly accept it!)  I am a worker.  I know I drive my parents crazy with it but since I was fifteen I have always had a job.  Snack shack at the pool, Putt Putt, lifeguarding, I have always wanted to pay my way in life and that is no different now.  

Drawing for Dollars

My goal is to draw 100 pictures.  Each donation of $50 and above will get you one of these drawings and will help me make another dent in the amount of money I need to get to Tisch.  I have a lot of different options and styles that you can check out in the Perks section.  And if you have any questions about the specifics of the drawings please email me at EllieDraws100Pictures@gmail.com and I’ll do my best to answer them. Each drawing will be numbered as a reminder that you were a part of this process.

I work as hard as possible at everything in front of me and I know that Tisch will be an incredible opportunity for me and my future. Can I draw you something to help me get there?
story_txt: 100 Pictures to get Ellie to TischI remember so clearly sitting at my job at the Putt Putt Fun Center last October. I was working on a set design for Newsies to take to the Virginia Theatre Association Drama Production competition. I was running the laser tag arena that day, and armed with colored pencils, scale rulers, and graph paper, I was able to create an entire set design for this show by slowly upping the time limits on the arena, minute by minute, just enough so that my boss wouldn’t notice and get me in trouble, but giving me more time between each game to work. At the end of that day kids were getting twenty-five minute sessions of laser tag and my design and model ended up winning me 3rd place in the state.Who is Ellie Matthews?I am currently a junior at Heritage High School and I also attend the Central Virginia Governor’s School for Science and Technology. I play on my school’s varsity soccer team as well as participating heavily in our school’s theatre program all while working 20+ hours a week as a Lifeguard at the YMCA and keeping up my 4.5 GPA. I have been drawing and creating things my entire life, it’s what I do best, it’s what I do constantly. Art and performing are the reasons I wake up in the morning and Theatre Production Design is the perfect combination of my love of both.  Last week I was accepted into the Tisch Summer High School Program at New York University. It is a highly competitive program with less than a quarter of the applicants granted admission. Waking up to the email saying I was accepted is one of the thrills of my life.And the program?The program itself is a month long on-campus intensive in their Theatre Production Studio where I’d be taking classes on everything from set design to painting with the best in the business. At the end of the program I would leave the school to start my senior year in high school with almost a semester’s worth of conservatory style college credit from NYU. But here’s the thing:  Tisch is not cheap and I need to raise a lot of money to make this work.  I am not asking for donations (although if you would like to give me a straight donation that would be amazing! I would totally love that and gladly accept it!)  I am a worker.  I know I drive my parents crazy with it but since I was fifteen I have always had a job.  Snack shack at the pool, Putt Putt, lifeguarding, I have always wanted to pay my way in life and that is no different now.  Drawing for DollarsMy goal is to draw 100 pictures.  Each donation of $50 and above will get you one of these drawings and will help me make another dent in the amount of money I need to get to Tisch.  I have a lot of different options and styles that you can check out in the Perks section.  And if you have any questions about the specifics of the drawings please email me at EllieDraws100Pictures@gmail.com and I’ll do my best to answer them. Each drawing will be numbered as a reminder that you were a part of this process.I work as hard as possible at everything in front of me and I know that Tisch will be an incredible opportunity for me and my future. Can I draw you something to help me get there?

story:
Short Summary

R Creative Collective (RCC) is a multi-media arts movement founded with the mission of creating space and providing creative outlets for those in search of well-being, growth, and community through creative expression.

For the past year and a half, we have been a mobile team, doing creative expression outreach with local non-profits and recovery organizations. We have served around 400  individuals through our community partnerships with The Relatives, Charlotte Rescue Mission, The Blanchard Institute, and Fellowship Hall; not to mention the numerous individuals that we have encountered at pop-up and community events.

We have provided 90% of our services to the community free of charge and would like to be able to continue providing our services at little to no cost for our charitable community partners through the aid of sponsorship and donations.

We have recently obtained two spaces in a small business incubator called Area 15 located near Uptown Charlotte. R Studio Gallery will open soon as a community gallery and workshop space where we host classes, workshops, and feature local artist’s collections on a rotating basis. The other space is The Rise Boutique, where we work with local business vendors and artisans as a storefront for their products sold on a commission basis, all of the proceeds from these ventures go to supporting our outreach programs.

We are looking to raise $8-10k to cover startup operations costs for our growing organization, including rent, insurance, supplies and equipment. We have set a modest goal of raising a portion of that through this campaign. In exchange, we are offering a variety of great perks. Your support will make a difference for so many and help our organizations keep its doors open so that we can continue to serve our community in extraordinary ways! 

If you are interested in becoming a larger long-term sponsor, please contact us at: info@rcreatives.org 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Make sure you're on our email list to hear about events and stay updated on the boutique and gallery. Please also spread the word to friends and family! 
  • In NC or SC? Bring a regular or one-time workshop to your workplace or organization.
    • Partners will be featured on the website and social media
    • Sliding scale and donation-based pricing options are available.
    • Email us at info@rcreatives.org to talk about the possibilities.
  • Share this campaign! 
  • Follow us on Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook @RCreatives1 on all platforms

The Impact

By providing space and workshops focused on encouraging the creative spirit in all of us, we believe that we can be a part of making a change in individuals and communities. We do this by empowering them to use their positive and inspired minds to transform the adverse obstacles that stand before them.

Our variety of creative expression workshops are connecting individuals to an innovative healing process that leads to a more enhanced self-awareness, increased self-confidence, and a strong sense of self-worth that builds resiliency. This has an invaluable effect on the individual and is of great benefit to our community at large. 

Risks & Challenges

One of our biggest goals is to keep these workshops affordable and accessible to those in need. We offer regular workshops to our community partners at recovery and at-risk youth centers 100% free of charge. In order to provide quality workshops with quality materials and facilitators, we must depend on donations and sponsors like you to help us continue our work. 

We carry this same belief in affordability and accessibility to our public community workshops because people outside or recovery centers and programs also need access to affordable creative outlets; everyone should have access to fun creative outlets, regardless of economic and health circumstances.  We operate our community workshops with a Pay What You Can (PWYC) style alongside a suggested donation price. We offer classes at an average of $15 (USD), which when compared to similar classes offered for $25-$35 (USD). In our classes participants get the same quality experiences they would get elsewhere and save money, while also helping someone else enjoy a class and community they may have otherwise not been able to attend.

The suggested donation amount goes directly to operation cost of the class and amounts made over the class costs, go towards our outreach programs. No one gets paid from these funds. 

We rely heavily on facilitators, many of which offer these same classes at higher prices elsewhere, volunteering their time because they believe in our mission to be able to keep the costs low. Donations made over the suggested amount are welcome and are used to help cover the costs of other guests who can’t afford the fee, therefore, keeping our classes truly accessible to all. 

The challenge that we face with this model is, unfortunately, the same that every PWYC business faces; when people don't pay what they can or choose to not to participate with the idea that the product is not as good as a class with a higher price. As an organization, we must absorb those losses and find alternative means of funding and support, so that we can stay true to our goal of providing a wide range of quality inclusive workshops that build up individuals and communities.

story:
Support SIRIUS and contribute to the production of art and the creation of community!

This is our first-ever online fundraising endeavour, an initiative necessarily related to the negative impact of the pandemic in the arts sector; COVID-19 has significantly mitigated our capacity to interact with the public, resulting in a major reduction of income streams. The arts sector is still facing unprecedented challenges, and thus any and all support is of utmost importance to guarantee the survival of artists and organisations.

Two Irish, Cork-county based artists with whom we have a special relationship, Marie Brett and Fiona Kelly, have created powerful, poetic and timely works in special limited editions as gifts for donors in primary categories.

This year, we have remained active while our doors were shut, setting up online programmes and preparing and/or delivering exhibitions and events both on site and offsite. We have also used this unusual operating context to reinvent ourselves: we are in the process of recalibrating our vision around civic practice and engagement to make us a more accessible, equal, diverse and inclusive institution.

We want to continue on this course next year, as we believe that the work that we want to do – topical and experimental, political and local, and with beneficial outcomes for society – is more urgent than ever. For this, we need your support!

story:
Festival Rekonstrukcija - a short history

Festival Rekonstrukcija was founded in 2018, by two street enthusiasts (Jana Danilovic & Tamara Markovic) who organized numerous other exhibitions, talks and workshops in order to improve the local status of the street art - an art which belongs to everyone.
The next reasonable step was to organize the festival, so the Festival Rekonstrukcija was born. 

This year, we are a small team of guerilla (street) artists, designers, and photographers, and we are trying to revitalize yet another part of our hometown.

After last year's success with the first edition of the festival, in one of the most iconic abandoned buildings in Belgrade city center, this year we are moving festival where it belongs, right on the streets of our capital!

 


We need your support!

 

Last year festival in numbers:

- 3,000+ visitors in 2 days of the festival 
- 40+ local artists participated, and during the festival they made:
- 13 murals and 3 art installations
- 6 educational/art workshops were held
- 20+ participants on design/eco market
- 2 nights of a music program

 

This year we need:

This year edition hopefully will be even bigger, and since we are a non-profit organization made of united artists, who are giving their best to make a difference, we need any kind of help and support in order to provide an enjoyable experience for all participants, as well as for all of the local citizens who will be part of our festival. 

We plan to have more than:

- 50 international and local street-artists (painters, sculptors, photographers, videographers, etc)
- music program for 3 days
- free workshops for young and old:)
- movie projections
- 5 photography exhibitions
- public talks and open discussions
- 3 surprise exhibitions
- design market
- street games
+much more interesting content!

 

Why is Rekonstrukcija important?

Rekonstrukcija celebrates art on the streets!

We are inviting established artists from various fields of visual arts, to join their forces with fresh ideas and energy of new and emerging talents, in order to transform the streets in art galleries accessible to everyone! 

Rekonstrukcija wants to communicate through street-art and other art forms on the street with everybody. From passionate art enthusiasts to accidental passers-by, we invite everyone to take part, and make their city a more beautiful and colorful place!  

All of the festival programs will be held on the streets and will be completely free of charge and accessible to anyone interested! 

 


Rekonstrukcija moves art from galleries and brings it where it should be, among the people!

story:
WHY WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT

We are aiming to raise $7,500 to cover the remaining cost of printing the publication, securing exhibition space, and costs associated with shipping artworks.

PROJECT CONTEXT

  • Approximately 30% of artists represented by commercial galleries are women (this does not even begin to break down the statistics on women of color, trans women, those with disabilities, gender non-binary and other non-male persons).*  
  • Roughly 3-5% of major permanent collections are made up by women.**  
  • We could go on but all this to say, women are often finding themselves awaiting permission to land, to work, and to be regarded with the respect they have earned as over half of the world’s producing artists.

WHO WE ARE

  • DADE is a collective of women and femme artists founded in 2017 by Diana Antohe, DS Chapman, Angie Reisch, and Ellen Smith. DADE is dedicated to our mission of supporting non-male makers through providing a platform for their work to be shown.
  • Holding Pattern Vol. I was published in May 2017 and included work from thirteen female-identifying artists. DADE hosted a book launch and panel discussion with the artist collective Toxic Shock at The Wild Detectives in Dallas, Texas to accompany the publication with an active discourse on the issues facing non-male artists in our community.
  • Holding Pattern Vol. II will feature visual artwork from 22 artists and commissioned written works from several writers. The project this year will also include a physical exhibition showcasing artworks from the publication along with selected readings from written works.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Can't donate right now? That's okay! Share our website, video, and campaign - Any little bit helps.

www.dadecollective.com

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BheTm916JM8 

____________________________

*see Hyperallergic's 2014 report

**See Judy Chicago's report for The Guardian

story:
Wes Brady lived a life of hard labor. Born enslaved in the 1850s, he worked other people’s land long after his emancipation and up to the time of his death in the early 20th Century.

“I was born and raised in Harrison County, (Texas) and I was 88 years old this July past and has wore myself out here in this county,” he told a reporter for the U.S. Works Progress Administration, Federal Writers' Project in the 1930s.

Like millions of enslaved African Americans, Brady worked for the benefit of others, never realizing the fruits of his labor nor appreciation for his work.  

Unstolen Dignity recognizes the contributions of enslaved Africans like Brady through the beauty of art and narrative. The project calls for the creation of 25 oil portraits. Each painting is designed to show an enslaved person in a dignified light. The goal is to foster a national conversation about the impact of slavery on the wealth of the United States while reaffirming the dignity of enslaved people.

The Unstolen Dignity crowdfunding campaign is raising money to offset the cost of creating and exhibiting the 25 oil portraits. The paintings will be displayed in galleries around the country. A coffee-table book also will be developed from the project.

Ladale Lloyd is a Florida-based artist specializing in oil portraiture, Florida landscape paintings and photography. An award-winning artist, his works are included in several public and private collections. He is also a former journalist and teacher.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

Funding is needed to complete about 16 more painting, purchase portrait-quality frames, research and write narratives for each of the paintings and cover the costs of a traveling exhibition.

In appreciation for your donations, I have put together a generous list of perks and incentives. They range from heart-felt thank-you cards to Unstolen Dignity mugs, tote bags and an opportunity to have one of your enslaved ancestors or family members painted by me. 

 

The Impact

Contributing to this project will help bring the faces and stories of unsung enslaved Americans to the national consciousness and spark important conversations about the impact of slavery on the country.

Risks & Challenges

Raising money to hold exhibits in major U.S. cities is the most pressing challenge. Completing the paintings, researching and writing about the subjects also pose challenges. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Sponsoring an exhibit in a major U.S. city.  Every little bit helps. If you're unable to contribute financially, you still may help by spreading the word about this project on social media and offline to family and friends.

story:
“Another World is Possible: Five Decades of Revolutionary Art with Ricardo Levins Morales” will open on October fifth in Minneapolis. It will be a visual feast of social justice movement history seen through the art I've been making in support of peoples struggles since 1968. The show will be up for 50 days (grand opening party on Oct.5th!) and will include inter-generational panels, discussions, ceremonies and classes.

Making this exhibit happen – including paying artists and panelists, producing the program books we'll give away, mounting pieces of art that haven't seen the light of day since Nixon was president, (Oh and food! Don't forget the food!) – takes money. This whole thing is being organized as an interactive community encounter with histories of resilience and struggle and I would love to have community support to cover some of the cost.

Please consider making a contribution. I can't entice you by letting you in free because it's all free. We (me and the wonderful committee that is making it happen) can offer you a print of my commemorative exhibit poster for donations of $25 or more. I also hope to see you there during the time it is on display at CTUL (Centro de Trabajadores Unidos en la Lucha), the trailblazing low-wage worker organizing center. 

 

Exhibit Info

October 5th-November 22nd at CTUL (Centro de Trabajadores Unidos en Lucha) 3715 Chicago Ave, Minneapolis, MN 55407.  October 5th, Opening 5pm-8:00pm

General Open Hours

Mondays 9am-5pm

Tuesdays 9am-5pm

Wednesdays 9am-8pm

Thursdays: 9am-8pm

Fridays 9am-5pm

Saturdays 11am-3pm

Have questions? Visit our website: www.rlmartstudio.com/exhibit
or contact our exhibit coordinator, Sagirah Shahid: sagirahshahid@gmail.com

story:
A Love Letter Project to Give Earth a Voice

It is no secret, no surprise that our ecology and our environment are in a precarious position. You are standing in the moment where this problem is so grand that the only solution is to overwhelm it with love and attention. That's what we believe, and we want you to join us. 

Have you ever received a love letter? If you have, you know how strong it is. This project is about bottling up the feeling of receiving something special. And sharing that spark of surprise and curiosity with as many people as possible. But this time around, it will be signed "love, earth".

We are a group of artists, creators, poets, writers, designers, architects and scientists. We all feel the need to act. But we need your help for one simple thing: 

Join us and write a letter of love from our planet. 

If you do, you will kickstart the largest love letter collective ever conceived, and help build the beginning of a structure that aims to be the largest physical message of love ever seen on the planet. One that can be seen from space. And one that is supported by thousands of small messages of love.

The beginning of this massive love, earth structure, the centrepiece comma altar, will be built at Burning Man 2019. This altar, the comma cathedral will hold your letters of love as a collective symbol until after the event, at which time they will be distributed to their recipients. 

 

Send Love, Signed Earth, to Humanity

Yes, we plan to build the largest love letter ever conceived. One you can see from space. And we need your help to do it. But first to prove it works, we are calling for a collective grassroots spirit that showcases the emotional and spiritual impact that a small, handheld love letter can have on us.

In order to fulfill the giant-sized, multi-year effort to bring to life the largest love letter ever seen, the soul of the project needs to be supported by a cascade of love letters, signed love, earth. Why? Because a letter the size that we are planning needs to be full of intention. 

This is where you come in. We are asking you to contribute to a collection of small, but important messages. The comma cathedral, the structure we are building, needs to be filled with letters from the place we call home. The goal for Burning Man 2019? One thousand letters that each give Earth a voice. With the result being a love letter force that fills the comma cathedral, and after the event, sends out a siren call that inspires and intrigues. 

 

How this Project Works 

This is undoubtably a unique project. The goal: to inspire more people to join the small minority of us making changes to balance society with our ecology. We care deeply. Do you? Here's how love, earth works. 

W R I T E R S : 

  1. We want you to write a super simple message of love, writing of hope, desire for change, call to action, wish, rally cry or dear commitment. Send it to us at letters@signedloveearth.com; 
  2. Send your message along with an intended recipient, either in the form of an email address or Instagram handle. You don't need to know the recipient personally, and in fact, that might even be more intriguing; 
  3. Donate to the project, picking the reward level that most inspires you; 
  4. Your message will be part of a growing collection of letters. We will produce your letter physically, hang it within the comma structure at Burning Man and photograph it within; 
  5. Your message will be sent, from @signedloveearth. After the event, you can expect your love letter to be digitally distributed, tagging your recipient. 

R E C E I V E R S : 

  1. Receivers are tagged in a digital copy of the letter, addressed to them from Mother Earth, either by email or in Instagram; 
  2. Receivers are provided an opportunity to respond and to pass along the gift to another, continuing the chain.

 

The Comma Cathedral at Burning Man

We need your help to build a structure that might just be the largest comma ever constructed, the centrepiece of what aims to be the largest love letter ever conceived. A love letter altar that forms a sacred gathering place for interaction and recommitment. This installation is the coming alive of a cathedral to house your messages of love. 
 
The comma, one of the most subtly powerful symbols of our written language, typically separates two intentions. It slows the rhythm of the reader. It is signifies emphasis, reminding us what is important. And sets us free in a fleeting moment to ponder what comes next. Looking down from high above the desert, the love, earth comma represents these poetic combinations and marks a passage of transition to the future. One where our atmosphere is carbon negative and our ecology is reset to thrive.

Imagine this ethereal emblem emerging as a sanctuary of love in the desert. Inside the structure, we are creating a nexus point to unite written words, emotion and action. A place to channel the most powerful human feeling, that of love, through poem and rhyme, characters and phrases, to better connect all of us to the planet’s urgent siren.

Within the structure, an interactive love letter writing area supports a hanging collection of completed letters that will grow, drawing on you and eventually, citizens of Burning Man, to contribute and collectively display one thousand love letters from Earth, distributed around the world after the event by the artists.

A photogenic and interactive wood CNC structure, this comma cathedral will house your letters. And while it will be packed away after Burning Man 2019, in future years will continue to grow in size and scale, popping up and expanding, until the entire love, earth message can be captured by cameras in orbit around our planet. 

 

The Future love, earth Expansion 

The beginning stage of love, earth will focus on the creation of the comma cathedral, kickstarting a love letter collection that we hope to grow into one of the largest in the world. With a successful project in August 2019, the group hopes to continue this momentum into the coming years, building the largest physical love letter ever conceived. This expanded structure would be the entire love, earth statement, and would be built so large it could be captured by orbital satellite imagery. 

While this next phase of the project may seem outlandish, it is the scale of the creation that holds the potential to inspire a great number of people. Supplied with impressive imagery from above, the project has the potential to turn one thousand love letters into ten thousand. From ten thousand to one million. And inspire action on a large scale. 

This project is important to the environmental problem we face as a society. We need to make the problem real for others, and to overwhelm it with love. Help create the largest love letter ever conceived, spreading love at a scale of massive proportions. 

 

The Romantic Inspiration 

This project originated as inspired art to a unique wedding. Having decided that the Black Rock Desert would be the location of their official union after thirteen years together, two of the lead artists, Dawn and Jordan, asked "how could we share what we have between us, with everyone?" 

"It is a gift Dawn has consistently surprised me with for the entirety of our relationship. Small, handwritten love letters appear everywhere and consistently in my life. On my desk, inside my travel bags and in the most random locations. Always short, romantic and caring, they always remind me that Dawn and I are connected with a most unique love, a bond that only the two of us know." 

"When we set out to get married at Burning Man, this was a way for me to honour our relationship in the grandest way possible. But more so, this artistic idea allowed both Dawn and I the ability to share one of the most intimate parts of our relationship with those who choose to take part. An interactive gift you can pass along to others, simply by surprising them with a message of love. I wanted to share with the world the feeling of receiving unexpected affection in the form of a letter. A feeling I know so well, and an emotion that I feel has the potential to change so much."

"Yet after talking with others, we all felt that focusing the outward energy, positivity and spirit on the biggest problem of our time: catastrophic environmental changes. There's a big group of us who believe we just need to be reminded of the deep connection each one of us shares with Mother Nature. It's when we are aware of this love and connection that good things happen." - Jordan Kallman

 

Project Creatives 

While the union of Dawn and Jordan inspired the project, there is a large collective of creatives behind the project. The group is made up of people with a track record of delivering complex projects at significant scale. But most importantly, this is a group of dreamers who believe that love might be the easiest way to unlock a solution to our biggest problems. 

For the past ten years, Jordan Kallman has co-led his event design and experiential agency, The Social Concierge. Since the agency's inception, Jordan has been responsible for the successful creation of ten annual cultural festivals and events, each one ranging in size initially from a few hundred to many thousands. In 2016, he co-created the largest dinner party in his country's history with over 7,000 diners attending a pop-up dinner on a single evening. A selection of his work can be found in highlights below. 

Michael Green is an award-winning architect known for his research, leadership, and advocacy in promoting the use of wood, new technology and innovation in the built environment. He lectures internationally on the subject, including his TED talk, “Why We Should Build Wooden Skyscrapers.” 

Stuart Lodge, an emerging expert at the intersection of robotics, 3D printing and wood products, is the lead designer of the love, earth comma cathedral. Having designed a number of wooden CNC pavilions for the TED Conference over the years, Stuart expertise was perfect for the love, earth comma cathedral. 

Other artists and poets involved in the project include visual designer Matt Wood, creative mind Briony Crane and serial entrepreneur, Dorian Banks. The project includes a number of renowned poets, who have committed to writing letters of love and will include physical pieces within the comma cathedral itself. 

 

What We Need

In order to create the comma altar and to execute the project, we are looking for two things: 

  1. Funding to assist with the project's material and fabrication costs
  2. Love letters, sent to us by you, to hang within the structure and start the movement

P R O J E C T   C O S T S :

The project's total cost is in excess of $40,000 USD, without accounting for the many contributions provided by our collective of designers, artists, engineers and builders. We are looking to raise $18,000+ USD to cover the costs of materials and fabrication alone. This budget breaks down as follows: 

  • 300 sheets of 1/2" plywood: $10,000
  • Hardware and fasteners: $2,000 
  • CNC wood cut fabrication of all plywood: $9,000 
  • Physical love letters, grommets and wind proof hang system: $1,200
  • Shipping, logistics and movement: $7,300
  • Lighting and power generation: $1,800

This equates to a stack of sustainably sourced plywood two stories high, twenty thousand screws, hundreds of hours of CNC cutting machine time, thousands of physical love letters, a 40' sea container and theatrical lighting to give this structure a nighttime glow. All human effort to the project is being donated, including designers, engineers, architects, build crew, photographers and dreamers. 

The funds that are raised will go towards the project's cost. Whatever budget gap remains will be covered by the lead artists of the project. If more than the project's costs are raised, any excess funding will be used to fund the larger installation in future years, creating the largest physical love letter ever conceived. To ensure the most sustainable outcome, any excess dollars this year will be channelled first to plant trees and ultimately offset atmospheric carbon of this year's installation. 

 

What You Get

Aside from the campaign rewards, you get to take part in the beginning of a special effort. Initial project backers and letter writers, will be highly cherished by the project artists and will be represented moving forward as initial founders. We encourage you to be part of this journey with us. 

This project is deeply connected to the arts, to design and to the love of writing. Because of this root connection, the project rewards are broken down into three main categories.  

R E W A R D S   C A T E G O R I E S :

  • Signed books and unique collectables from our roster of best-selling authors and poets; 
  • Special edition and single print run photography, plans, schematics, accessories and engravings of the love, earth comma altar; 
  • Unique ways to integrate your contributions at the love, earth altar, from having your name engraved on the structure as a founding member to experiencing a one-of-a-kind dinner within the art piece.

 

Risks and Challenges

love, earth is a passion-filled art project. But of course, any one-of-a-kind art project is fraught with risk. Not to mention, the love, earth structure is being built in the middle of the Black Rock Desert, one of the most unforgiving environments on the planet. 

Risks and challenges include construction delays, severe weather, assembly issues and potential lag in sending out the letters of love after Burning Man. Having a lead artist who is a seasoned veteran of event and festival productions, someone who regularly operates on a condensed timeline, will help to ensure the project remains on-track. A dedicated and experienced build crew made up of carpenters and technicians will also ensure a committed culture, one that will see the end project through to a positive conclusion. The project is supported by registered architects and engineers who build some of the world's tallest wood structures. 

love, earth is a risky endeavour, but with the help of funding from generous backers, this project has enormous potential to grow into the future. We welcome you to our community of creatives in spreading love, and in doing so, we will build momentum, overcoming challenges as a collective. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know not everyone is able to donate. We welcome all. If you feel inspired and simply want to write a love letter from earth to someone, send it to us at letters@signedloveearth.com. We will ensure it is included in the project. 

Please follow along at @signedloveearth and of course please share this campaign if you appreciate what we are trying to do. 

Join us and write a letter of love from our planet. 

@signedloveearth

letters@signedloveearth.com

Are you a visual artist or poet who would like to support this project? If so, send us an email at letters@signedloveearth.com to get involved. We are looking for creatives who believe in change, love and our ability to affect the future.

story:
Project Summary     

Hello! It’s me, Amy. I’m a 45-year-old American ceramic artist, master of sociology, and single mom hailing from Pennsylvania with the chance to relaunch my career in ceramics after a longer than anticipated hiatus, in the form of a self-created residency/apprenticeship in Peru. 

I'm already here in Peru and well on my way! Your support will allow me to continue making work for an additional 6 months, where I can advance my skills and a body of work, re-establish myself as a functioning artist, research ongoing opportunities for my return, apprentice the business-side of an active production studio, make partnerships and connections that will serve me beyond my time in Peru, and, of course, sell my stuff!

Formally trained in ceramics/fine arts at Alfred University’s esteemed college of ceramics, I began my career 20 years ago working for a ceramic artist/interior designer in NYC and eventually in Peru, where my time was ultimately cut short when I unwittingly left to embark on single-motherhood and social service! It’s again in Peru where I have the opportunity to redirect my career back to where it began.

I've always received an enthusiastic response to my work. People like it! I’m confident it has a place in the world. What I haven’t had are the resources and time to develop and produce more prolifically, to actually get it IN the world. 

I have skills, I have space, I have opportunity, I have a network. I just need a little more funding!

Through planning, networking, and both longstanding and new connections in Peru I've been able to manifest a visa, studio space and living arrangement in Cieneguilla, Peru, a small town just outside of Lima, through March 2020.

My studio space is set within a small ceramics production studio, Inka Ceramics, in operation for over 15 years and owned by a longtime friend and Peruvian woman entrepreneur. I’ve spent the better part of the past five months building a small workspace there, developing my craft, routine and creative process, working out technical snags and developing glazes while assessing costs, needs, challenges and opportunities before deciding to crowdfund.

     I'm turning a corner towards several opportunities after a lot of groundwork, but for the benefits to keep outweighing the costs, I need to make a more generous front-end investment to continue ongoing development and production.

 

What I Need & What You Get!

My fundraising goal is calculated to cover basic materials and tools through March 2020, allowing me to take full advantage of this unique opportunity. It includes the following:

  • Clay
  • Natural gas and kiln use for individual gas-kiln firings.
  • Raw materials for glaze formulation/testing.
  • Underglazes and stains.
  • Additional studio equipment and tools as needed.
  • Travel costs! Including transportation of work from the studio to Lima and research/business outside of Cieneguilla such as gift shows and studio visits.
  • Fees associated with calls for entry, grant and residency applications.
  • Photography accessories for professional documentation of work.
  • Website development associated business tools.
  • Packing materials and international shipping costs for additional perks, sales, and shows.
  • Business cards.

 

If I do not reach my entire funding goal, what I raise will still go towards the bullet points above, but less time factored in Peru and redirected towards continuing this pursuit back home. Anything over my goal will be used towards future phases of development. 

PERKS!

Receive a personalized thank you from Cieneguilla on any contribution of $10 or more!

For $50, $75, or $125, select from a variety of mugs - with demitasse and full-size options. I will be shipping primarily internationally, so perks are small-scale and shipping costs are absorbed for simplicity (which means $0 added shipping!).   

These mugs are one of a kind and meant to be uniquely personal for each user. Mugs will be like what is pictured, but not exact.  Colorways may vary as glazes are still in development. The element of surprise is currently part of this experience! Embrace it.

Other Ways To Help

Get the word out! If you are unable to contribute financially but believe in me and my project, you can help by spreading the word and sharing this campaign with interested folks!

The Impact

Reaching this goal will give me time to intensively develop my craft and work in a way I have not been afforded until now, and one I don't know if or when I can recreate. My creative process and perspective are being enriched more by this experience than any current alternative. That enrichment will ultimately express itself through my work, how I show-up in this world, and what I bring to the table as an individual.

Helping me also means the chance to help Peruvian women in business! My collaboration with Inka Ceramics, which is woman-owned and an employer of majority women, is mutually beneficial in our potential to advance one another's growth.

I get the benefit of having access to a production studio, equipment, and connections to business opportunities. In turn, my success has the potential to generate business and growth for Inka Ceramics, which positively impacts the local community, particularly women.

I've boot-strapped myself farther than I imagined by following opportunities, trusting my instincts and abilities, and taking a big leap of faith, but I've reached a crossroads. The support I receive here will dictate my next steps and in what direction this journey takes me.

Risks & Challenges

  • Ceramics can be unforgiving and unpredictable. It’s time-consuming. Technical problems, functional problems, glaze problems, firing problems are all part of the process, especially in phases of development, exploration and experimentation.

 

  • I work outdoors and often use elements from the natural environment to make forms, so I’m constantly adjusting to how climate and nature effect my processes and timing.

 

  • Several common glaze materials I am accustomed to using are not available here and can only be imported. I’m creating my own glazes with limited materials, different from what I know, while also re-learning the calculation process. Figuring out where and how to get certain materials and testing new formulas has made developing glazes take longer than I would like!

 

  • I'm in Peru! I’m without the ease, abundance and convenience found in more developed countries. Things are harder to find, transportation is challenging, and everything is slower. The studio is Spanish-speaking only and, although I speak Spanish well, talking production and business are new contexts for me, even in English! 

 

The good news is these challenges are all manageable, just a bit slower to work through than I would like. Additionally, they are enhancing my problem-solving skills and depth of experience!

A Little More of My Story

Thank you for staying with me this far and thank you (hopefully) for your support!

Here's a bit more about me, if you're feeling it.

I’ve been a single, full-time working parent for 18 years. With limited supports and resources and a child diagnosed with type-1 diabetes as a baby, best-interest dictated choices that took me away from my creative network and trajectory at the time, down a long path of challenges and into a career of social service and advocacy, which I am also passionate about!

I never fully quit creating, nor gave up on one day returning to my roots in clay and as a maker, whenever that became possible. I thought that would be a few years. It turned out to be quite a few more! My son just graduated high school and we are both taking advantage of this moment to transition into our new independence before he goes to college. For me, that’s in the form of an intentional restructuring of my life and work.

I’ve spent the past two years preparing for this transition by simultaneously completing a master’s degree in sociology and working in clay again, looking for my path back into the world of ceramics. I’ve always envisioned an eventual marriage of my two career paths, but where I need and want to catch up is in my craft!

Happily, what I’m doing now allows me to satisfy both my artist and sociologist sides. I’m fully immersed in the culture of the small community where I’m staying during my time here, where I am generally the only non-Peruvian. I’m walking distance from the studio, able to live simply, and highly engaged with the natural environment around me. I’m also connected to a nonprofit home for boys near where I live, where I completed volunteer fieldwork towards my master’s degree and where I may have the potential to offer clay workshops in the future.

I'm grateful and blessed to be doing what I am doing and excited to see where it takes me. With your help, I look forward to finding out where that is.
story_txt:
Project Summary     
Hello! It’s me, Amy. I’m a 45-year-old American ceramic artist, master of sociology, and single mom hailing from Pennsylvania with the chance to relaunch my career in ceramics after a longer than anticipated hiatus, in the form of a self-created residency/apprenticeship in Peru. 
I'm already here in Peru and well on my way! Your support will allow me to continue making work for an additional 6 months, where I can advance my skills and a body of work, re-establish myself as a functioning artist, research ongoing opportunities for my return, apprentice the business-side of an active production studio, make partnerships and connections that will serve me beyond my time in Peru, and, of course, sell my stuff!

Formally trained in ceramics/fine arts at Alfred University’s esteemed college of ceramics, I began my career 20 years ago working for a ceramic artist/interior designer in NYC and eventually in Peru, where my time was ultimately cut short when I unwittingly left to embark on single-motherhood and social service! It’s again in Peru where I have the opportunity to redirect my career back to where it began.
I've always received an enthusiastic response to my work. People like it! I’m confident it has a place in the world. What I haven’t had are the resources and time to develop and produce more prolifically, to actually get it IN the world. 
I have skills, I have space, I have opportunity, I have a network. I just need a little more funding!


Through planning, networking, and both longstanding and new connections in Peru I've been able to manifest a visa, studio space and living arrangement in Cieneguilla, Peru, a small town just outside of Lima, through March 2020.
My studio space is set within a small ceramics production studio, Inka Ceramics, in operation for over 15 years and owned by a longtime friend and Peruvian woman entrepreneur. I’ve spent the better part of the past five months building a small workspace there, developing my craft, routine and creative process, working out technical snags and developing glazes while assessing costs, needs, challenges and opportunities before deciding to crowdfund.
     I'm turning a corner towards several opportunities after a lot of groundwork, but for the benefits to keep outweighing the costs, I need to make a more generous front-end investment to continue ongoing development and production.
 
What I Need & What You Get!
My fundraising goal is calculated to cover basic materials and tools through March 2020, allowing me to take full advantage of this unique opportunity. It includes the following:


Clay

Natural gas and kiln use for individual gas-kiln firings.
Raw materials for glaze formulation/testing.
Underglazes and stains.
Additional studio equipment and tools as needed.
Travel costs! Including transportation of work from the studio to Lima and research/business outside of Cieneguilla such as gift shows and studio visits.
Fees associated with calls for entry, grant and residency applications.
Photography accessories for professional documentation of work.
Website development associated business tools.
Packing materials and international shipping costs for additional perks, sales, and shows.
Business cards.

 
If I do not reach my entire funding goal, what I raise will still go towards the bullet points above, but less time factored in Peru and redirected towards continuing this pursuit back home. Anything over my goal will be used towards future phases of development. 
PERKS!



Receive a personalized thank you from Cieneguilla on any contribution of $10 or more!
For $50, $75, or $125, select from a variety of mugs - with demitasse and full-size options. I will be shipping primarily internationally, so perks are small-scale and shipping costs are absorbed for simplicity (which means $0 added shipping!).   
These mugs are one of a kind and meant to be uniquely personal for each user. Mugs will be like what is pictured, but not exact.  Colorways may vary as glazes are still in development. The element of surprise is currently part of this experience! Embrace it.
Other Ways To Help
Get the word out! If you are unable to contribute financially but believe in me and my project, you can help by spreading the word and sharing this campaign with interested folks!
The Impact

Reaching this goal will give me time to intensively develop my craft and work in a way I have not been afforded until now, and one I don't know if or when I can recreate. My creative process and perspective are being enriched more by this experience than any current alternative. That enrichment will ultimately express itself through my work, how I show-up in this world, and what I bring to the table as an individual.

Helping me also means the chance to help Peruvian women in business! My collaboration with Inka Ceramics, which is woman-owned and an employer of majority women, is mutually beneficial in our potential to advance one another's growth.
I get the benefit of having access to a production studio, equipment, and connections to business opportunities. In turn, my success has the potential to generate business and growth for Inka Ceramics, which positively impacts the local community, particularly women.
I've boot-strapped myself farther than I imagined by following opportunities, trusting my instincts and abilities, and taking a big leap of faith, but I've reached a crossroads. The support I receive here will dictate my next steps and in what direction this journey takes me.

I work outdoors and often use elements from the natural environment to make forms, so I’m constantly adjusting to how climate and nature effect my processes and timing.
 
Several common glaze materials I am accustomed to using are not available here and can only be imported. I’m creating my own glazes with limited materials, different from what I know, while also re-learning the calculation process. Figuring out where and how to get certain materials and testing new formulas has made developing glazes take longer than I would like!
 
I'm in Peru! I’m without the ease, abundance and convenience found in more developed countries. Things are harder to find, transportation is challenging, and everything is slower. The studio is Spanish-speaking only and, although I speak Spanish well, talking production and business are new contexts for me, even in English!

story:
Welcome to the Black Arctic.

The Black Arctic is an ongoing art research project developed during my master's thesis while at the Sandberg Academie in Amsterdam. It is a speculative region established by slaves lost to sea during the slave trade who then, after drifting northwards of the Middle Passage (the  route in the North Atlantic used during the slave trade) and build their own civilization. It features its own mythologies, its own heros, its own style of music, its own style of art.

In other words, it is an afrofuturist dream.

I'm using it to develop new methods of discussing the current state of Blackness and Black being through art, music, spoken word, and film. Much like Sun Ra's Space is the Place, the Black Arctic provides a transformative space outside of colonialism and allows for radical methods of thought, creation, and critique.  I want to study the evolution of our culture through the sheer act of producing culture itself in colonial-free context. 

As a major part of this research and project, I will traveling to the Arctic ocean later this year as a part of an art/science expedition that will last three weeks.

And it will be amazing. 
I will conduct field research and recordings, I will map geography, I will run around atop of a glacier and commune with the spirit of climate change. But most importantly,

I will be making a short film about the Black Arctic.

This film will contain two spoken word performances; Sirens and The Death of Darius P. Jenkins (and his life thereafter). Both of which are performed by the emissary of the Black Arctic, Darius P. Jenkins.

Introducing Darius, emissary of the Black Arctic. He freed himself - mentally, emotionally, and politically - from the United States of America after sensationalism of Black death due to police violence caused pikes in television news viewership. And he is so excited to perform in the Arctic for you all.

 

This is where you come in.

This expedition will not be cheap and requires resources I don't currently have.
So, I'm asking for your help to conduct this research, to produce this film, and to bring the Black Arctic into our reality!

 

Here is what  I will need.

I need $2500 to cover the initial payment of the expedition, which is what I am asking you to help with. This will help cover such things as:

  • Booking sea vessel suitable for Arctic sailing, its crew, and provisions for three weeks.
  • Room and board for three weeks
  • Hotel in Svalbard before and after the residency.

Anything over the amount needed will go towards;

  • Recording equipment (audio and film)
  • Suitable clothing for Arctic conditions
  • Costume for Darius P. Jenkins
  • Airfare

What I can give you.

Everyone donating will have exclusive film viewings after it is completed, and before it goes to anyone else. And, of course, I have a selection of other things for you too!

  • All donations receive a personal thank you email.
  • A personally written thank you, from Darius to you. 
  • Social media shout outs
  • A digital copy of wę, a short story in parts about about the impossibility of utopia in a world shaped by colonialism, about the inevitability of death and the persistence of our afterlives, about the oil spill that is time.
  • A printed copy of wę
  • Sirens EP, featuring a spoken word piece as a map that will guide you to the Black Arctic, while warning you about the dangers of sirens; both mythological and real. This comes on a USB stick and contains three versions (full, instrumental, and vocal), the stick is shipped inside a bottle with a custom SIRENS label.
  • And another coming soon...

 

Apropos COVID-19

I understand that we are living in unprecedented times, at least within living memory. 
Funds are tight, maybe some of you aren't even working, maybe all of you are undergoing a severe sort of cabin fever from the social isolation.  I feel for you. 

There are a lot of unknowns these days, and all of it is a little scary, really. 
However there is great solace in the unknown, simply because the unknown has not been clearly defined.  This gives us the change to define it ourselves, and in doing so we gain access to certain arenas in life that were, possibly, inaccessible to us before. 

The Black Arctic is a chance to define some of that unknown, a chance to redefine what we already know. And, best of all, you get to take an active role in all of it. 
Quite frankly, I will not be able to do this without your help. 


If you can't contribute, that is ok! 
You can still help by..

  • Getting the word out, make some noise about the campaign. Tell your mom, your father, your grandparents, your cousins, your best friend, your best friend's dog, and whoever/whatever else has two ears or two hands or two eyes that will listen to you. 
  • I also require arctic clothing, equipment, and airfare! Can you donate clothes? Great! Have a contact mic that you are looking to get rid of? Donate it, I'll take it! Wait, do you work for an airline?  Discounts!? Yes that's amazing!
  • Or, wait, did you want to contribute but can't because INDIEGOGO doesn't accept IDEAL? That's ok too, I also accept Paypal.

The Impact

This project is new, fresh, exciting, and highly relevant. It is a collision of design and academic research, it will produce new entry points within the Diasporic dialectic, and I think these sorts of works are vital as we continue to dismantle colonial power systems.
Additionally, I will be using this film:

  • As part of the ongoing work that is the Black Arctic, which includes spoken word and music, and eventually a hefty amount of academia. 
  • For touring in galleries/exhibition spaces.
  • All research and research outcomes will be used as a foundation for a future PhD

Thank you so much!

I appreciate your time and your help. 
Now let's make this happen!
