story:
About the Project

Hi! My name is Lyla Shlon and I need your help in acquiring a lithography press for my upcoming collaborative workshop in Baltimore, MD. I studied printmaking at the Maryland Institute College of Art and went on to do the Printer Training Program specifically for collaborative lithography at the Tamarind Institute in New Mexico.  

I am in the process of establishing a collaborative lithography workshop here in Baltimore, MD and am missing a big part of the picture: A PRESS!

Charles Brand 36" x 60" lithography press

A community print shop, Studio Two Three in Richmond, VA, is selling the press that will help me get my workshop started here in Baltimore. By contributing to this campaign you are not only helping the print community in Baltimore gain a lithography shop, but also helping an established communal printshop in Richmond make space for their new press!

Lithography is a process that is done traditionally using limestone as the matrix for printing. The basis of the process is the rejection of water by oil. Lithography is a planographic process and these stones can be used over and over again by graining off the surface of the stone. The image is created by an artist on the surface using greasy materials and then etched to create a grease loving reservoir just under the surface of the stone. By keeping the stone wet and using oil based ink, one can create multiples prints off the surface of the stone! Lithography is used in the contemporary art world as a fine arts printing process.

A drawing on limestone and materials for drawing, art by Zoe Keller

Currently I am using the printmaking facilities at the Maryland Institute College of Art (MICA) to facilitate collaborations and make work. As grateful as I am to have the department welcome me back to use their equipment, it is time to move out of working in a student shop.

Baltimore has a thriving arts community with many opportunities for visibility in the art world. With spaces popping up for studios and gallery shows, support for community projects and public art- Baltimore is a wonderful city to be printing in. Many of the artists working in Baltimore had access to print media through school and, once they graduated, had no facility to continue to explore printmaking. Two Birds One Stone Editions is a chance to bring collaborative lithography back to Baltimore. The amount of interest from artists in this city for printed matter demands a collaborative shop like this one. By contributing to this campaign you help give this community a workspace for fine arts editions and lets us share a part of our community with you! Print is multiples, print is accessible, print is for the people!

What We Need

The initial $7000: Studio Two Three is asking $5000 for the press itself, scraper bars, a plate backer and tympan for the press. The additional $2000 will pay for the riggers and freight to move the press from Richmond to Baltimore.

Any additional funds raised past the initial $7000 will go into other equipment for the workshop, particularly- stones, plates, scraper bars, rollers etc! 

What You Get!

Your fabulous generosity will be rewarded with PRINT! The perks to this campaign are detailed on the right side of the page. A peek at some of the prints offered in this campaign:

The 7 Color lithograph offered at the $250 level, and a detail shot of the pigment

Magnolia, an etching by Jonathan Thomas, 15 x 17

The final print from the recent collaboration with Zoe Keller, only available through this campaign as a $100 reward

The Impact

Viewing prints, new and old, is very accessible to the community here in Baltimore. Every other year we host the Baltimore Print Fair at the Baltimore Museum of Art, which brings in many of the contemporary well known publishers and dealers of fine prints. We have our own Prints and Multiples fair every spring that showcases artists working in print and is very much a display of our own arts community. With all of these ways to be inspired by print in this city, we're doing a disservice to our arts community by not having a facility like this one. Printmaking is a very community oriented experience, not just in the ability to share multiples- but also with the environment of most print shops involving many people working in one space. With people constantly being a part of, or being invited in to work in, these shops, they can become their own little communities. 

This shop will not only produce fine arts editions, but serve as a resource for artists interested in working lithographically and with a technically trained printer. The tradition of collaborative lithography is one that I aim to keep people interested in. Collaborative oriented projects are unique to work on, and the relationship between an artist and their printer is a special one. Collaborative printers can inform their artists work in the studio, and artists bring interesting challenges to the table for their printers. A printer can suggest techniques their artist might never have thought to use, and an artist can bring expectations for the process the printer might not have considered. These working relationships are informative for both parties involved, an artist might learn something about their studio practice and a printer might discover new techniques they can use again in the future.

Artist Zoe Keller working on a collaborative print with Lyla Shlon at MICA

The print industry, until recently, has been largely dominated by men. Also as a women printer, I feel a certain responsibility as a role model to other young women who are interested in the print world. I want to be a resource not just for a community of artists, but also a community of upcoming printers who face the challenges of being women in this industry. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you're excited about this campaign but cannot contribute, don't fret! You can still help by using the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign all over the internet! Thank you for sharing and looking, I'm so happy you're excited about this project!


Thank you: Gabe Dinsmoor for making the fabulous video for this campaign, Jonathan Thomas and Zoe Keller for graciously donating their work, Tori Baggot for taking photos and Elise Dransfield for the type design!

The 7 Color lithograph offered at the $250 level, and a detail shot of the pigment



Magnolia, an etching by Jonathan Thomas, 15 x 17

The final print from the recent collaboration with Zoe Keller, only available through this campaign as a $100 reward

The Impact Viewing prints, new and old, is very accessible to the community here in Baltimore. Every other year we host the Baltimore Print Fair at the Baltimore Museum of Art, which brings in many of the contemporary well known publishers and dealers of fine prints. We have our own Prints and Multiples fair every spring that showcases artists working in print and is very much a display of our own arts community. With all of these ways to be inspired by print in this city, we're doing a disservice to our arts community by not having a facility like this one. Printmaking is a very community oriented experience, not just in the ability to share multiples- but also with the environment of most print shops involving many people working in one space. With people constantly being a part of, or being invited in to work in, these shops, they can become their own little communities. 
This shop will not only produce fine arts editions, but serve as a resource for artists interested in working lithographically and with a technically trained printer. The tradition of collaborative lithography is one that I aim to keep people interested in. Collaborative oriented projects are unique to work on, and the relationship between an artist and their printer is a special one. Collaborative printers can inform their artists work in the studio, and artists bring interesting challenges to the table for their printers. A printer can suggest techniques their artist might never have thought to use, and an artist can bring expectations for the process the printer might not have considered. These working relationships are informative for both parties involved, an artist might learn something about their studio practice and a printer might discover new techniques they can use again in the future.


Artist Zoe Keller working on a collaborative print with Lyla Shlon at MICA

The print industry, until recently, has been largely dominated by men. Also as a women printer, I feel a certain responsibility as a role model to other young women who are interested in the print world. I want to be a resource not just for a community of artists, but also a community of upcoming printers who face the challenges of being women in this industry. 







    Other Ways You Can Help If you're excited about this campaign but cannot contribute, don't fret! You can still help by using the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign all over the internet! Thank you for sharing and looking, I'm so happy you're excited about this project!

Thank you: Gabe Dinsmoor for making the fabulous video for this campaign, Jonathan Thomas and Zoe Keller for graciously donating their work, Tori Baggot for taking photos and Elise Dransfield for the type design!

story:
Short Summary

Hello, we are a group of undergraduate and graduate students at Ohio University's School of Art + Design. 
This summer, we have been offered the opportunity to study at the International Ceramics Studio in Kecskemet, Hungary for four weeks. 
We are hoping to raise partial funds for this residency by offering small gifts to those who donate. 
(please see below for full student participant profiles)
What We Need  

The program will cost each student approximately $7,000 for airfare, room, board, and the program fees. 

We are asking for about a 1/3 of this cost in donations in order to supplement the potential scholarships and financial aid we are already seeking through the university. 

Our program will be from July 1st, 2015 to August 2nd, 2015 and will include:

  •  3 weeks of studio access at the International Ceramics Studio
  •  An exhibition showcasing our work at the end of the residency
  • Required undergraduate and graduate classes taught by OU faculty                     and faculty at the Ceramics Studio
  • Symposium lectures
  • Tours of the areas surrounding Kecskemet including Romania and                         Transylvania


What You Get

$10 gets you a postcard from Hungary by the Ohio University art students.

$15 gets you a postcard and an original sticker made by the Ohio University art students. 

$25 gets you a postcard and a poster with an original screenprinted image created by the Ohio University art students. 

$50 gets you a postcard and a t-shirt in your size printed by the Ohio University art students.

 $75 gets you a postcard and a handmade ceramic mug made by the Ohio University art students.

$100 and above gets you a postcard and any 2 other items from the above list of perks. 


The Impact

We understand the unique opportunity this presents for us. Through this program, many of us are able to travel internationally for the first time. Additionally, the opportunity to display our work at the International Ceramic Studio is an honor and a valuable experience. 

Other Ways You Can Help


Please share our fundraising page with others to help spread the word. 

Thank you for visiting the OU Ceramics Hungary Trip page! 


Participating Students


Allison Cochran
Hi my name is Allison Cochran and I am currently a B.F.A candidate in Ceramics at ohio university. I am headed to study ceramics at the international ceramics studio in Keskemet this summer. I am raising money to fund my trip to Romania and Hungary! 

Kelsey Duncan

Originally from Southeast Idaho, Kelsey Duncan received his Bachelors of Fine Art from the University of Montana. Following his undergraduate studies he built a studio at his home in Missoula, Montana where he worked as a full time studio artist.  Drawing heavily from his social and geological surroundings for content, he found a well of inspiration living and working in the Northwest. In the fall of 2012 Kelsey moved to New York for a two-year artist residency at the Clay Art Center. His work has been shown in group and solo exhibitions throughout the United States, most recently in The Zanesville Prize for Contemporary Ceramics.  He joined the Ohio University as a graduate student in the fall of 2014.  Kelsey will be spending his summer teaching at the Clay Art Center and the 92nd street Y in New York City and eagerly awaits his trip to Hungary.


Seana Higgins

Seana Higgins is a Chicago-born artist working in clay and multi-media. She received a BFA in art education and ceramics from University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign in 2008 and did a year of study at Louisiana State University in 2010. She has taught visual arts in a variety of settings including Chicago Public Schools, Lillstreet Art Center, Terra Incognito Studio and Urban Gateways. Higgins was a long-term resident artist at Terra Incognito in Oak Park, Illinois and a short term resident at Red Lodge Clay Center in 2012. She has exhibited in several local and national exhibitions including the 2014 NCECA National Student Juried Exhibition, and Athens Voices traveling juried exhibition earlier this year. Higgins is a second year MFA candidate in the Ceramics department at Ohio University and continues to work both functionally and sculpturally in clay. She plans to use the Hungary trip as a means to explore her Eastern European heritage, using the knowledge gained for continued development of familial themes in her autobiographical sculptural work. 


Rosemary Howell

My name is Rosemary Lakin Howell. I'm from Flatwoods, Ky and studying ceramics at Ohio University.

I hope to go to Hungary to gain new perspectives from a culture outside of my own and work with world reknowned artists in a studio setting.

This opportunity is irreplaceable in the advancement of my education and my artistic endeavors.

Any donations will help me get one step closer to this amazing experience and will be eternally appreciated.


Ellen Kleckner

Ellen Kleckner grew up in the Orange Groves of Southern California, as the “gifted child” in a family of 4 girls with strong midwestern blood. With encouragement from her parents to find something to do with all her energy, she found her love for ceramics.  Her study of ceramics has taken her to the wilds of New York, the wood of Tennessee, the cornfields of Nebraska, and most recently to the hills of Ohio were she is currently at Ceramics Graduate Student.  


 

Amanda Morris

Amanda Morris is a first-generation college student from Louisville, Kentucky. She completed her undergraduate degree at Herron School of Art and Design within IUPUI, located in Indianapolis, Indiana. Morris is currently working on her MFA in Printmaking at Ohio University in Athens, Ohio. She plans on attending the Hungary and Romania Ceramics trip this summer in order to broaden the skills, ideas, and imagery behind her work. ​

  



Steph Wadman

website: stephwadman.com

I hail from !Canada! by way of Tampa, Florida, but am nomading Athens, Ohio while I complete my Masters in Sculpture at Ohio University.

As a sculptor, I am invested in the 3D object, but am inspired by social interaction and communication. While in Hungary I want to make use of the international environment to explore communication across cultures. Specifically, I want to highlight connections between two people whom find themselves unable to communicate with each other. The connections I make will take form in sculpture and will make use of the local Hungarian materials as a reflection of the environment and community that helped to conceptualize and actualize them.
